\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics[width=3485\sphinxpxdimen,height=1290\sphinxpxdimen]{{GridAPPS-D_Logo}.png}

\sphinxAtStartPar
GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D™ is an open\sphinxhyphen{}source platform that accelerates development and deployment of portable applications for advanced distribution management and operations. It is built in a linux environment using Docker, which allows large software packages to be distributed as containers.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Its purpose is to reduce the time and cost to integrate advanced functionality into distribution operations, to create a more reliable and resilient grid.

\sphinxAtStartPar
GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D enables standardization of data models, programming interfaces, and the data exchange interfaces for:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
devices in the field

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
distributed apps in the systems

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
applications in the control room

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The platform provides
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
robust testing tools for applications

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
distribution system simulation capabilities

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
standardized research capability

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
reference architecture for the industry

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
application development kit

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D source code is publically available from \sphinxhref{https://github.com/GRIDAPPSD}{GitHub}. The GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D™ project is sponsored by the U.S. Department of Energy and receives ongoing updates from a team of core developers at PNNL.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D team encourages and appreciates community involvement, including issues and pull requests on GitHub, participation in monthly app developers meetings, and posts on the discussion board.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Questions and support requests should be filed in the \sphinxhref{https://github.com/GRIDAPPSD/gridappsd-forum/discussions}{GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Forum Discussion Board}

\sphinxAtStartPar
General issues and bugs can be reported in the \sphinxhref{https://github.com/GRIDAPPSD/gridappsd-forum/issues}{GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Forum Issues Page}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Bugs in the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D platform can be reported in full detail using the \sphinxhref{https://github.com/GRIDAPPSD/GOSS-GridAPPS-D/issues}{GOSS\sphinxhyphen{}GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Issues Page}


\chapter{Windows 10 Installation}
\label{\detokenize{installation/windows10/index:windows-10-installation}}\label{\detokenize{installation/windows10/index::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This section contains detailed installation instructions and runtime environment tips for running GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D and its dependencies on a Windows 10 machine.


\section{Virtual Machine \& Docker Setup}
\label{\detokenize{installation/windows10/1.1W-Virtual-Machine-Docker-Setup:Virtual-Machine-_-Docker-Setup}}\label{\detokenize{installation/windows10/1.1W-Virtual-Machine-Docker-Setup::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
A typical Windows 10 installation does not include several of the tools needed to run the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform Several software packages need to be installed prior to installing GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D in the next step

\sphinxAtStartPar
Installation Steps:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{installation/windows10/1.1W-Virtual-Machine-Docker-Setup:Verify-System-Requirements}]{\emph{1. Verify System Requirements}}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{installation/windows10/1.1W-Virtual-Machine-Docker-Setup:Verify-OS-Build}]{\emph{2. Verify OS Build}}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{installation/windows10/1.1W-Virtual-Machine-Docker-Setup:Install-Windows-Subsystem-for-Linux}]{\emph{3. Install Windows Subsystem for Linux}}}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{installation/windows10/1.1W-Virtual-Machine-Docker-Setup:Enable-WSL}]{\emph{3.1. Enable WSL}}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{installation/windows10/1.1W-Virtual-Machine-Docker-Setup:Upgrade-to-WSL2}]{\emph{3.2. Upgrade to WSL2}}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{installation/windows10/1.1W-Virtual-Machine-Docker-Setup:Install-Linux-Ubuntu-OS}]{\emph{3.3. Install Linux Ubuntu OS}}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{installation/windows10/1.1W-Virtual-Machine-Docker-Setup:Set-up-Ubuntu-in-WSL}]{\emph{3.4. Set up Ubuntu in WSL}}}

\end{itemize}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{installation/windows10/1.1W-Virtual-Machine-Docker-Setup:Install-Docker-for-Windows}]{\emph{4. Install Docker for Windows}}}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
It is also possible to use Virtualbox to create a virtual Ubuntu Linux machine. This approach may be used if it is desired to use Eclipse, etc. for Java development. However, performance of Virtualbox is significantly worse than WSL2 for running GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D simulations and python application development.


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\subsection{System Requirements}
\label{\detokenize{installation/windows10/1.1W-Virtual-Machine-Docker-Setup:System-Requirements}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{OS:}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Windows 10, Version 2004 or higher, with Build 19041 or higher

\end{itemize}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{RAM:}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
8GB (\sphinxstyleemphasis{absolute minimum} for 13 and 123 node models, \sphinxstyleemphasis{may encounter memory overload during installation} );

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
16GB (preferred for small models, minimum for 8500/9500 node models);

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
32GB (recommended for application development)

\end{itemize}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Disk Space:}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
15GB required for installation

\end{itemize}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Note:} The download size is quite large, so it is recommended to use a fiber or ethernet interent connection, rathered than a metered hotspot to avoid excessive data usage charges.


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\subsection{Windows 10 OS Build Requirments}
\label{\detokenize{installation/windows10/1.1W-Virtual-Machine-Docker-Setup:Windows-10-OS-Build-Requirments}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
To check your OS build, type \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{winver}} in the Cortana seach bar:

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=834\sphinxpxdimen,height=681\sphinxpxdimen]{{win_setup_run_winver}.png}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Check to see if your OS is
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
For x64 systems: \sphinxstylestrong{Version 1903 or higher, with Build 18362 or higher.}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
For ARM64 systems: \sphinxstylestrong{Version 2004 or higher, with Build 19041 or higher.}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=1085\sphinxpxdimen,height=496\sphinxpxdimen]{{win_setup_goodbad_winver}.png}

\sphinxAtStartPar
If not, run \sphinxstylestrong{Windows Update} to get the latest verion of Windows 10 available for your machine. It may take some time for the new OS to download. Multiple restarts are typical while upgrading the windows version.


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\subsection{Disconnect from Corporate VPN}
\label{\detokenize{installation/windows10/1.1W-Virtual-Machine-Docker-Setup:Disconnect-from-Corporate-VPN}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
There is a known issue with WSL2 and some corporate / laboratory VPNs. During WSL2 and docker installation, the Domain Name Server is set to that of your corporate intranet if your machine is connected to a VPN. This will cause issues when accessing github, etc. from within WSL2.

\sphinxAtStartPar
This issue has also been reported by users using Virtualbox VMs.


\subsection{Install Windows Subsystem for Linux}
\label{\detokenize{installation/windows10/1.1W-Virtual-Machine-Docker-Setup:Install-Windows-Subsystem-for-Linux}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D and the associated docker containers will run using the Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL), which is a new feature to Windows 10 that enables linux code to run natively in Windows without a separate virtual machine. The steps in this section are also available on the \sphinxhref{https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/wsl/install-win10}{Microsoft website}


\subsubsection{Enable WSL}
\label{\detokenize{installation/windows10/1.1W-Virtual-Machine-Docker-Setup:Enable-WSL}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Open Windows PowerShell as an administrator:

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=840\sphinxpxdimen,height=685\sphinxpxdimen]{{win_setup_open_powershell}.png}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Enable WSL by entering

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{dism.exe /online /enable\sphinxhyphen{}feature /featurename:Microsoft\sphinxhyphen{}Windows\sphinxhyphen{}Subsystem\sphinxhyphen{}Linux /all /norestart}}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=859\sphinxpxdimen,height=134\sphinxpxdimen]{{win_setup_enable_wsl2}.png}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Then, without restarting, enable the virtual machine platform by entering

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{dism.exe /online /enable\sphinxhyphen{}feature /featurename:VirtualMachinePlatform /all /norestart}}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=859\sphinxpxdimen,height=265\sphinxpxdimen]{{win_setup_enable_VM}.png}

\sphinxAtStartPar
When completed, restart your machine. It may take a few minutes for the new settings to be applied while restarting.


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\subsubsection{Upgrade to WSL2}
\label{\detokenize{installation/windows10/1.1W-Virtual-Machine-Docker-Setup:Upgrade-to-WSL2}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Download the latest WSL2 package .msi installer from the \sphinxhref{https://wslstorestorage.blob.core.windows.net/wslblob/wsl\_update\_x64.msi}{Microsoft repository}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Run the update package to install WSL2 using the wizard:

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=495\sphinxpxdimen,height=387\sphinxpxdimen]{{win_setup_WSL_wizard}.png}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Open Windows PowerShell again and update the settings to use WSL2 by entering

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{wsl \sphinxhyphen{}\sphinxhyphen{}set\sphinxhyphen{}default\sphinxhyphen{}version 2}}


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\subsubsection{Install Linux Ubuntu OS}
\label{\detokenize{installation/windows10/1.1W-Virtual-Machine-Docker-Setup:Install-Linux-Ubuntu-OS}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Open the Microsoft Store app, and search for \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Ubuntu}} and install the desired version (available versions are 16.04, 18.04, and 20.04)

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=1202\sphinxpxdimen,height=934\sphinxpxdimen]{{win_setup_ubuntu_store}.png}

\sphinxAtStartPar
When it has finished downloading, click \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Launch}}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=1202\sphinxpxdimen,height=439\sphinxpxdimen]{{win_setup_ubuntu_launch}.png}


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\subsubsection{Set up Ubuntu in WSL}
\label{\detokenize{installation/windows10/1.1W-Virtual-Machine-Docker-Setup:Set-up-Ubuntu-in-WSL}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Wait for the Ubuntu OS to install.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=979\sphinxpxdimen,height=89\sphinxpxdimen]{{win_setup_ubuntu_setup}.png}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Select a username and password. These do not need to be the same as your Windows or Microsoft Account login.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=979\sphinxpxdimen,height=161\sphinxpxdimen]{{win_setup_ubuntu_username2}.png}


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\subsection{Install Docker for Windows}
\label{\detokenize{installation/windows10/1.1W-Virtual-Machine-Docker-Setup:Install-Docker-for-Windows}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Download and run \sphinxstylestrong{Docker Desktop for Windows} from \sphinxhref{https://desktop.docker.com/win/stable/Docker\%20Desktop\%20Installer.exe}{Docker Hub}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Be sure to select “\sphinxstylestrong{Install required components for WSL2}”

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=706\sphinxpxdimen,height=489\sphinxpxdimen]{{win_setup_docker_wizard}.png}

\sphinxAtStartPar
After restarting your machine, Docker should start automatically, and you will see a notification stating “\sphinxstylestrong{Linux WSL2 containers are starting}”

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=966\sphinxpxdimen,height=182\sphinxpxdimen]{{win_setup_containers_starting}.png}


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\section{Installing GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D}
\label{\detokenize{installation/windows10/1.2W-Installing-GridAPPS-D:Installing-GridAPPS-D}}\label{\detokenize{installation/windows10/1.2W-Installing-GridAPPS-D::doc}}

\subsection{Clone the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Docker repository}
\label{\detokenize{installation/windows10/1.2W-Installing-GridAPPS-D:Clone-the-GridAPPS-D-Docker-repository}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Disconnect from your corporate/laboratory VPN (if applicable) and open the Ubuntu terminal:

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=836\sphinxpxdimen,height=686\sphinxpxdimen]{{win_setup_open_ubuntu}.png}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Clone the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D repository:

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{git clone https://github.com/GRIDAPPSD/gridappsd\sphinxhyphen{}docker}}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=979\sphinxpxdimen,height=113\sphinxpxdimen]{{win_setup_clone_gapps}.png}


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\subsection{Install the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Docker Containers}
\label{\detokenize{installation/windows10/1.2W-Installing-GridAPPS-D:Install-the-GridAPPS-D-Docker-Containers}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Change directories into the \sphinxstylestrong{gridappsd\sphinxhyphen{}docker} folder and start the latest stable release of the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D platform.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{cd gridappsd\sphinxhyphen{}docker}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{./run.sh}}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=1467\sphinxpxdimen,height=195\sphinxpxdimen]{{win_setup_run_sh1}.png}

\sphinxAtStartPar
It is possible to specify a particular release tag using the \sphinxhyphen{}t option and the release tag
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{./run.sh \sphinxhyphen{}t releases\_2020.09.0}} \sphinxhyphen{} use the September 2020 release

\subsection{Known Issues around Corporate VPN Connectivity}
\label{\detokenize{installation/windows10/1.2W-Installing-GridAPPS-D:Known-Issues-around-Corporate-VPN-Connectivity}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
There is a known issue around WSL2 and Virtualbox VM compatibility with corporate VPNs.

\sphinxAtStartPar
If your machine was connected to a corporate VPN during setup, the Doman Name Server (DNS) lookup address is set to that of your corporate intranet. To reset it, open an ubuntu session and edit the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{resolv.conf}} file
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{sudo nano /etc/resolv.conf}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
comment out existing nameserver address

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
add new line with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{nameserver 8.8.8.8}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
save file and restart terminal

\end{itemize}


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\bigskip\hrule\bigskip


\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=1201\sphinxpxdimen,height=150\sphinxpxdimen]{{GridAPPS-D_narrow}.png}

\chapter{Running GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D}

\section{Starting the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform}
\label{\detokenize{installation/1.4-Running-GridAPPS-D:Starting-the-GridAPPS-D-Platform}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
If you are accessing this section after completing the installation steps in the previous procedure, then the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform is already running.

\sphinxAtStartPar
When you start your machine next time, you will need to start the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform again. To do this, change directories into \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{gridappsd\sphinxhyphen{}docker}} and run the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{./run.sh}} script
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{./run.sh}} or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{./run.sh \sphinxhyphen{}t release\_tag}}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
A complete set of releases of the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform is available under {\hyperref[\detokenize{installation/1.8-Platform-Release-History::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc}{Platform Release History}}}}

\sphinxAtStartPar

\section{Stopping the Platform}
\label{\detokenize{installation/1.4-Running-GridAPPS-D:Stopping-the-Platform}}

\subsection{Stopping the Platform from Inside the Docker Container}
\label{\detokenize{installation/1.4-Running-GridAPPS-D:Stopping-the-Platform-from-Inside-the-Docker-Container}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
If you are currently inside the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{./run\sphinxhyphen{}gridappsd.sh}} script inside the docker container, use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Ctrl+C}} to stop the platform. Some error messages may be displayed as the platform services are stopped.

\sphinxAtStartPar
{\color{red}\bfseries{}|gapps\textbackslash{}\_cntrl\textbackslash{}\_c|}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Then exit the docker container using \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{exit}}. This will return to the main ubuntu bash command line:

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=979\sphinxpxdimen,height=170\sphinxpxdimen]{{gapps_exit}.png}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Then run the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{./stop.sh}} script to shut down all the docker containers and free RAM used by the Platform:

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=979\sphinxpxdimen,height=345\sphinxpxdimen]{{gapps_stop_sh_2}.png}


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\subsection{Stopping the Platform from a New Terminal}
\label{\detokenize{installation/1.4-Running-GridAPPS-D:Stopping-the-Platform-from-a-New-Terminal}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
If your terminal was reset or closed, you can stop the platform and shut down all docker containers by changing directories into \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{gridappsd\sphinxhyphen{}docker}} and running the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{./stop.sh}} script:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{cd gridappsd\sphinxhyphen{}docker}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{./stop.sh}}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
{\color{red}\bfseries{}|stop\sphinxhyphen{}sh|}


\section{Restarting the Platform}
\label{\detokenize{installation/1.4-Running-GridAPPS-D:Restarting-the-Platform}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
After the Platform has been stopped, it can be restarted by running the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{./run.sh}} script again from within the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{gridappsd\sphinxhyphen{}docker}} directory

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=979\sphinxpxdimen,height=242\sphinxpxdimen]{{win_setup_change_tags3}.png}

\section{Changing Release Tags}

\sphinxAtStartPar
To change the Platform to run on a different release, run the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{./stop.sh}} script using the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}c}} option to remove the current containers.

\sphinxincludegraphics[width=1348\sphinxpxdimen,height=196\sphinxpxdimen]{{win_setup_change_tags}.png}

Remove the gridappsd directory using \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{sudo rm \sphinxhyphen{}r gridappsd gridappsdmysql}}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=979\sphinxpxdimen,height=242\sphinxpxdimen]{{win_setup_change_tags3}.png}

\section{Pulling Updated Containers}
\label{\detokenize{installation/1.4-Running-GridAPPS-D:Pulling-Updated-Containers}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D platform should automatically check for and pull updated containers each time the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{./run.sh}} script is run.

However, it is sometimes necessary to force docker to pull new containers (e.g. if using a custom set of containers as specified by modifying the docker\sphinxhyphen{}compose.yml file).

\chapter{Using the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Viz}
\label{\detokenize{installation/1.5-Using-GridAPPS-D-Viz:Using-the-GridAPPS-D-Viz}}\label{\detokenize{installation/1.5-Using-GridAPPS-D-Viz::doc}}

\section{Accessing the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Viz}
\label{\detokenize{installation/1.5-Using-GridAPPS-D-Viz:Accessing-the-GridAPPS-D-Viz}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Start the Platform using the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{./run.sh}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{./run\sphinxhyphen{}gridappsd.sh}} scripts as explained in \sphinxhref{1.4--Lesson-1.4-Running-GridAPPS-D.ipynb}{Running GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D}. After the Platform is running, open your browser and navigate to \sphinxhref{http://localhost:8080}{localhost:8080} for desktop installations and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{your.server.ip.address:8080}} for cloud installations.

\sphinxAtStartPar
You should see a splash screen with login options for various user roles. The default username and password combinations are available in the \sphinxhref{https://github.com/GRIDAPPSD/GOSS-GridAPPS-D/blob/master/gov.pnnl.goss.gridappsd/conf/pnnl.goss.core.security.userfile.cfg}{pnnl.goss.core.security.userfile.cfg} configuration file.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=1911\sphinxpxdimen,height=891\sphinxpxdimen]{{01_login}.png}

\sphinxAtStartPar
If the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{./run\sphinxhyphen{}gridappsd.sh}} script inside the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D docker container has not been started or has been interrupted, you will see a server connection error when attempting to log in:

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=1898\sphinxpxdimen,height=889\sphinxpxdimen]{{02_login_error}.png}

\sphinxAtStartPar
After logging in, there are two menus in the top left and right corners. On the left is the main menu for using the VIZ features. On the right is the settings menu.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=2021\sphinxpxdimen,height=260\sphinxpxdimen]{{menus1}.png}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The settings menu contains options for changing the color theme from dark to light, the time zone used, and level of logging detail.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=1920\sphinxpxdimen,height=237\sphinxpxdimen]{{settings_menu}.png}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=1920\sphinxpxdimen,height=390\sphinxpxdimen]{{light_theme}.png}

\sphinxAtStartPar
On the left is the main menu, which has options for creating simulations, comparing simulations, exploring the databases, and passing API calls through the STOMP client. Each of these will be explained in detail below.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=1920\sphinxpxdimen,height=482\sphinxpxdimen]{{main_menu}.png}


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\section{Creating a Simulation}
\label{\detokenize{installation/1.5-Using-GridAPPS-D-Viz:Creating-a-Simulation}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
To create a simulation from the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D VIZ, select \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Configure New Simulation}} from the main menu:

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=1912\sphinxpxdimen,height=505\sphinxpxdimen]{{config_sim_1}.png}


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\subsection{Power System Configuration}
\label{\detokenize{installation/1.5-Using-GridAPPS-D-Viz:Power-System-Configuration}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The first tab provides a set of menu options to select the desired distribution feeder on which the simulation will run. Detailed descriptions of the available test feeders inlcuded by default are provided in \sphinxhref{../api\_usage/3.3--Lesson-3.3--Using-the-PowerGrid-Models-API.ipynb\#7.-Available-Models-in-Default-Installation}{Available Models}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=1829\sphinxpxdimen,height=854\sphinxpxdimen]{{config_system_config}.png}


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\subsection{Simulation Configuration}
\label{\detokenize{installation/1.5-Using-GridAPPS-D-Viz:Simulation-Configuration}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The next tab provides several options for specifying
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
simulation start time (which determines weather and load data used)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
simulation duration in seconds

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
simulator used

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
real\sphinxhyphen{}time
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
If checked, 1 sec of clock time equals 1 sec of simulation time

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
If unchecked, the simulation runs as fast as possible (used for generating AI training data)

\end{itemize}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
simulation name

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
model configuration

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The model creation configuration textbox enables modification of the model from the default configuration, inlcuding opening/closing switches, changing DER setpoints, and changing the load profile. Details of the syntax for custom configurations is explained in \sphinxhref{../api\_usage/3.5--Lesson-3.5--Creating-Running-Simulation-API.ipynb\#simulation\_config}{simulation\_config settings}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=1910\sphinxpxdimen,height=903\sphinxpxdimen]{{config_sim_config}.png}


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\subsection{Application Configuration}
\label{\detokenize{installation/1.5-Using-GridAPPS-D-Viz:Application-Configuration}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The application configuration tab enables selection of which app should run during the simulation. The GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D VIZ allows for selection of just one app at a time. Two or more apps may be run simultaneously by starting the simulation through the Simulation API and specifying the desired apps using the \sphinxhref{../api\_usage/3.5--Lesson-3.5--Creating-Running-Simulation-API.ipynb\#application\_config}{application\_config key}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=2022\sphinxpxdimen,height=943\sphinxpxdimen]{{config_app_config}.png}


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\subsection{Test Manager Configuration}
\label{\detokenize{installation/1.5-Using-GridAPPS-D-Viz:Test-Manager-Configuration}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The Test Manager is used to create realistic operational events during the course of the simulation, including faults, communication outages, and custom event scripts.

\sphinxAtStartPar
For large models (such as the IEEE 8500 node and 9500 node test systems), it may take several seconds for the model dictionary to load. While the power system model is being queried, a splashscreen will be displayed.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=1920\sphinxpxdimen,height=1030\sphinxpxdimen]{{config_test_dict}.png}


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\subsubsection{Communication outages}
\label{\detokenize{installation/1.5-Using-GridAPPS-D-Viz:Communication-outages}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The first option is to create communication outages for both SCADA measurements and equipment control commands by clicking the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{CommOutage}} radio button.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Equipment control commands can be blocked by specifying an Input Outage with options for
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
start time

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
end time

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
all equipment (outages all commands for all equipment if checked)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
equipment type

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
equipment name

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
affected phases

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
CIM control attribute

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
To add an Input Outage, specify the desired options, click the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{+}} button, and then click the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Add event}} button at the bottom of the page. The speficied outages will then be displayed on the right side under the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{CommOutage}} tab.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=1528\sphinxpxdimen,height=1101\sphinxpxdimen]{{config_test_input_outage}.png}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Measurement sensor outages can be created with an Output Outage with options for
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
all measurements (all sensors outages if checked)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
equipment type

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
equipment name

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
affected phases

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
measurement type (voltage, apparent power, position)

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
To add an Output Outage, specify the desired options, click the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{+}} button, and then click the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Add event}} button at the bottom of the page. The speficied outages will then be displayed on the right side under the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{CommOutage}} tab.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=1523\sphinxpxdimen,height=1127\sphinxpxdimen]{{config_test_output_outage}.png}


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\subsubsection{Equipment Faults}
\label{\detokenize{installation/1.5-Using-GridAPPS-D-Viz:Equipment-Faults}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The next option is to create a fault on any class of equipment in the model by clicking the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Fault}} radio button. Options will appear to select the
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
equipment type

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
equipment name

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
phases to be faulted

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
type of fault

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
start time

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
end time

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
fault impedance

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
After setting the values, click the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Add event}} button. The fault will be displayed on the right side of the screen under the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Fault}} tab.

\sphinxAtStartPar
When the simulation reaches the event start time, the logical fault simulator traces the fault up to first upstream switch and opens that switch to clear the fault.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Note: The GridLAB\sphinxhyphen{}D logical fault simulator currently may not process faults in meshed networks correctly and fail to open the appropriate set of switches to clear the fault. This is a known bug with a workaround to open the appropriate switches using a custom Test Manager event file.}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=2020\sphinxpxdimen,height=1139\sphinxpxdimen]{{config_test_fault}.png}


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\subsubsection{Custom Event Files}
\label{\detokenize{installation/1.5-Using-GridAPPS-D-Viz:Custom-Event-Files}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Custom event messages can be written in format of a CIM Difference Message. The format of custom event files is explained in \sphinxhref{../api\_usage/3.5--Lesson-3.5--Creating-Running-Simulation-API.ipynb\#test\_config}{test\_config settings}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Event files can be uploaded by clicking the cloud\sphinxhyphen{}shaped button and selecting the desired files to be uploaded from your local machine. Click \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Open}} to upload each file. The custom event will then be displayed under the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Command}} tab.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=1903\sphinxpxdimen,height=889\sphinxpxdimen]{{config_test_upload}.png}

\subsection{2.5. Service Configuration}

The last tab is the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D service configuration. This enables selection of particular services that should be run along with the simulation, such as the Sensor Simulator or DNP3 service.

After selecting all desired simulation parameters, click \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Submit}} to start the simulation.

\section{Running a Simulation with VIZ}

\sphinxAtStartPar
After clicking \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Submit}}, the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D VIZ will generate a new oneline diagram for the desired feeder. Large models, such as the IEEE 8500 and 9500 node test systems, will take several seconds to load. A splashscreen will be displayed while the oneline diagram is being created.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Across the tab are three more tabs for events loaded into the simulation, applications configured to run, and SCADA alarms received during the simulation.

To start the simulation, click the start button shown above. A “Simulation is starting” message will be displayed while the CIM model is imported, converted, and configured to run with the specified simulation parameters.

After the simulation starts, a unique simulation ID will be created and displayed in the top left corner. This ID is used by applications to communicate with the correct simulation (as multiple simulations may be running simulateously).

\section{Configuring Remote GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D VIZ}
\label{\detokenize{installation/1.7-Cloud-Server-Configuration:Configuring-Remote-GridAPPS-D-VIZ}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
To access the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D VIZ from a local client, it is necessary to specify the IP address of the remote server in the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{viz.config}} file located in the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textasciitilde{}/gridappsd\sphinxhyphen{}docker/conf/}} directory.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The configuration file is formatted as a JSON string specifying the version of the VIZ used and the IP address and port to be used:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYGZob{}
    \PYGZdq{}version\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZdq{}remote:develop\PYGZdq{},
    \PYGZdq{}host\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZdq{}my.server.ip.address:61614\PYGZdq{}
\PYGZcb{}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\section{Version 2019.06.0}
\label{\detokenize{installation/1.8-Platform-Release-History:Version-2019.06.0}}\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Bugs Fixed
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Updated configuration, power grid model and simulation API for CIM100 and app evaluation features addition.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
All logs are being published to topic instead of queue.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Fixed TypError bug in gridappsd\sphinxhyphen{}sensor\sphinxhyphen{}service.

\end{itemize}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
New Features
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Communication outages: Platform supports input and/or output outage request with simulation for all or some selected power grid components. Outages are initiated and removed at the requested start and end time.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Fault injection: Platform can receive faults with simulation request and forwards them to co\sphinxhyphen{}simulator.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Viz UI updated: Input form added for communication outage and fault parameter selection. Input form moved from single page to separate tabs.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
CIM version update: Updated CIM version to CIM100. Added support for Recloser and Breaker in model parsing.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
New methods in Python wrapper: Capability added in gridappsd\sphinxhyphen{}python to start, stop and run a simulation directly from python using yaml or json.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Sample app container move to Python 3.6 as default. Updated gridappsd\sphinxhyphen{}sample\sphinxhyphen{}app to use updated container.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Debug scripts added: Added scripts in gridappsd\sphinxhyphen{}docker to run platform, co\sphinxhyphen{}simulator and simulator in separate terminals for debugging purposes.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Sensor service in available in gridappsd container by default. Sensor service is no longer required to be added in gridappsd container via docker\sphinxhyphen{}compose file.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Default log level is changed from DEBUG to ERROR for limiting the amount of log messages on terminal.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Breaking API change} \sphinxhyphen{} Simulation input and output topics changed in gridappsd\sphinxhyphen{}python from FNCS\_INPUT\_TOPIC to SIMULATION\_INPUT\_TOPIC and FNCS\_OUTPUT\_TOPIC to SIMULATION\_OUTPUT\_TOPIC.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Breaking API change} \sphinxhyphen{} Simulation request return a json with simulation id and list of events with their uuids instead of just simulation id.

\end{itemize}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Documentation
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Using GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D documentation section updated for new UI input form with communication outages and faults selection.

\chapter{GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Introduction}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.1-Intro-to-GridAPPS-D:GridAPPS-D-Introduction}}\label{\detokenize{overview/2.1-Intro-to-GridAPPS-D::doc}}

\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\section{What is GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D?}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.1-Intro-to-GridAPPS-D:What-is-GridAPPS-D?}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D™ is an open\sphinxhyphen{}source platform that accelerates development and deployment of portable applications for advanced distribution management and operations. It is built in a linux environment using Docker, which allows large software packages to be distributed as containers.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D™ project is sponsored by the U.S. DOE’s Office of Electricity, Advanced Grid Research. Its purpose is to reduce the time and cost to integrate advanced functionality into distribution operations, to create a more reliable and resilient grid.

\sphinxAtStartPar
GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D enables standardization of data models, programming interfaces, and the data exchange interfaces for:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
devices in the field

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
distributed apps in the systems

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
applications in the control room

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The platform provides
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
robust testing tools for applications

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
distribution system simulation capabilities

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
standardized research capability

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
reference architecture for the industry

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
application development kit

\end{itemize}


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\section{GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform Characteristics}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.1-Intro-to-GridAPPS-D:GridAPPS-D-Platform-Characteristics}}

\subsection{Vendor / Vendor Platform Independent}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.1-Intro-to-GridAPPS-D:Vendor-/-Vendor-Platform-Independent}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform and application development environment is independent of any specific vendor or vendor platform, in other words vendor neutral. The results of this effort are intended to be useful and available to any vendor or application developer who wishes to apply them or incorporate them into existing or future products.


\subsection{Standards\sphinxhyphen{}based Architecture}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.1-Intro-to-GridAPPS-D:Standards-based-Architecture}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D is the first platform for energy and distribution management systems that is designed with standards for data integration, including data models, programming interfaces, and data exchange interfaces between grid devices in the field, distributed applications in utility systems, and applications in utility control rooms. This means that the applications developed using GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D make them broadly applicable and interchangeable across utility systems, reducing the cost and time for
utilities to integrate new functionality.

\sphinxAtStartPar
To the greatest extent possible, the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform incorporates and supports industry standards, in particular interoperability standards, including the power system model representation using the Common Information Model (CIM) and communications with other platforms / physical equipment through DNP3, IEEE 2030.5, and the open field messaging bus (OpenFMB)


\subsection{Replicable}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.1-Intro-to-GridAPPS-D:Replicable}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
As a reference implementation of a standards\sphinxhyphen{}based architecture, advanced applications and services developed with GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform should be replicable, with the ability to be deployed at multiple locations on different distribution feeders with almost no code customization.


\subsection{Flexible Distribution Simulation}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.1-Intro-to-GridAPPS-D:Flexible-Distribution-Simulation}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform enables users to run real\sphinxhyphen{}time quasi\sphinxhyphen{}static simulations of large distribution network models with real\sphinxhyphen{}time load data, thermal co\sphinxhyphen{}simulation of houses, real\sphinxhyphen{}time weather data, and real\sphinxhyphen{}time operation of switches, DERs, and volt\sphinxhyphen{}var control equipment. The platform supports multiple distribution simulators through a co\sphinxhyphen{}simulation bridge that abstracts the simulation configuration details to a simple API.


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\section{Data Representation \& Management}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.1-Intro-to-GridAPPS-D:Data-Representation-_-Management}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
A key to GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D is providing the distribution system application developer with a standardized approach to data. The intent is to allow the developer to make logical references to data referencing standard data models and interfaces without concern for how the data is physically made available. This standardized, logical data interface is based on existing standards to the greatest extent possible.


\subsection{Standards\sphinxhyphen{}based Data Representation}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.1-Intro-to-GridAPPS-D:Standards-based-Data-Representation}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The Common Information Model (CIM) is used for all power system models, which enables rapid exchange of power system models across compliant applications and services. Using the set of standardized model queries provided by the PowerGrid Models API, a GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D application is able to scale seamlessly across different network models with no modifications to the application code.


\subsection{Standards\sphinxhyphen{}based Data Interfaces}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.1-Intro-to-GridAPPS-D:Standards-based-Data-Interfaces}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform and GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D APIs provide a standardized method for interfacing with power system model data, real\sphinxhyphen{}time simulation data, historical data, and log data. Each of these APIs abstract the database specifics, and enable simple queries through a set of standardized messages formatted as JSON strings.


\subsection{Data Translation to Non\sphinxhyphen{}standardized Elements}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.1-Intro-to-GridAPPS-D:Data-Translation-to-Non-standardized-Elements}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
CIM Hub and the Configuration File API allow conversion of the power system model data from the standards\sphinxhyphen{}based CIM XML format used by the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform to model formats used by other software packages, such as GridLAB\sphinxhyphen{}D and OpenDSS. This model conversion process can be performed with a simple set of standardized API calls.


\subsection{Available Distribution Feeders}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.1-Intro-to-GridAPPS-D:Available-Distribution-Feeders}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D platform comes pre\sphinxhyphen{}configured with a combination of IEEE Test Feeders, PNNL Taxanomoy feeders, and other realistic synthetic models. Additional models and actual utility feeder data can be uploaded easily as CIM XML files into the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform, which can then be used for application testing and real\sphinxhyphen{}time simulation.


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\section{Real\sphinxhyphen{}Time Distribution Simulation}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.1-Intro-to-GridAPPS-D:Real-Time-Distribution-Simulation}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform inlcudes a robust real\sphinxhyphen{}time distribution simulator with comparable capabilities to a Dispatcher Training Simulator. This environment enables application developers to test algorithms and application code on both the standard realistic sythetic feeders pre\sphinxhyphen{}configured in the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform download and any other power system models that the user can upload through the CIM Hub package.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The distribution simulator is the source of data to the distribution system application developer enabling them to evaluate the performance of their application with ideal or realistic noisy data under different operating and performance conditions.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D platform currently supports only quasi\sphinxhyphen{}static simulation (i.e. simulation of electromechanical / electromagnetic transients, variable microgrid island frequency, synchro\sphinxhyphen{}check relays, etc. are not supported currently). These types of simulations can be performed with GridLAB\sphinxhyphen{}D outside of the the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform and application development environment.


\subsection{Real\sphinxhyphen{}Time \& Faster\sphinxhyphen{}than\sphinxhyphen{}Real\sphinxhyphen{}Time Simulation}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.1-Intro-to-GridAPPS-D:Real-Time-_-Faster-than-Real-Time-Simulation}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Simulations can be run in two modes:
\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{)}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Real\sphinxhyphen{}time mode: one second of computer clock time corresponds to one second of simulation time. The GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform runs the simulation in each time and publishes simulation data and sensor measurements every three seconds.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Faster\sphinxhyphen{}than\sphinxhyphen{}real\sphinxhyphen{}time mode: The GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D runs the simulation as fast as possible and does not wait for three seconds of computer clock time to pass before it publishes the simulation data from the current time step. This mode is very useful for creating historical training data sets for AI/ML applications.

\end{enumerate}


\subsection{Controllable Power System Equipment}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.1-Intro-to-GridAPPS-D:Controllable-Power-System-Equipment}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
All of the power system equipment can be controlled in real\sphinxhyphen{}time through the Simulation API, allowing applications to open/close switches, dispatch DGs / DERs, adjust setpoints of rooftop PV, adjust regulator taps, and turn capacitor banks on or off.


\subsection{Noisy / Bad Data Injection \& Communication Failures}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.1-Intro-to-GridAPPS-D:Noisy-/-Bad-Data-Injection-_-Communication-Failures}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform supports the Sensor Simulator Service, which is able to inject noise, bad measurements, and data packet losses into the simulation output. The frequency at which sensors publish can also be adjusted and aggregated, allowing realistic representation of real sensors, such as AMI meters that publish data every 15 minutes, rather than at each simulation time step. This allows the user to train and evaluate applications with realistic measurement for meters and sensors, rather
than “pure” data created by the power flow solver.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform also supports simulation of communication failures through the Test Manager during which data is not received from sensors, control commands are delivered to selected equipment, or both. This enables application developers to test algorithm performance under realistic conditions, during which physical equipment might not respond to control commands.


\subsection{Reconfigurable Power System Topologies}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.1-Intro-to-GridAPPS-D:Reconfigurable-Power-System-Topologies}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform supports simulation of both meshed and radial power system topologies, as well as reconfiguration of the power system network in real\sphinxhyphen{}time by opening / closing / tripping of various switching devices, such as breakers, reclosers, sectionalizers, and fuses. These switches can be controlled by an application through the Simulation API or through the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Viz GUI


\subsection{Real\sphinxhyphen{}Time Simulation Visualization}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.1-Intro-to-GridAPPS-D:Real-Time-Simulation-Visualization}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform includes the Viz GUI application, which presents a simple graphic user interfaces with some of the basic functionalities found in an Dispatcher Training Simulator, inlcuding a one\sphinxhyphen{}line diagram of the feeder, colorized switch positions, outage locations, alarm messages, and customizable stripcharts of power flow, node voltage, and tap position.


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\section{Using the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.1-Intro-to-GridAPPS-D:Using-the-GridAPPS-D-Platform}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D currently runs in a Linux virtual machine (VM). Although it can be built from sources, the primary form of distribution is as a set of Docker containers. Users can install the Docker infrastructure on their computer and then download the Docker containers. Several platform usage scenarios are then feasible:
\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Start and run the application through its browser interface. Utilities could use the platform this way to evaluate new applications, or to evaluate applications on their own circuits. The App Hosting Manager allows a user to install and configure new applications to run in the platform, by modifying configuration files but without having to write new code. GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D will also be able to ingest any distribution circuit provided in CIM format.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Write scripted scenarios and responses using the Test Manager, and run those through GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D. This mode can be used for a more rigorous evaluation, and also for operator training.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Write a new application, using one of the open\sphinxhyphen{}source examples as a template. This mode should provide a faster on\sphinxhyphen{}ramp for application developers to develop a standards\sphinxhyphen{}compliant product.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
DMS vendors can use the platform to develop and test their own standards\sphinxhyphen{}compliant interfaces. Any GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D code may be incorporated into a commercial product, pursuant to its BSD license terms. The goal is for an application to be deployable from one platform to another, simply by moving the program file(s) and updating local configuration files.

\end{enumerate}

\section{Integration with External Vendor Systems}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.2-GridAPPS-D-Architecture:Integration-with-External-Vendor-Systems}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
External vendor systems are able to interface with GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D compliant applications and services through two means.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The first is direct integration through the standards\sphinxhyphen{}based API and message bus. This enables products that comply with the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D™ platform to * reduce utility time and cost to integrate new functionality * give utilities more choice in technology providers * scale up or down for any size utility * expand market opportunities for developers and vendors

\sphinxAtStartPar
The second method is through the standards\sphinxhyphen{}based services, such as the DNP3 service, IEEE 2030.5 service, etc. that enable communication between GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D compliant applications and external vendor systems through SCADA and other control center protocols.


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\section{GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Applications}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.2-GridAPPS-D-Architecture:GridAPPS-D-Applications}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D platform and API enable rapid development of advanced power applications that are able to operate in a real\sphinxhyphen{}time environment and interface with external software and systems. Multiple power applications have already been developed on the platform, including
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Volt\sphinxhyphen{}Var Optimization (VVO)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Fault Location Isolation and Service Restoration (FLISR)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Distributed Energy Resource Dispatch and Management (DERMS)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Solar Forecasting, Load Forecasting, etc.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
and more

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Applications can be containerized in Docker for direct integration into the platform or interface through the API. Applications can be written in any programming language, but API libraries are currently available in only Python and Java.


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\section{GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Services}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.2-GridAPPS-D-Architecture:GridAPPS-D-Services}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D platform can host a multitude of services for processing both real\sphinxhyphen{}time simulation and control center data. These services can be called by any application through the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D API.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Some of the available services include

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Sensor Simulator}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Alarm Service}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{DNP3 Protocol Service}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{IEEE 2030.5 Protocol Service}

\end{itemize}


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\section{GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Application Programming Interface}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.2-GridAPPS-D-Architecture:GridAPPS-D-Application-Programming-Interface}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D offers a unique standards\sphinxhyphen{}based application programming interface (API) that will be the focus of the lessons in this set of tutorials. The API enables any application, service, or external vendor product to interface with each other, access control center data, run a real\sphinxhyphen{}time simulation, and issue equipment control commands.

\sphinxAtStartPar
GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D has several APIs to serve different needs and objectives, inlcuding * \sphinxstylestrong{Powergrid Models API} \textendash{} Allows apps and services to access the power system model data * \sphinxstylestrong{Configuration File API} \textendash{} Allows apps to set equipment statuses and system conditions * \sphinxstylestrong{Simulation API} \textendash{} Allows apps to start a real\sphinxhyphen{}time simulation and issue equipment commands * \sphinxstylestrong{Timeseries API} \textendash{} Allows apps to pull real\sphinxhyphen{}time and historical data * \sphinxstylestrong{Logging API} \textendash{} Allows apps to access logs and publish
log messages

\sphinxAtStartPar
Additional APIs are currently under development to enable communication and control of field devices, as well as cyber\sphinxhyphen{}physical network co\sphinxhyphen{}simulation.


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\section{GOSS Message Bus}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.2-GridAPPS-D-Architecture:GOSS-Message-Bus}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
One of the unique features of GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D is the GOSS Message Bus, which enables integration and communication between applications, services, and external software on a publish\sphinxhyphen{}subscribe basis.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D platform publishes SCADA and simulation data, alarms, and other real\sphinxhyphen{}time data. Applications subscribe to the types of messages relevant to their objectives and publish equipment commands and control settings.


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\section{GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Core Services}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.2-GridAPPS-D-Architecture:GridAPPS-D-Core-Services}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
“Under the hood” of the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D platform are the core services and managers.

\sphinxAtStartPar
An application developer should not need a detailed understanding of the core services, as all interaction is performed through the various APIs, which will be dicussed in detail in the upcoming tutorial lessons.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The core services provide the key functionality offered by the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D platform, inlcuding database access, processing API calls, handling equipment commands, and running simulations.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Some of the core services included in the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D platform are * \sphinxstylestrong{Platform Manager} \textendash{} Coordinates all of the other managers * \sphinxstylestrong{Process Manager} \textendash{} Coordinates platform component interactions * \sphinxstylestrong{Application Manager} \textendash{} Manages application registration, execution, and status reporting * \sphinxstylestrong{Configuration Manager} \textendash{} Manages the setup and configuration of real\sphinxhyphen{}time simulations * \sphinxstylestrong{Simulation Manager} \textendash{} Allows users and apps to create, start, stop, and pause co\sphinxhyphen{}simulations * \sphinxstylestrong{Data
Manager} \textendash{} Coordinates the integrated repository of model, timeseries data, and metadata * \sphinxstylestrong{Model Manager} \textendash{} Loads and checks CIM\sphinxhyphen{}based power system models * \sphinxstylestrong{Logging Manager} \textendash{} Supports logging for application development and execution * \sphinxstylestrong{Services Manager} \textendash{} Coordinates all services available for users and apps * \sphinxstylestrong{Test Manager} \textendash{} Enables creation of simulation events, faults, and network outages


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\section{Co\sphinxhyphen{}Simulation Framework}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.2-GridAPPS-D-Architecture:Co-Simulation-Framework}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The co\sphinxhyphen{}simulation framework serves as the simulation context for the rest of GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D. When a simulation is requested through the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D plaform the simulation manager instantiates a FNCS or HELICS co\sphinxhyphen{}simulation federation consisting of two applications. The first application is a powerflow simulator which can be either GridLAB\sphinxhyphen{}D or OpenDSS that simulates real world distribution feeder or feeders. The second is a custom application that serves as bridge between the FNCS/HELICS message bus
and the GOSS message bus. The data that travels between the co\sphinxhyphen{}simulation federation and the rest of the platform are SCADA measurement, SCADA control, and simulation status and control messages.The bridge application subscribes to the simulation input topic to recieve any SCADA control, simulation control, and simulation event messages. The bridge forwards SCADA control commands and simulation events like faults and outages to the powerflow simulator. The bridge publishes SCADA measurements
from the powerflow simulator on a simulation output topic that GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D applications and other parts of the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D platform subscribe to.


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\section{Database Structures}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.2-GridAPPS-D-Architecture:Database-Structures}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Default installation of GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D comes with following data stores:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{MySQL:} It is used to store log data from platform, applications and services. For details, please see Logging API, which is covered in detail in Lesson 2.7.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Blazegraph:} It is used to store power grid model data. The data contains equipments, properties and their initial measurement values. It is a triplestore that supports complex graph representation and class structure for CIM standard data model.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{InfluxDB:} InfluxDB is a time series data store and is used to store simulation output, simulation input, weather and load data. It also store output from services line sensor service and alarms service. For the purposes of the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D project, InfluxDB is managed by Proven. Proven is a database software suite supporting disclosure, collection, and management of modeling and simulation data.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
For the purpose of developing applications, the data stores used should be transparent to the application as long the data model and standardized API is used.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The next step is to establish a connection with the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D platform so that API calls can be passed and processed.

\sphinxAtStartPar
This can be done by 1) manually specifying the connection and port or 2) using the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D utils to automatically determine the port


\subsubsection{Option 1: Manually specify connection parameters}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.3-GridAPPS-D-Python-Library:Option-1:-Manually-specify-connection-parameters}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
By default, the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D API communicates with the platform on port 61613.

\subsection{Passing API calls with GridAPPSD\sphinxhyphen{}Python}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.3-GridAPPS-D-Python-Library:Passing-API-calls-with-GridAPPSD-Python}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
There are three generic API call routines:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleemphasis{send(self, topic, message)} \textendash{}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleemphasis{get\_response(self, topic, message)} \textendash{}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleemphasis{subscribe(self, topic, callback)} \textendash{}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
For this example, we will use a very short query to request the MRIDs of the models available in the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform. We will explain how to make various kinds of queries in the upcoming lessons on how to use each API.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The first step is to define the topic, which specifies the channel on which to communicate with the API. The concept of the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Topic will be introduced in the next lesson. The specific topic definitions and their purposes will be discussed in greater detail in the lessons on each GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D API.

{

\end{sphinxVerbatim}
}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Next, we need to create the message the will be passed. The message must be a valid Python Dictionary or JSON\sphinxhyphen{}formated string. The way a message is created, structured, formatted, and parsed is discussed in detail in

\sphinxAtStartPar
If it is a short query, we can write it as a single line.

\end{sphinxVerbatim}
}

\sphinxAtStartPar

\chapter{GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Application Structure}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.4-GridAPPS-D-Application-Structure:GridAPPS-D-Application-Structure}}\label{\detokenize{overview/2.4-GridAPPS-D-Application-Structure::doc}}

\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\section{Application Structure}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.4-GridAPPS-D-Application-Structure:Application-Structure}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The structure of a GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D application can be broken into nine sections:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Querying for the power system model

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Querying for measurement MRIDs

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Querying for weather data (if needed)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Configuring parallel simulations (if needed)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
App core algorithm \& measurement processing

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Subscribing to simulation output

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Publishing equipment commands

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Querying historical \& timeseries data

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Subscribing and publishing to logs

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Each of these task sections within an application are explained below with sample code that can interact with a simulation running on the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D platform.


\section{Connecting to GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.4-GridAPPS-D-Application-Structure:Connecting-to-GridAPPS-D-Platform}}
\sphinxAtStartPar

\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\section{Querying for the Power System Model}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.4-GridAPPS-D-Application-Structure:Querying-for-the-Power-System-Model}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The first portion of a GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D application is series of queries to the PowerGrid Models API to obtain information about the power system model.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Because GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D applications are designed to be portable across numerous power system models without any code modification, the application must query the Blazegraph database and create a set of local variables that contain the information needed by the app to run its internal code.

\sphinxAtStartPar
An application will query for the various pieces of power system equipment relevant to its objective (e.g. a VVO app will be interested in regulators and capacitors, while a FLISR app will be interested in switches and reclosers present in the model). The query will typically include requests for information about the names, location, mRIDS, and electrical parameters for the various pieces of equipment needed by the application..


\subsection{Model Query Information flow}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.4-GridAPPS-D-Application-Structure:Model-Query-Information-flow}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The figure below shows the information flow involved in making a query for the power system model.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The query is sent using \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{gapps.get\_response(topic, message)}} on a queue channel (explained in {\hyperref[\detokenize{api_usage/3.1-API-Communication-Channels::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc}{API Communication Channels}}}}) with a response expected back from the platform within the specified timeout period.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=1604\sphinxpxdimen,height=1134\sphinxpxdimen]{{01_query_model}.png}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Application passes query to GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform}

\sphinxAtStartPar
First, the application creates a query message for requesting information about the desired power system components in the format of a JSON string or equivalant Python dictionary object. The syntax of this message is explained in detail in {\hyperref[\detokenize{api_usage/3.3-Using-the-PowerGrid-Models-API::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc}{Using the PowerGrid Models API}}}}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The application then passes the query through the PowerGrid Models API to the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform, which publishes it to a queue channel on the GOSS Message Bus. If the app is authenticated and authorized to pass queries, the query message is delivered to the data managers, which obtain the desired information from the Blazegraph Database.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform responds to Application query}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The data managers then publish the response from the Blazegraph Database to the appropriate queue channel. The PowerGrid Models API then returns the desired information back to the application as a JSON message or equivalant Python dictionary object.


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip

\label{\detokenize{overview/2.4-GridAPPS-D-Application-Structure:Model-Query-Sample-App-Code}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Below is a sample query of how the application will use the PowerGrid Models API to query for the details associated for all the switches in the feeder.

    \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{requestType}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{QUERY\PYGZus{}OBJECT\PYGZus{}DICT}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}

\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}

        \PYG{n}{sw\PYGZus{}mrid} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{index}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{IdentifiedObject.mRID}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{]}

\PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{switch\PYGZus{}dict}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Print dictionary for first switch}

\section{Querying for Measurement mRIDs}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.4-GridAPPS-D-Application-Structure:Querying-for-Measurement-mRIDs}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The next portion of a GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D application is series of queries to the PowerGrid Models API to obtain information about the measurements associated with various pieces of equipment the application is interested in. Due to structure of the Common Information Model (introduced in {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/2.6-Common-Information-Model::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc}{Intro to Common Information Model}}}}), there exist a separate set of objects associated with the positive\sphinxhyphen{}neutral\sphinxhyphen{}voltage (PNV), volt\sphinxhyphen{}ampere (VA), and position
measurements (POS) for each line, transformer, switch, etc.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Because GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D applications are designed to be portable across numerous power system models without any code modification, the application must query the Blazegraph Database and create a set of local variables that contain the unique mRIDS of each measurement needed by the app to run its internal code. In a subsequent step, the app will use these measurement mRIDs to subscribe to the live streaming data issued by the simulation.


\subsection{Measurement Query Information Flow}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.4-GridAPPS-D-Application-Structure:Measurement-Query-Information-Flow}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The figure below shows the information flow involved in making a query for the power system model.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The query is sent using \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{gapps.get\_response(topic, message)}} on a queue channel (explained in {\hyperref[\detokenize{api_usage/3.1-API-Communication-Channels::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc}{API Communication Channels}}}}) with a response expected back from the platform within the specified timeout period.

\sphinxAtStartPar

The figure below shows the information flow involved in making a query for the power system model.

\sphinxstylestrong{Application passes query to GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform}

\sphinxAtStartPar
First, the application creates a query message for requesting information about the desired power system components in the format of a JSON string or equivalant Python dictionary object. The syntax of this message is explained in detail in {\hyperref[\detokenize{api_usage/3.3-Using-the-PowerGrid-Models-API::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc}{Using PowerGrid Models API}}}}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The application then passes the query through the PowerGrid Models API to the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform, which publishes it to a queue channel on the GOSS Message Bus. If the app is authenticated and authorized to pass queries, the query message is delivered to the data managers, which obtain the desired information from the Blazegraph Database.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform responds to Application query}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The data managers then publish the response from the Blazegraph Database to the appropriate queue channel. The PowerGrid Models API then returns the desired information back to the application as a JSON message or equivalant Python dictionary object.

\section{Querying for Weather Data}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.4-GridAPPS-D-Application-Structure:Querying-for-Weather-Data}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The next portion of a GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D application is series of queries to the Timeseries API to obtain information about the weather data for the current time, including irradiation, temperature, etc. This information can be used for solar forecasting, load forecasting, etc.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Because GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D applications are designed to be portable across numerous power system models without any code modification, the application must query the Timeseries Influx Database and create a set of local variables that contain the weather data needed by the app to run its internal code.


\subsection{Weather Query Information Flow}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.4-GridAPPS-D-Application-Structure:Weather-Query-Information-Flow}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The figure below shows the information flow involved in making a query for the power system model.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The query is sent using \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{gapps.get\_response(topic, message)}} on the Timeseries queue channel (explained in {\hyperref[\detokenize{api_usage/3.1-API-Communication-Channels::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc}{API Communication Channels}}}}) with a response expected back from the platform within the specified timeout period.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=1600\sphinxpxdimen,height=1137\sphinxpxdimen]{{03_query_weather}.png}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Application passes query to GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform}

\sphinxAtStartPar
First, the application creates a query message for requesting information about the desired power system components in the format of a JSON string or equivalant Python dictionary object. The syntax of this message is explained in detail in {\hyperref[\detokenize{api_usage/3.7-Using-the-Timeseries-API::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc}{Using the Timeseries API}}}}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The application then passes the query through the Timeseries API to the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform, which publishes it to a queue channel on the GOSS Message Bus. If the app is authenticated and authorized to pass queries, the query message is delivered to the Data Managers, which obtain the desired information from the Timeseries Influx Database.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform responds to Application query}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The Data Managers then publish the response from the Timeseries Influx Database to the appropriate queue channel. The Timeseries API then returns the desired information back to the application as a JSON message or equivalant Python dictionary object.


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip

\section{Configuring a Parallel Simulation}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.4-GridAPPS-D-Application-Structure:Configuring-a-Parallel-Simulation}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Some applications may choose to run parallel simulations (similar to a digital twin), either within the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D platform or by exporting the model to OpenDSS, GridLAB\sphinxhyphen{}D, etc. This is accomplished through one or more queries to the Configuration File API to create a simulation configuration file and/or exported power system model.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The simulation configuration file contains all the necessary info to create a new simulation, including the power system model, date/time, and variations from the default basecase (i.e. re\sphinxhyphen{}dispatched DERs and switches that have been opened/closed).

\sphinxAtStartPar
The exported power system model is the entire model as a set of GLM or DSS that can be saved to an external file and then solved with a different power flow solver outside of the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform.


\subsection{Configuration Query Information Flow}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.4-GridAPPS-D-Application-Structure:Configuration-Query-Information-Flow}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The figure below shows the information flow involved in making a query for the power system model.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The query is sent using \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{gapps.get\_response(topic, message)}} on the Configuration File queue channel (explained in {\hyperref[\detokenize{api_usage/3.1-API-Communication-Channels::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc}{API Communication Channels}}}}) with a response expected back from the platform within the specified timeout period.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=1601\sphinxpxdimen,height=1137\sphinxpxdimen]{{04_config_sim_export1}.png}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Application passes query to GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform}

\sphinxAtStartPar
First, the application creates a query message for requesting information about the desired power system configuration in the format of a JSON string or equivalant Python dictionary object. The syntax of this message is explained in detail in {\hyperref[\detokenize{api_usage/3.4-Using-the-Configuration-File-API::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc}{Using the Configuration File API}}}}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The application then passes the query through the Configuration File API to the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform, which publishes it to a queue channel on the GOSS Message Bus. If the app is authenticated and authorized to pass queries, the query message is delivered to the Configuration Manager.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform responds to Application query}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The Configuration Manager obtains the CIM XML file for the desired power system model and then converts it to the desired output format with all of the requested changes to the model. The Configuration File API then returns the desired information back to the application as a JSON message (for Y\sphinxhyphen{}Bus or partial models) or export the files to the directory specified in the

\section{Processing Measurements \& App Core Algorithm}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.4-GridAPPS-D-Application-Structure:Processing-Measurements-_-App-Core-Algorithm}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The next portion of a GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D application is the measurement processing and core algorithm section. This section is built as either a class or function definition with prescribed arguments. Each has its advantages and disadvantages:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The function\sphinxhyphen{}based approach is simpler and easier to implement. However, any parameters obtained from other APIs or methods to be used inside the function currently need to be defined as global variables.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The class\sphinxhyphen{}based approach is more complex, but also more powerful. It provides greater flexibility in creating additional methods, arguments, etc.

\end{itemize}


\subsection{App Core Information Flow}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.4-GridAPPS-D-Application-Structure:App-Core-Information-Flow}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This portion of the application does not communicate directly with the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D platform.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Instead, the next part of the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D application ({\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/2.4-GridAPPS-D-Application-Structure:7.-Subscribing-to-Simulation-Output}]{\emph{Subscribing to Simulation Output}}}) delivers the simulated SCADA measurement data to the core algorithm function / class definition. The core algorithm processes the data to extract the desired measurements and run its optimization / control agorithm.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=1602\sphinxpxdimen,height=1134\sphinxpxdimen]{{05_app_core_algorithm}.png}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{No message from core algorithm to GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The core algorithm does not send any API messages to the platform

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{No response to core algorithm from GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The core algorithm receives its measurement data and other imputs from the subscription object defined next, rather than directly from the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D platform.
