\section{Subscribing to Simulation Output}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.4-GridAPPS-D-Application-Structure:Subscribing-to-Simulation-Output}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The next portion of a GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D application is series of queries to the Timeseries API to obtain information about the weather data for the current time, including irradiation, temperature, etc. This information can be used for solar forecasting, load forecasting, etc.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Because GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D applications are designed to be portable across numerous power system models without any code modification, the application must query the Timeseries Influx Database and create a set of local variables that contain the weather data needed by the app to run its internal code.


\subsection{Simulation Subscription Information Flow}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.4-GridAPPS-D-Application-Structure:Simulation-Subscription-Information-Flow}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The figure below shows the information flow involved in subscribing to the simulation output.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The subscription request is sent using \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{gapps.subscribe(topic, class/function object)}} on the specific Simulation topic channel (explained in {\hyperref[\detokenize{api_usage/3.1-API-Communication-Channels::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc}{API Communication Channels}}}}). No immediate response is expected back from the platform. However, after the next simulation timestep, the Platform will continue to deliver a complete set of measurements back to the application for each timestep until the end of the simulation.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=1601\sphinxpxdimen,height=1134\sphinxpxdimen]{{06_subscribe_to_sim}.png}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Application passes subscription request to GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The subscription request is perfromed by passing the app core algorithm function / class definition to the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{gapps.subscribe}} method. The application then passes the subscription request through the Simulation API to the topic channel for the particular simulation on the GOSS Message Bus. If the application is authorized to access simulation output, the subscription request is delivered to the Simulation Manager.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform delivers published simulation output to Application}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Unlike the previous queries made to the various databases, the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform does not provide any immediate response back to the application. Instead, the Simulation Manager will start delivering measurement data back to the application through the Simulation API at each subsequent timestep until the simulation ends or the application unsubscribes. The measurement data is then passed to the core algorithm class / function, where it is processed and used to run the app’s optimization /
control algorithms.


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip

\section{8. Publishing Equipment Commands}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.4-GridAPPS-D-Application-Structure:8.-Publishing-Equipment-Commands}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The next portion of a GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D App is publsihing equipment control commands based on the optimization results or objectives of the app algorithm.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Depending on the preference of the developer, this portion can be a separate function definition, or included as part of the main class definition as part of the {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/2.4-GridAPPS-D-Application-Structure:6.-Processing-Measurements-_-App-Core-Algorithm}]{\emph{Measurement Processing / App Core}}} class definition described earlier.


\subsection{Equipment Command Information Flow}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.4-GridAPPS-D-Application-Structure:Equipment-Command-Information-Flow}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The figure below outlines information flow involved in publishing equipment commands to the simulation input.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Unlike the various queries to the databases in the app sections earlier, equipment control commands are passed to the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D API using the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{gapps.send(topic, message)}} method. No response is expected from the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D platform.

\sphinxAtStartPar
If the application desires to verify that the equipment control command was received and implemented, it needs to do so by 1) checking for changes in the associated measurements at the next timestep and/or 2) querying the Timeseries Database for historical simulation data associated with the equipment control command.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=1602\sphinxpxdimen,height=1135\sphinxpxdimen]{{07_publish_commands}.png}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Application sends difference message to GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform}

\sphinxAtStartPar
First, the application creates a difference message containing the current and desired future control point / state of the particular piece of power system equipment to be controlled. The difference message is a JSON string or equivalant Python dictionary object. The syntax of a difference message is explained in detail in {\hyperref[\detokenize{api_usage/3.6-Controlling-Simulation-API::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc}{Publishing Equipment Commands}}}}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The application then passes the query through the Simulation API to the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform, which publishes it on the topic channel for the particular simulation on the GOSS Message Bus. If the app is authenticated and authorized to control equipment, the difference message is delivered to the Simulation Manager. The Simulation Manager then passes the command to the simulation through the Co\sphinxhyphen{}Simulation Bridge (either FNCS or HELICS).

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{No response from GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform back to Application}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform does not provide any response back to the application after processing the difference message and implementing the new equipment control setpoint.

\section{Querying Historical \& Timeseries Data}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.4-GridAPPS-D-Application-Structure:Querying-Historical-_-Timeseries-Data}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The next portion of a GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D application is querying historical data from the current and/or previous simulations.

\sphinxAtStartPar
All simulation output and commands from the current and previous simulations are stored in the Timeseries Database, and can be queried to provide AI/ML training data, verify processing of equipment commands, or

\sphinxAtStartPar
Note that Timeseries Database data is cleared when the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform is shut down with the ./stop.sh script. It is recommended to copy historical / training data to an external persistent directory using the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{docker cp}} command, as given in {\hyperref[\detokenize{installation/1.6-Docker-Shortcuts::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc}{Docker Shortcuts}}}}.


\subsection{Historical Data Query Information Flow}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.4-GridAPPS-D-Application-Structure:Historical-Data-Query-Information-Flow}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The figure below outlines the information flow involved in querying for historical and timeseries data.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The query is sent using the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{gapps.get\_response(topic, message)}} method on the Timeseries queue channel with a response expected back from the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D platform within the specified timeout period.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=1603\sphinxpxdimen,height=1136\sphinxpxdimen]{{08_query_timeseries}.png}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Application passes query to GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform}

\sphinxAtStartPar
First, the application creates a query message for requesting information about the desired power system components in the format of a JSON string or equivalant Python dictionary object. The syntax of this message is explained in detail in {\hyperref[\detokenize{api_usage/3.7-Using-the-Timeseries-API::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc}{Querying Timeseries Data}}}}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The application then passes the query through the Timeseries API to the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform, which publishes it to a queue channel on the GOSS Message Bus. If the app is authenticated and authorized to pass queries, the query message is delivered to the Data Managers, which obtain the desired information from the Timeseries Influx Database.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform responds to Application query}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The Data Managers then publish the response from the Timeseries Influx Database to the appropriate queue channel. The Timeseries API then returns the desired information back to the application as a JSON message or equivalant Python dictionary object.

\chapter{Introduction to the Common Information Model}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.6-Common-Information-Model:Introduction-to-the-Common-Information-Model}}\label{\detokenize{overview/2.6-Common-Information-Model::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This section introduces the CIM as a model format that is used for power system data and information exchange across applications, platforms, and services. The CIM is used for all power system models in GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D, and it is important to have an understanding of the concepts and implementation of CIM for describing power systems using unique mRIDs for each piece of equipment and associated modeling objects.


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\section{Introduction}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.6-Common-Information-Model:Introduction}}

\subsection{What is the Common Information Model?}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.6-Common-Information-Model:What-is-the-Common-Information-Model?}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The Common Information Model (CIM) is an abstract information model that can be used to model an electrical network and the various equipment used on the network.

\sphinxAtStartPar
CIM is widely used for data exchange of bulk transmission power systems, and is now beginning to find increasing use for distribution modeling and analysis.

\sphinxAtStartPar
By using a common model, utilities, vendors, and researches from both academia and industry can reduce the effort and cost of data integration, and instead focus on developing increased functionality for managing and optimizing the smart grid of the future.


\subsection{Why is Data Integration Important?}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.6-Common-Information-Model:Why-is-Data-Integration-Important?}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
In a typical distribution utility there are hundreds and even in some cases thousands of software solutions and applications that are managed by the IT department. These applications are used and operated independently by the various groups, departments, and organizations within the utility. Whenever a business process requires data from one system or application to be transferred to another system or application, the data needs to be manually extracted from the first database and then converted
to the format of the other application’s database.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Two strategies exist for dealing with extreme level of effort needed to manage, update, export, convert, and import data formats between different applications and databases.
\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{)}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Reduce the number of databases by purchasing a large software suite from a single vendor using a single proprietary data format that is internally\sphinxhyphen{}integrated and compatible with all the applications needed by utility

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Adopt a common data integration platform that allows external integration between multiple software packages using a shared data format

\end{enumerate}


\subsection{What does CIM Provide?}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.6-Common-Information-Model:What-does-CIM-Provide?}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
CIM is an information model, that is an abstract, formal representation of objects, their attributes, the relationships between them, and the operations that can be performed on them. It is NOT a database structure or physical data store. It is a technology\sphinxhyphen{}agnostic model for describing the properties of physical power system equipment, power flow data, and messages that can be exchanged between various platforms and applications.

\sphinxAtStartPar
To describe various power system objects, CIM uses \sphinxstylestrong{Class Diagrams} and \sphinxstylestrong{Sequence Diagrams} created using the Unified Modeling Language (UML). It also uses the Resource Description Framework (RDF) to describe classes and attributes in an eXtensible Markup Language (XML) file format. The details of what is covered in each part of the CIM is described in detail below.


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\section{Background and Structure of the CIM}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.6-Common-Information-Model:Background-and-Structure-of-the-CIM}}

\subsection{UML Class Diagrams}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.6-Common-Information-Model:UML-Class-Diagrams}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The Unified Modeling Language (UML) provides 13 types of diagrams to define software architecture. One of the is the \sphinxstylestrong{UML Class Diagram}, which visually represents object hierarchies and relationships.

\sphinxAtStartPar
First a review of basic concepts and terminology related to class diagrams:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
An \sphinxstylestrong{object} is any thing that we want to describe.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
A \sphinxstylestrong{class} represents a specific type of object.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
A \sphinxstylestrong{class hierarchy} is a model of the system showing every component as a separate class. The class hierarchy should represent the real\sphinxhyphen{}world structure of the system.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
A \sphinxstylestrong{package} is a group of classes. Think of folders in a computer file explorer.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Inheritance} allows us to define very general “parent classes” and very specific “child classes”.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Attributes} are the properties that describe what type of thing the class represents.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Associations} are the relationships between various objects and how they are connected to each other.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Class diagrams show all the attributes and associations of various classes in a particular package in a single picture. To read a class diagram, remember that
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Lines with an arrowhead indicate class inheritance. For example, in the figure below, \sphinxstyleemphasis{ACLineSegment} inherits from \sphinxstyleemphasis{Conductor}, \sphinxstyleemphasis{ConductingEquipment}, \sphinxstyleemphasis{Equipment} and then \sphinxstyleemphasis{PowerSystemResource}. \sphinxstyleemphasis{ACLineSegment} inherits all attributes and associations from its ancestors (e.g., length), in addition to its own attributes and ancestors.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Lines with a diamond indicate composition. For example, \sphinxstyleemphasis{Substations} make up a \sphinxstyleemphasis{SubGeographicalRegion}, which then make up a \sphinxstyleemphasis{GeographicRegion}.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Lines without a terminating symbol are associations. For example, \sphinxstyleemphasis{ACLineSegment} has (through inheritance) a \sphinxstyleemphasis{BaseVoltage}, \sphinxstyleemphasis{Location} and one or more \sphinxstyleemphasis{Terminals}.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Italicized names at the top of each class indicate the ancestor (aka superclass), in cases where the ancestor does not appear on the diagram. For example, \sphinxstyleemphasis{PowerSystemResource} inherits from \sphinxstyleemphasis{IdentifiedObject}.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=1686\sphinxpxdimen,height=1610\sphinxpxdimen]{{d8d7aa708d3f1dc94cd53984730b194a3f88cf1c}.png}

\sphinxAtStartPar
A complete set of UML Class Diagrams is provided in the Advanced CIM Modeling section. This section contains class diagrams for all the objects used in GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D and tables of properties to help you create and pass your own custom SPARQL queries to the Blazegraph Database.


\subsection{UML Sequence Diagrams}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.6-Common-Information-Model:UML-Sequence-Diagrams}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
UML sequence diagrams are used to model the flow of messages, events, and actions between the entities of a system. Time is represented vertically—showing the time sequence of interactions in the system. Displayed horizontally at the top of the diagram are the applications or entities in the system.

\sphinxAtStartPar
CIM uses UML diagrams to represent work flow, operations processes, and other utility use\sphinxhyphen{}cases. For the purposes of application development within GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D, a detailed understanding of UML sequence diagrams is not required.


\subsection{Resource Description Framework (RDF)}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.6-Common-Information-Model:Resource-Description-Framework-(RDF)}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The Resource Description Framework (RDF) is a method of defining information models that is specified by the World Wide Web Consortium (the W3C). Detailed documentation is available on the \sphinxhref{https://www.w3.org/TR/2004/REC-rdf-concepts-20040210/}{W3C website}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
RDF focuses on making statements about objects in a subject\sphinxhyphen{}predicate\sphinxhyphen{}object expression. Each expression is commonly called a “triple” in RDF terminology. The subject is defined by naming a resource, the object denotes traits or attributes associated with the subject, and the predicate expresses the relationship between the subject and the object.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The subject, or resource, in an RDF model is expressed as a Uniform Resource Identifier (URI). URIs are similar to the Uniform Resource Locators (URLs) used as web addresses but are more general because they are not limited to accessible data on the web. The predicate and object are also technically URIs and so also are just identifiers. The subject\sphinxhyphen{}predicate\sphinxhyphen{}object triplets takes the form of expressing syntactical constructs like “a substation has a name”.

\sphinxAtStartPar
RDF Schema (RDFS) files describe the classes, attributes, and relationships of an information model and typically use an .rdfs file format. RDF instance files describe object instances and typically use an .xml extension. RDF incremental files describe changes to a set of object instances as described by an instance file, and typically use an .xml extension.

\sphinxAtStartPar
CIM uses RDF instance files to define power system models with unique master resource identifier (\sphinxstylestrong{mRID}) issued by a model authority. The mRID is globally unique within an exchange context. Global uniqeness is easily achived by using a UUID for the mRID. It is strongly recommended to do this. For CIM XML data files in RDF syntax, the mRID is mapped to rdf:ID or rdf:about attributes that identify CIM object elements.


\subsubsection{Key Concepts \& Terminology from RDF}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.6-Common-Information-Model:Key-Concepts-_-Terminology-from-RDF}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{URI References} \textendash{} CIM and GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D use two URI references to identify properties and resources. These identify the RDF format and the CIM classes used.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textless{}http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22\sphinxhyphen{}rdf\sphinxhyphen{}syntax\sphinxhyphen{}ns\#\textgreater{}}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textless{}http://iec.ch/TC57/CIM100\#\textgreater{}}}

\end{itemize}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\_\_

\end{itemize}


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\section{Summary of CIM XML Classes}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.6-Common-Information-Model:Summary-of-CIM-XML-Classes}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This section provides a brief look at the classes of equipment modeled in CIM XML and used in GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Details of each package, the class diagram, and attributes of each class are provided in the relevant sections of the reference guide to this lesson.


\subsection{Names, Nodes, Terminals}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.6-Common-Information-Model:Names,-Nodes,-Terminals}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The \sphinxstyleemphasis{Core} package provides very high level information of the distribution feeder model


\subsubsection{IdentifiedObject}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.6-Common-Information-Model:IdentifiedObject}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The \sphinxstyleemphasis{Core} package contains a class called \sphinxstyleemphasis{IdentifiedObject}. This class is very abstract and only contains attributes used to reference the object either by a user or in software. The attributes of \sphinxstyleemphasis{IdentifiedObject} include \sphinxstylestrong{*mRID*}, which is the master resource identifier that should be a globally 3\sphinxhyphen{}18 unique identifier of objects; the \sphinxstyleemphasis{mRID} does not have to be human\sphinxhyphen{}readable. This identifier is generally intended to be used by software systems.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The attributes \sphinxstyleemphasis{name}, \sphinxstyleemphasis{description}, \sphinxstyleemphasis{aliasName}, and \sphinxstyleemphasis{pathName} are intended for providing identifiers that are human\sphinxhyphen{}readable. It is common for names of objects within a utility to not be unique due to historical naming conventions, the results of mergers and acquisitions, and the inability of other software systems to manage uniqueness. For these reasons, there are no constraints on these names requiring them to be unique.


\subsubsection{PowerSystemResource}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.6-Common-Information-Model:PowerSystemResource}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The \sphinxstyleemphasis{PowerSystemResource} class inherits from \sphinxstyleemphasis{IdentifiedObject} and provides another relatively abstract class used in the CIM. The \sphinxstyleemphasis{PowerSystemResource} class supports an association to a \sphinxstyleemphasis{Company} class. This relationship identifies the company that operates the resource.


\subsubsection{ConnectivityNode}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.6-Common-Information-Model:ConnectivityNode}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The \sphinxstyleemphasis{ConnectivityNode} class has a relationship to the \sphinxstyleemphasis{Terminal} class. Each \sphinxstyleemphasis{ConductingEquipment} object has \sphinxstyleemphasis{Terminals,} which are then connected to \sphinxstyleemphasis{ConnectivityNodes.} The terminals can be thought of as being closely related to the conducting equipment, and the connectivity nodes are the glue that defines what equipment is connected to what other equipment.

\sphinxAtStartPar
CIM also includes the \sphinxstyleemphasis{TopologicalNode} class, which is used to convert breaker\sphinxhyphen{}switch oriented power system models to bus\sphinxhyphen{}branch models. This object is not used in GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D, which does not feature transmission substation configurations (e.g. breaker\sphinxhyphen{}and\sphinxhyphen{}a\sphinxhyphen{}half, main\sphinxhyphen{}and\sphinxhyphen{}transfer\sphinxhyphen{}bus, ring\sphinxhyphen{}bus, etc.) that require topological processing of breaker and switch positions to determine network topology and line connectivity.


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\subsection{Power System Equipment}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.6-Common-Information-Model:Power-System-Equipment}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
CIM XML provides a number of classes for defining physical power system equipment, including lines, switches, transformers, regulators, capacitors, and reactors.


\subsubsection{\sphinxstyleemphasis{Equipment} and \sphinxstyleemphasis{ConductingEquipment}}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.6-Common-Information-Model:Equipment-and-ConductingEquipment}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The \sphinxstyleemphasis{ConductingEquipment} class inherits from an \sphinxstyleemphasis{Equipment} class which inherits from \sphinxstyleemphasis{PowerSystemResource}. This is the parent class for most of the physical equipment that are used to model the power system.


\subsubsection{\sphinxstyleemphasis{Conductor} and \sphinxstyleemphasis{ACLineSegment}}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.6-Common-Information-Model:Conductor-and-ACLineSegment}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Directly inheriting from \sphinxstyleemphasis{ConductingEquipment} is the \sphinxstyleemphasis{Conductor} class. This class specifies the length of the conductor.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Each segment of a distribution line is defined in a CIM model as an \sphinxstyleemphasis{ACLineSegment}. This class contains the electrical attributes commonly associated with a line needed for steady state analysis, including the positive\sphinxhyphen{}sequence and zero\sphinxhyphen{}sequence resistance, reactance, conductance, and susceptance.

\sphinxAtStartPar
More details are available in the {\color{red}\bfseries{}\textasciigrave{}LineModel class diagram \textless{}\textgreater{}\textasciigrave{}\_\_} and {\color{red}\bfseries{}\textasciigrave{}list of attributes \textless{}\textgreater{}\textasciigrave{}\_\_}


\subsubsection{\sphinxstyleemphasis{PowerTransformer, TransformerWindings,} and \sphinxstyleemphasis{TapChanger}}
\label{\detokenize{overview/2.6-Common-Information-Model:PowerTransformer,-TransformerWindings,-and-TapChanger}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
These three classes specify the portions of a step\sphinxhyphen{}down transformer and regulator.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The \sphinxstyleemphasis{PowerTransformer} class inherits from \sphinxstyleemphasis{Equipment} (not ConductingEquipment) and has associations to the TransformerWinding class.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The majority of the electrical characteristics associated with the transformer are actually associated with the \sphinxstyleemphasis{TransformerWinding} objects.

\sphinxAtStartPar
An association from the \sphinxstyleemphasis{TransformerWinding} class to the \sphinxstyleemphasis{TapChanger} class is used when the transformer has a tap changer. The \sphinxstyleemphasis{TapChanger} class has as attributes for things like the tap steps and nominal setting. The \sphinxstyleemphasis{TapChanger} class inherits from the \sphinxstyleemphasis{PowerSystemResource} class instead of the \sphinxstyleemphasis{Equipment} class, so it has few inherited attributes and associations.

\chapter{API Communication Channels}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.1-API-Communication-Channels:API-Communication-Channels}}\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.1-API-Communication-Channels::doc}}

\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\section{1. What are Channels in GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D?}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.1-API-Communication-Channels:1.-What-are-Channels-in-GridAPPS-D?}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
When communicating with the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform through API, it is necessary to specify a communication channel, which tells the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D platform on which channel to communicate with the application and through which API the message should be directed.


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\section{2. \sphinxstyleliteralintitle{\sphinxupquote{/queue/}} vs \sphinxstyleliteralintitle{\sphinxupquote{/topic/}}}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.1-API-Communication-Channels:2.-/queue/-vs-/topic/}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D uses two types of communication channels to determine the visibility of the API call to other applications and services.


\section{2.1. Queue Channels}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.1-API-Communication-Channels:2.1.-Queue-Channels}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{/queue/}} is used for communication channels where only the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform is listening to the API call. These API calls are processed on a first\sphinxhyphen{}in, first\sphinxhyphen{}out basis. There is only one subscriber to the communication channel.

\sphinxAtStartPar
API calls to the Blazegraph database, Logs, Timeseries database, Config files, and Platform status are all queue channels. All the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Topics for queue channels typically do not change over the course of an application or simulation run.

\sphinxAtStartPar
In the GridAPPSD\sphinxhyphen{}Python library, it is assumed that a topic is a queue channel if not otherwise specified. These two GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Topic definitions are equivalent:

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{topic = \textquotesingle{}/queue/goss.gridappsd.process.request.data.powergridmodel\textquotesingle{}}}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{topic = \textquotesingle{}goss.gridappsd.process.request.data.powergridmodel\textquotesingle{}}}


\section{2.2. Topic Channels}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.1-API-Communication-Channels:2.2.-Topic-Channels}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{/topic/}} is used for communication channels where the API call is to broadcast to all subscribers through the GOSS Message Bus, inlcuding other applications, services, FNCS Bridge, etc.

\sphinxAtStartPar
API calls to the Simulation, services, and active applications use topic channels to communicate and typically need to the specify the Simulation ID, Service ID, and Application ID. The particular topic for such an API call will change between simulations and instances, and so shortcut functions are provided in GridAPPSD\sphinxhyphen{}Python library to assist in generating the correct Topic.

\sphinxAtStartPar
In GridAPPSD\sphinxhyphen{}Python, it is necessary to specify if a GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Topic is a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{/topic/}} channel broadcasting to all subscribers:

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{topic = "/topic/goss.gridappsd.simulation.input."+simulation\_id}}


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\section{3. Static GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Topics}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.1-API-Communication-Channels:3.-Static-GridAPPS-D-Topics}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Below are a list of the most common topics and where they are used. The appropriate topic for each API call will also be listed again in the subsequent sections on each GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D API. The list below can serve as an additional convenient reference.

\sphinxAtStartPar
These topics remain the remain the same between platform, application, and simulation instances. The GridAPPSD\sphinxhyphen{}Python Library shortcuts use all uppercase naming to indicate that these are static topic names.


\subsection{Importing the Topics Library}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.1-API-Communication-Channels:Importing-the-Topics-Library}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
When using topics in GridAPPSD\sphinxhyphen{}Python, it is recommended to import the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{topics}} library from \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{gridappsd}}. This enables you to rapidly call the correct topic without needing to search for the correct topic string. This also protects your code from any changes inside the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform if particular topic strings are deprecated or replaced \textendash{} the python library names will stay persistent between all Platform releases.

\sphinxAtStartPar
For static GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D topics, import the library by running

{
\sphinxsetup{VerbatimColor={named}{nbsphinx-code-bg}}
\sphinxsetup{VerbatimBorderColor={named}{nbsphinx-code-border}}
\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\llap{\color{nbsphinxin}[ ]:\,\hspace{\fboxrule}\hspace{\fboxsep}}\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{gridappsd} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{topics} \PYG{k}{as} \PYG{n}{t}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
}


\subsection{Request PowerGrid Model Data}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.1-API-Communication-Channels:Request-PowerGrid-Model-Data}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{/queue/}} channel is used to communicate with PowerGrid Models API to pull power system model info from the the Blazegraph Database. The PowerGrid Model API is covered in detail in {\hyperref[\detokenize{api_usage/3.3-Using-the-PowerGrid-Models-API::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc}{Using the PowerGrid Models API}}}}.

The base static string used is \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{goss.gridappsd.process.request.data.powergridmodel}}, which can be called using the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{.REQUEST\_POWERGRID\_DATA}} or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{.BLAZEGRAPH}} methods from the topics library

\subsection{Request Timeseries Data}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.1-API-Communication-Channels:Request-Timeseries-Data}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{/queue/}} channel is used to communicate with the Timeseries API and Timeseries database, which stores real\sphinxhyphen{}time and historical data, such as weather information and AMI meter readings. The Timeseries database is covered in detail in {\hyperref[\detokenize{api_usage/3.7-Using-the-Timeseries-API::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc}{Using the Timeseries API}}}}. A sample message that would be passed with this topic is

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Text String:} The topic can be specified as a static string:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{topic = "goss.gridappsd.process.request.data.timeseries"}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{gapps.get\_response(topic, message)}}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{GridAPPSD\sphinxhyphen{}Python Library Method:} The correct topic can also be imported from the GridAPPSD\sphinxhyphen{}Python topics library:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{from gridappsd import topics as t}}

\section{Dynamic GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Topics}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.1-API-Communication-Channels:Dynamic-GridAPPS-D-Topics}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Several GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D topics are unique to each application, simulation, or service instance. These topics are dynamic and will change from instance to instance.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform will require that the topic specify the particular instance so that the API call can be delivered to the correct simulation or service.

\sphinxAtStartPar
To assist with the task of creating a dynamic topic that automatically updates between instances, several function are available in the GridAPPSD\sphinxhyphen{}Python topics library.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The available GridAPPSD\sphinxhyphen{}Python functions for dynamic topics are
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{simulation\_input\_topic(simulaton\_id)}} \textendash{} Gets the topic to write data to for the simulation

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{simulation\_output\_topic(simulation\_id)}} \textendash{} Gets the topic for subscribing to output from the simulation

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{simulation\_log\_topic(simulation\_id)}} \textendash{} Topic for the subscribing to the logs from the simulation

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{service\_input\_topic(service\_id, simulation\_id)}} \textendash{} Utility method for getting the input topic for a specific service

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{service\_output\_topic(service\_id, simulation\_id)}} \textendash{} Utility method for getting the output topic for a specific service

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{application\_input\_topic(application\_id, simulation\_id)}} \textendash{} Utility method for getting the input topic for a specific application

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{application\_output\_topic(application\_id, simulation\_id)}} \textendash{} Utility method for getting the output topic for a specific application

\end{itemize}


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip

\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.1-API-Communication-Channels:Subscribe-to-Simulation-Output}}

\chapter{API Message Structure}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.2-API-Message-Structure:API-Message-Structure}}\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.2-API-Message-Structure::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This section introduces the format used for passing messages to the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D API and how to wrap those messages using the GridAPPSD\sphinxhyphen{}Python Library.


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\section{Python Dictionaries VS JSON Strings}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.2-API-Message-Structure:Python-Dictionaries-VS-JSON-Strings}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
One of the confusing aspects of passing messages to and from the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform and APIs is the difference between Python Dictionaries and JSON scripts, which look identical.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{JSON} is a \sphinxstyleemphasis{serialization format}. That is, JSON is a way of representing structured data in the form of a textual string.

\sphinxAtStartPar
A \sphinxstylestrong{Python Dictionary} is a \sphinxstyleemphasis{data structure}. That is, it is a way of storing data in memory that provides certain abilities to the code: in the case of dictionaries, those abilities include rapid lookup and enumeration.

\sphinxAtStartPar
It is possible to convert between the two by importing the JSON library: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{import json}}. Full documentation of JSON\sphinxhyphen{}Python interoperability and usage is available in \sphinxhref{https://docs.python.org/3/library/json.html}{Python Docs}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Use the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{json.dumps()}} method to serialize a dictionary as a JSON string. Use the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{json.loads()}} to import a JSON file and convert it into a dictionary. But the two are not the same: dictionaries are for working with data in your program, and JSON is for storing it or sending it around between programs.

\sphinxAtStartPar
With the GridAPPSD\sphinxhyphen{}Python Library, it is possible to pass query arguments as either a python dictionary or as a string. Both approaches will provide the same results.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{1) Format API call message as a dictionary}

\sphinxAtStartPar
This is the most direct approach, and will be used most often throughout this set of notebook tutorials. The format and structure of the python dictionary is explained in the next section.

\sphinxsetup{VerbatimColor={named}{nbsphinx-code-bg}}
\sphinxsetup{VerbatimBorderColor={named}{nbsphinx-code-border}}

\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\section{Structure of a GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Message}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.2-API-Message-Structure:Structure-of-a-GridAPPS-D-Message}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The structure of messages in GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D follows that of a Python Dictionary using a data structure that is more generally known as an associative array. An excellent tutorial on advanced usage of the python dictionary structure is available on \sphinxhref{https://realpython.com/python-dicts/}{Real Python}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
A dictionary consists of a collection of \sphinxstylestrong{key\sphinxhyphen{}value pairs}. Each key\sphinxhyphen{}value pair maps the \sphinxstylestrong{key} to its associated \sphinxstylestrong{value}.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
A dictionary is defined by enclosing a comma\sphinxhyphen{}separated list of key\sphinxhyphen{}value pairs in curly braces ( \sphinxstylestrong{\{ \}} ).

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
A colon ( \sphinxstylestrong{:} ) separates each key from its associated value.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Square brackets ( \sphinxstylestrong{{[} {]}} ) are used for a list of values associated to a particular key.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Additional curly braces ( \sphinxstylestrong{\{ \}} ) can be used for cases where multiple key\sphinxhyphen{}value pairs (e.g. equipment setpoints) are associated with a particular key (e.g. an equipment class).

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The general dictionary format used for GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D messages is

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
message = \PYGZob{}
    \PYGZdq{}key1\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZdq{}value1\PYGZdq{},
    \PYGZdq{}key2\PYGZdq{}: [\PYGZdq{}value21\PYGZdq{}, \PYGZdq{}value22\PYGZdq{}],
    \PYGZdq{}key3\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZob{}
        \PYGZdq{}key31\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZdq{}value31\PYGZdq{},
        \PYGZdq{}key32\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZdq{}value32\PYGZdq{}
        \PYGZcb{},
      .
      .
      .
    \PYGZdq{}key\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZdq{}value\PYGZdq{}
\PYGZcb{}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Important}: Be sure to pay attention to placement of commas ( \sphinxstylestrong{,} ) at the end of each line. Commas are placed at the end of each line \sphinxstyleemphasis{except} the last line. Incorrect comma placement will result in a syntax exception.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The particular set of key\sphinxhyphen{}value pairs for each GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D API is covered in detail in Lessons 2.1 through 2.7.


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\section{Parsing Returned Data}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.2-API-Message-Structure:Parsing-Returned-Data}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
After passing an API call, the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform returns a JSON string that is subsequently converted into a python dictionary by the GridAPPSD\sphinxhyphen{}Python Library. This section will outline how to parse the data returned.

\sphinxAtStartPar
For this example, we are going to use a simple query from the PowerGrid Model API (covered in Lesson 2.2.) to obtain the details of a piece of equipment using its unique mRID (introduced in the next lesson).

{
\sphinxsetup{VerbatimColor={named}{nbsphinx-code-bg}}
\sphinxsetup{VerbatimBorderColor={named}{nbsphinx-code-border}}
\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\llap{\color{nbsphinxin}[ ]:\,\hspace{\fboxrule}\hspace{\fboxsep}}\PYG{n}{model\PYGZus{}mrid} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZus{}49AD8E07\PYGZhy{}3BF9\PYGZhy{}A4E2\PYGZhy{}CB8F\PYGZhy{}C3722F837B62}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}} \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} IEEE 13 Node used for all example queries}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Specify correct topic}
\PYG{n}{topic} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{goss.gridappsd.process.request.data.powergridmodel}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}

\PYG{n}{message} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
        \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{modelId}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{model\PYGZus{}mrid}\PYG{p}{,}
        \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{requestType}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{QUERY\PYGZus{}OBJECT\PYGZus{}DICT}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
        \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{resultFormat}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{JSON}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
        \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{objectType}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{LinearShuntCompensator}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Pass API Call to GridAPPS\PYGZhy{}D Platform}
\PYG{n}{response} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{gapps}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{get\PYGZus{}response}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{topic}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{message}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{json}
\PYG{k}{with} \PYG{n+nb}{open}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{foo.txt}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{w}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{as} \PYG{n}{out}\PYG{p}{:}
    \PYG{n}{out}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{write}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{json}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{dumps}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{response}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{indent}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The structure of the python dictionary returned by the API is three key\sphinxhyphen{}value pairs for the keys of
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textquotesingle{}data\textquotesingle{}}} \textendash{} this is the data you requested

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textquotesingle{}responseComplete\textquotesingle{}}} \textendash{} true or false

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textquotesingle{}id\textquotesingle{}}} \textendash{} unique id associated with the API response dictionary

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
A typical API response will the structure below:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
response = \PYGZob{}
    \PYGZsq{}data\PYGZsq{}: [\PYGZob{}\PYGZsq{}key1\PYGZsq{}: \PYGZsq{}value1\PYGZsq{},
        \PYGZsq{}key2\PYGZsq{}: [\PYGZsq{}value21\PYGZsq{}, \PYGZsq{}value22\PYGZsq{}]\PYGZcb{},
        \PYGZob{}\PYGZsq{}key1\PYGZsq{}: \PYGZsq{}value1\PYGZsq{},
         \PYGZsq{}key2\PYGZsq{}: [\PYGZsq{}value21\PYGZsq{}, \PYGZsq{}value22\PYGZsq{}]\PYGZcb{}],
     \PYGZsq{}responseComplete\PYGZsq{}: True,
     \PYGZsq{}id\PYGZsq{}: \PYGZsq{}12345678\PYGZsq{}
\PYGZcb{}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The first step is to filter the dictionary to just the data requested: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{response{[}\textquotesingle{}data\textquotesingle{}{]}}}. The result will be a list object.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Note: \sphinxstyleemphasis{some} API calls will also need to additional filters of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{{[}results{]}{[}bindings{]}}}. The STOMP Client presented in the next section is very helpful for previewing the structure of the dictionary returned by GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D.

{
\sphinxsetup{VerbatimColor={named}{nbsphinx-code-bg}}
\sphinxsetup{VerbatimBorderColor={named}{nbsphinx-code-border}}
\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\llap{\color{nbsphinxin}[ ]:\,\hspace{\fboxrule}\hspace{\fboxsep}}\PYG{n}{response} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{gapps}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{get\PYGZus{}response}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{topic}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{message}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{response\PYGZus{}obj} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{response}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{data}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{]}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
}

\sphinxAtStartPar
As \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{response\_obj}} is of the python type \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{list}} rather than \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{dict}}, it is necessary to use numerical indices instead of keys to access the values. A simple \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{for}} loop is very helpful here.

\sphinxAtStartPar
In this example, we want to filter the results to create a list that contains just the name and mRID of the capacitor banks in the model.

{
\sphinxsetup{VerbatimColor={named}{nbsphinx-code-bg}}
\sphinxsetup{VerbatimBorderColor={named}{nbsphinx-code-border}}
\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\llap{\color{nbsphinxin}[ ]:\,\hspace{\fboxrule}\hspace{\fboxsep}}\PYG{n}{capacitors} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{p}{]}
\PYG{k}{for} \PYG{n}{index} \PYG{o+ow}{in} \PYG{n}{response\PYGZus{}obj}\PYG{p}{:}
    \PYG{n}{cap\PYGZus{}name} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{index}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{IdentifiedObject.name}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{]}
    \PYG{n}{cap\PYGZus{}mrid} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{index}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{id}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{]}
    \PYG{n}{message} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nb}{dict}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{name} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{cap\PYGZus{}name}\PYG{p}{,}
                   \PYG{n}{mrid} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{cap\PYGZus{}mrid}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{n}{capacitors}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{append}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{message}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
}

\sphinxAtStartPar

\section{Using the STOMP Client}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.2-API-Message-Structure:Using-the-STOMP-Client}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Visualization App includes a feature to pass API call messages through the GUI using the Simple Text Oriented Messaging Protocol (STOMP).

\sphinxAtStartPar
Open the Viz App, which is hosted on \sphinxhref{http://localhost:8080/}{localhost:8080} (note: cloud\sphinxhyphen{}hosted installations will use the IP address of the server).

\sphinxAtStartPar
Select \sphinxstylestrong{Stomp Client} from the main drop\sphinxhyphen{}down menu:

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=2021\sphinxpxdimen,height=260\sphinxpxdimen]{{menus}.png}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=1920\sphinxpxdimen,height=525\sphinxpxdimen]{{menu_select_stomp}.png}

\sphinxAtStartPar
This opens the STOMP Client, which can be used to pass a message to any of the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D APIs to preview results or debug the API call message.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=1918\sphinxpxdimen,height=898\sphinxpxdimen]{{STOMP_client}.png}


\subsection{Specifying the Topic}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.2-API-Message-Structure:Specifying-the-Topic}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The appropriate GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D topic needs to be copied and pasted into the \sphinxstylestrong{Destination Topic} box at the top of the window. The topic specifies on which channel the STOMP Client will communicate with the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform and to which API the message needs to be delivered.

\sphinxAtStartPar
A complete list of GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D topics was provided in \sphinxhref{../api\_usage/3.1--Lesson-3.1--API-Communication-Channels.ipynb}{API Communication Channels} and will also be provided in context for each of the API calls detailed in subsequent lessons.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{IMPORTANT:} Remember to remove the python wrapping quotations at the beginning and end of the topic. For example, if the python\sphinxhyphen{}wrapped topic was

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{topic = "goss.gridappsd.process.request.data.powergridmodel" \# Specify the topic}}

\sphinxAtStartPar
then the topic that is entered in the Stomp Client \sphinxstylestrong{Destination Topic} box is simply

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{goss.gridappsd.process.request.data.powergridmodel}}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{IMPORTANT:} The GridAPPSD\sphinxhyphen{}Python shortcut functions will not work in the STOMP Client. The full text string versions must be used.


\subsection{Entering the Request Message}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.2-API-Message-Structure:Entering-the-Request-Message}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The \sphinxstylestrong{Request} box accepts an API call message identical to those provided in these notebook lessons.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{IMPORTANT:} Remember to remove the python wrapping at the beginning and end of the message. For example, if the python\sphinxhyphen{}wrapped message was

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{message = "\{"requestType": "QUERY\_MODEL\_NAMES", "resultFormat": "JSON"\}" \# Sample PowerGrid Model API Call}}

\sphinxAtStartPar
then the message that is entered in the Stomp Client \sphinxstylestrong{Request} box is simply

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\{"requestType": "QUERY\_MODEL\_NAMES", "resultFormat": "JSON"\}}}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The STOMP client will automatically flag any errors in the JSON message.


\subsection{Submitting a Request}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.2-API-Message-Structure:Submitting-a-Request}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
After entering the topic and message, click \sphinxstylestrong{Send request} to send the API call to the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform. The response will be displayed in the box below.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=1917\sphinxpxdimen,height=897\sphinxpxdimen]{{STOMP_output}.png}

\sphinxAtStartPar
It can be seen that the response from the STOMP Client is identical to that obtained by passing the same topic and message using the GridAPPSD\sphinxhyphen{}Python Library:

{
\sphinxsetup{VerbatimColor={named}{nbsphinx-code-bg}}
\sphinxsetup{VerbatimBorderColor={named}{nbsphinx-code-border}}
\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\llap{\color{nbsphinxin}[ ]:\,\hspace{\fboxrule}\hspace{\fboxsep}}\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{gridappsd} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{GridAPPSD} \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Import Libraries}
\PYG{n}{gapps} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{GridAPPSD}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{localhost}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{, 61613)}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{username}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{system}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{password}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{manager}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Connect to Platform}
\PYG{n}{topic} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{goss.gridappsd.process.request.data.powergridmodel}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}} \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Specify correct Topic}
\PYG{n}{message} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{requestType}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{QUERY\PYGZus{}MODEL\PYGZus{}NAMES}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{resultFormat}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{JSON}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}} \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Sample PowerGrid Model API message}
\PYG{n}{gapps}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{get\PYGZus{}response}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{topic}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{message}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Pass API call to Platform}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
}

\chapter{Using the PowerGrid Models API}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.3-Using-the-PowerGrid-Models-API:Using-the-PowerGrid-Models-API}}\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.3-Using-the-PowerGrid-Models-API::doc}}

\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\section{Introduction to the PowerGrid Model API}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.3-Using-the-PowerGrid-Models-API:Introduction-to-the-PowerGrid-Model-API}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The PowerGrid Models API is used to pull model information from the Blazegraph Database, inlcuding the names, mRIDs, measurements, and nominal values of power system equipment in the feeder (such as lines, loads, switches, transformers, and DERs).

\sphinxAtStartPar
In the Application Components diagram (explained in detail with sample code in {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/2.4-GridAPPS-D-Application-Structure::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc}{GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Application Structure}}}}), the PowerGrid Models API is used for querying for the power system model and querying for model measurement MRIDs.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=1602\sphinxpxdimen,height=1136\sphinxpxdimen]{{power_grid_models_usage}.png}


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\section{API Syntax Overview}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.3-Using-the-PowerGrid-Models-API:API-Syntax-Overview}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Application passes query to GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform}

\sphinxAtStartPar
First, the application creates a query message for requesting information about the desired power system components in the format of a JSON string or equivalant Python dictionary object. The syntax of this message is explained in detail below.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The query is sent using \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{gapps.get\_response(topic, message)}} with a response expected back from the platform within the specified timeout period.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The application then passes the query through the PowerGrid Models API to the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform, which publishes it to the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{goss.gridappsd.process.request.data.powergridmodel}} queue channel on the GOSS Message Bus. If the app is authenticated and authorized to pass queries, the query message is delivered to the data managers, which obtain the desired information from the Blazegraph Database.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform responds to Application query}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The data managers then publish the response from the Blazegraph Database to the appropriate queue channel. The PowerGrid Models API then returns the desired information back to the application as a JSON message or equivalant Python dictionary object.


\subsection{API Communication Channel}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.3-Using-the-PowerGrid-Models-API:API-Communication-Channel}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
All queries passed to the PowerGrid Models API need to use the correct communication channel, which is obtained using the {\hyperref[\detokenize{api_usage/3.1-API-Communication-Channels::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc}{GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Topics library}}}}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The PowerGrid Model API uses a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{/queue/}} channel to pull power system model info from the the Blazegraph Database. The base static string used is \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{goss.gridappsd.process.request.data.powergridmodel}}, which can be called using the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{.REQUEST\_POWERGRID\_DATA}} or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{.BLAZEGRAPH}} methods from the topics library.

\sphinxAtStartPar
When developing in python, it is recommended to use the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{.REQUEST\_POWERGRID\_DATA}} method. When using the STOMP client in GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D VIZ, it is necessary to use the base static string.

{
\sphinxsetup{VerbatimColor={named}{nbsphinx-code-bg}}
\sphinxsetup{VerbatimBorderColor={named}{nbsphinx-code-border}}
\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]

\PYG{n}{topic} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{t}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{REQUEST\PYGZus{}POWERGRID\PYGZus{}DATA}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
}


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\subsection{Structure of a Query Message}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.3-Using-the-PowerGrid-Models-API:Structure-of-a-Query-Message}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Queries passed to PowerGrid Models API are formatted as python dictionaries or equivalent JSON scripts wrapped as a python string.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
message = \PYGZob{}
    \PYGZdq{}requestType\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZdq{}INSERT QUERY HERE\PYGZdq{},
    \PYGZdq{}resultFormat\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZdq{}JSON\PYGZdq{},
    \PYGZdq{}modelId\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZdq{}OPTIONAL INSERT MODEL mRID HERE\PYGZdq{},
    \PYGZdq{}objectType\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZdq{}OPTIONAL INSERT CIM CLASS HERE\PYGZdq{},
    \PYGZdq{}objectId\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZdq{}OPTIONAL INSERT OBJECT mRID HERE\PYGZdq{},
    \PYGZdq{}filter\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZdq{}OPTIONAL INSERT SPARQL FILTER HERE\PYGZdq{}
\PYGZcb{}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The components of the message are as follows:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"requestType":}} \textendash{} Specifies the type of query. Available requestType are listed in the next section.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"resultFormat":}} \textendash{} Specifies the format of the response, can be \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"JSON"}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"CSV"}}, or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"XML"}}. (CAUTION: the PowerGridModel API uses the key \sphinxstyleemphasis{resultFormat}, while the Timeseries API uses the key \sphinxstyleemphasis{reponseFormat}. Using the wrong key for either API will result in a java.lang error.)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"modelID":}} \textendash{} Optional. Used to filter the query to only one particular model whose mRID is specified. Be aware of spelling and capitalization differences between JSON query spelling \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"modelId"}} and Python Library spelling \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{model\_id}}.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"objectType":}} \textendash{} Optional. Used to filter the query to only one CIM class of equipment. Speciying the \sphinxstyleemphasis{objectID} will override any values specified for \sphinxstyleemphasis{objectType}.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"objectID":}} \textendash{} Optional. Used to filter the query to only one object whose mRID is specified. Specifying the \sphinxstyleemphasis{objectID} will override any values specified for \sphinxstyleemphasis{objectType}.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"filter":}} \textendash{} Optional. Used to filter the query using a SPARQL filter. SPARQL queries are covered in the next lesson.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The usage of each of these message components are explained in detail with code block examples below.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Important}: Be sure to pay attention to placement of commas ( \sphinxstylestrong{,} ) at the end of each JSON line. Commas are placed at the end of each line \sphinxstyleemphasis{except} the last line. Incorrect comma placement will result in a JsonSyntaxException.

\sphinxAtStartPar
All of the queries are passed to the PowerGrid Model API using the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{.get\_response(topic, message)}} method for the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D platform connection variable.


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\subsection{Specifying the requestType}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.3-Using-the-PowerGrid-Models-API:Specifying-the-requestType}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Below are the possible \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{requestType}} strings that are used to specify the type of each query. Executable code block examples are provided for each of the requests in the subsections below.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The first group of \sphinxstyleemphasis{requestType} key\sphinxhyphen{}value pairs are for queries for information related to the just the mRIDs of a set of feeders or set of equipment within a particular feeder:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"requestType": "QUERY\_MODEL\_NAMES"}} \textendash{} {\hyperref[\detokenize{api_usage/3.3-Using-the-PowerGrid-Models-API:Query-for-mRIDs-of-all-Models}]{\emph{Query for the list of all model name mRIDs}}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"requestType": "QUERY\_OBJECT\_IDS"}} \textendash{} {\hyperref[\detokenize{api_usage/3.3-Using-the-PowerGrid-Models-API:Query-for-mRIDs-of-Objects-in-a-Feeder}]{\emph{Query for a list of all mRIDs for objects of a CIM class}}}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The second group of \sphinxstyleemphasis{requestType} key\sphinxhyphen{}value pairs are for queries for Python dictionaries containing all specifics of a set of feeders or set of equipment within a particular feeder:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"requestType": "QUERY\_MODEL\_INFO"}} \textendash{} {\hyperref[\detokenize{api_usage/3.3-Using-the-PowerGrid-Models-API:Query-for-Details-Dictionary-of-all-Models}]{\emph{Query for the dictionary of all details for all feeders in Blazegraph}}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"requestType": "QUERY\_OBJECT\_DICT"}} \textendash{} {\hyperref[\detokenize{api_usage/3.3-Using-the-PowerGrid-Models-API:Query-for-Object-Dictionary}]{\emph{Query for the dictionary of all details for an object using either its *objectType* OR its *objectID*}}}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The third group of \sphinxstyleemphasis{requestType} key\sphinxhyphen{}value pairs are for obtaining information about CIM objects and attributes:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"requestType": "QUERY\_OBJECT\_TYPES"}} \textendash{} {\hyperref[\detokenize{api_usage/3.3-Using-the-PowerGrid-Models-API:Query-for-CIM-Classes-of-Objects-in-Model}]{\emph{Query for the types of CIM classes of objects in the model}}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"requestType": "QUERY\_OBJECT"}} \textendash{} {\hyperref[\detokenize{api_usage/3.3-Using-the-PowerGrid-Models-API:Query-for-CIM-Attributes-of-an-Object}]{\emph{Query for CIM attributes of an object using its unique mRID}}}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
One of the most important queries is for object measurements. Each piece of equipment has voltage, power, and/or position measurements associated with it. Each measurement has a unique mRID which is different from that of the equipment.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"requestType": "QUERY\_OBJECT\_MEASUREMENTS"}} \textendash{} {\hyperref[\detokenize{api_usage/3.3-Using-the-PowerGrid-Models-API:Querying-for-Measurements}]{\emph{Query for all measurement types and mRIDs for an object using either its *objectType* OR its *ObjectID*}}}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The last group of \sphinxstyleemphasis{requestType} key\sphinxhyphen{}value pairs are for queries based on SPARQL filters or complete SPARQL queries. Usage of these two \sphinxstyleemphasis{requestType} is made in conjunction with custom SPARQL queries given in \sphinxhref{https://github.com/GRIDAPPSD/CIMHub/blob/master/queries.txt}{Sample SPARQL Queries}.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"requestType": "QUERY\_MODEL"}} \textendash{} Query for all part of a specified model, filtered by object type using a SPARQL filter.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"requestType": "QUERY"}} \textendash{} Query using a complete SPARQL query.

\end{itemize}

\section{Querying for Model mRIDS}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.3-Using-the-PowerGrid-Models-API:Querying-for-Model-mRIDS}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Every piece of equipment has a unique mRID, as explained in {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/2.6-Common-Information-Model::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc}{Intro to Common Information Model}}}}. These mRIDs are used to identify and communicate with equipment in GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The set of queries below provide just the mRIDs of equipment matching the query filters. If the full details of equipment are desired (e.g. name and properties), use the {\hyperref[\detokenize{api_usage/3.3-Using-the-PowerGrid-Models-API:Querying-for-Equipment-Dictionaries}]{\emph{Query for Equipment Dictionaries}}} API calls in the next section.

\sphinxAtStartPar
This section outlines the pre\sphinxhyphen{}built JSON queries that can be passed to the PowerGrid Model API to obtain mRIDs and other information for all models and feeders stored in the Blazegraph Database.


\subsection{Query for mRIDs of all Models}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.3-Using-the-PowerGrid-Models-API:Query-for-mRIDs-of-all-Models}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This query obtains a list of all the model MRIDs stored in the Blazegraph database.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Query requestType:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"requestType": "QUERY\_MODEL\_NAMES"}}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Allowed parameters:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"resultFormat":}} \textendash{} “XML” / “JSON” / “CSV” \textendash{} Optional. Will return results as a list in the format selected.

\end{itemize}

{
\sphinxsetup{VerbatimColor={named}{nbsphinx-code-bg}}
\sphinxsetup{VerbatimBorderColor={named}{nbsphinx-code-border}}
\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\llap{\color{nbsphinxin}[ ]:\,\hspace{\fboxrule}\hspace{\fboxsep}}\PYG{n}{message} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{requestType}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{QUERY\PYGZus{}MODEL\PYGZus{}NAMES}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{resultFormat}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{JSON}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}

\PYG{n}{gapps}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{get\PYGZus{}response}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{topic}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{message}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The same query can be passed through the STOMP client by specifying the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{goss.gridappsd.process.request.data.powergridmodel}} topic and the same message without the python wrapping:

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=1917\sphinxpxdimen,height=816\sphinxpxdimen]{{QUERY_OBJECT_IDS}.png}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Python Library Method}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The GridAPPSD\sphinxhyphen{}Python library contains a pre\sphinxhyphen{}built method for obtaining the mRIDs of all models, providing identical results to those obtained above.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{.query\_model\_names}} method is associated with the GridAPPSD connection object and returns a list of all the CIM XML classes of objects present in the Blazegraph for a particular model or all models in the database.

\subsection{Query for mRIDs of Objects in a Feeder}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.3-Using-the-PowerGrid-Models-API:Query-for-mRIDs-of-Objects-in-a-Feeder}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This query is used to obtain all the mRIDs of objects of a particular CIM class in the feeder.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Query responseType is
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"requestType": "QUERY\_OBJECT\_IDS"}}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Allowed parameters are:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"modelId":}} “model name mRID” \textendash{} When specified it searches against that model, if empty it will search against all models

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"objectType":}} “CIM Class” \textendash{} Optional. Specifies the type of objects you wish to return details for.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"resultFormat":}} \textendash{} “XML” / “JSON” / “CSV” \textendash{} Will return results as a list in the format selected.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Within a particular feeder, it is possible to query for objects of all the CIM classes supported by PowerGrid Models API (discussed above in {\hyperref[\detokenize{api_usage/3.3-Using-the-PowerGrid-Models-API:CIM-Objects-Supported-by-PowerGrid-Models-API}]{\emph{CIM Objects Supported by the API}}}). Other types of equipment require custom SPARQL queries.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Note that the RDF URI is not included in the query, only the name of the class, such as \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"objectType": "ACLineSegment"}} or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"objectType": "LoadBreakSwitch"}}.

{
\sphinxsetup{VerbatimColor={named}{nbsphinx-code-bg}}
\sphinxsetup{VerbatimBorderColor={named}{nbsphinx-code-border}}
\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\llap{\color{nbsphinxin}[ ]:\,\hspace{\fboxrule}\hspace{\fboxsep}}\PYG{n}{message} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{requestType}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{QUERY\PYGZus{}OBJECT\PYGZus{}IDS}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{modelId}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{model\PYGZus{}mrid}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{objectType}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{LoadBreakSwitch}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{resultFormat}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{JSON}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}

\PYG{n}{gapps}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{get\PYGZus{}response}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{topic}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{message}\PYG{p}{)}

\subsection{Query for Object Dictionary}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.3-Using-the-PowerGrid-Models-API:Query-for-Object-Dictionary}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This query returns a python dictionary of all the equipment attributes and mRIDs. The query can be for 1) all objects of a particular \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{objectType}} or 2) for those connected to a particular object based on the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{objectId}}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
If neither \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{objectType}} or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{objectId}} is provided, the query will provide all measurements belonging to the model. Query responseType is
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"requestType": "QUERY\_OBJECT\_DICT"}}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Allowed parameters are:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"modelId":}} “model name mRID” \textendash{} When specified it searches against that model, if empty it will search against all models

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"objectId":}} “object mRID” \textendash{} Optional. Specifies the type of objects you wish to return details for.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"objectType":}} “CIM Class” \textendash{} Optional. Specifies the type of objects you wish to return details for.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"resultFormat":}} “XML” / “JSON” / “CSV” \textendash{} Will return results as a list in the format selected.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Speciying the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{objectID}} will override any values specified for \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{objectType}}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Example 1: Querying for model dictionary for an \textasciigrave{}\textasciigrave{}”objectID”:\textasciigrave{}\textasciigrave{}}

    \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{requestType}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{QUERY\PYGZus{}OBJECT\PYGZus{}DICT}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{modelId}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{model\PYGZus{}mrid}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{objectId}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{switch\PYGZus{}mrids}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{,}

\section{Querying for CIM Attributes}

\subsection{Query for CIM Classes of Objects in Model}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.3-Using-the-PowerGrid-Models-API:Query-for-CIM-Classes-of-Objects-in-Model}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This query is used to query for a list of all the CIM XML classes of objects present in the Blazegraph for a particular model or all models in the database.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Query requestType is
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"requestType": "QUERY\_OBJECT\_TYPES"}}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Allowed parameters are
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"modelId":}} “model name mRID” \textendash{} Optional. Searches only the particular model identified by the given unique mRID

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"resultFormat":}} \textendash{} “XML” / “JSON” / “CSV” \textendash{} Will return results as a list in the format selected.

\end{itemize}



__1) Query entire Blazegraph database__

Omit the `"modelId"` parameter to search the entire blazegraph database.

{

    \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{resultFormat}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{JSON}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
}

\sphinxAtStartPar
This query is used to obtain all the attributes and mRIDs of those attributes for a particular object whose mRID is specified.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Query responseType is
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar

Allowed parameters are:
\begin{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"objectId":}} “object mRID” \textendash{} Optional. Specifies the type of objects you wish to return details for.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"resultFormat":}} \textendash{} “XML” / “JSON” / “CSV” \textendash{} Will return results as a list in the format selected.

\end{itemize}

{
\sphinxsetup{VerbatimColor={named}{nbsphinx-code-bg}}
\sphinxsetup{VerbatimBorderColor={named}{nbsphinx-code-border}}

\PYG{n}{message} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{requestType}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{QUERY\PYGZus{}OBJECT}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{resultFormat}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{JSON}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{modelId}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{model\PYGZus{}mrid}\PYG{p}{,}
