\section{Querying for Object Measurements}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.3-Using-the-PowerGrid-Models-API:Querying-for-Object-Measurements}}

\subsection{Object mRIDs vs Measurement mRIDs}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.3-Using-the-PowerGrid-Models-API:Object-mRIDs-vs-Measurement-mRIDs}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
A key concept in GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D and CIM XML power system models is the difference between the object mRID of a piece of equipment and multiple measurement mRIDs associated with its control settings and power flow values.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Measurements differ from the state variables (e.g. those obtained from State Estimator or a power flow calculation) in that the values are measured here and not calculated or estimated. Each Measurement is associated to a \sphinxstyleemphasis{PowerSystemResource}, and in GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D for now, also a Terminal that belongs to the same \sphinxstyleemphasis{PowerSystemResource}. (Non\sphinxhyphen{}electrical measurements, for example weather, would not have the Terminal).

\sphinxAtStartPar
The \sphinxstyleemphasis{measurementType} is a string code from IEC 61850, with the following currently suppported:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{PNV} \textendash{} Phase to Neutral Voltage

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{VA} \textendash{} Volt\sphinxhyphen{}Amperes (apparent power)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{A} \textendash{} Amperes (current)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{POS} \textendash{} Position for switches and transformer taps

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Each measurement object has a \sphinxstylestrong{name}, \sphinxstylestrong{mRID}, and \sphinxstylestrong{phases}. In GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D, each phase is measured individually so multi\sphinxhyphen{}phase codes like ABC should not be used.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Pos measurements will be discrete, for such things as tap position, switch position, or capacitor bank position.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The others will be Analog, with magnitude and optional angle in degrees.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Each MeasurementValue will have a timeStamp and mRID inherited from IdentifiedObject, so the values can be traced.


\subsection{Querying for Measurements}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.3-Using-the-PowerGrid-Models-API:Querying-for-Measurements}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This query returns details for the measurements within a model. The query can be for 1) all objects of a particular \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{objectType}} or 2) for those connected to a particular object based on the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{objectId}}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
If neither \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{objectType}} or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{objectId}} is provided, the query will provide all measurements belonging to the model. Query responseType is
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"requestType": "QUERY\_OBJECT\_MEASUREMENTS"}}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Allowed parameters are:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"modelId":}} “model name mRID” \textendash{} When specified it searches against that model, if empty it will search against all models

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"objectId":}} “object mRID” \textendash{} Optional. Specifies the type of objects you wish to return details for.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"objectType":}} “CIM Class” \textendash{} Optional. Specifies the type of objects you wish to return details for.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"resultFormat":}} “XML” / “JSON” / “CSV” \textendash{} Will return results as a list in the format selected.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Speciying the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{objectID}} will override any values specified for \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{objectType}}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Example 1: Querying for all measurements for an \textasciigrave{}\textasciigrave{}”objectID”:\textasciigrave{}\textasciigrave{}}

    \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{requestType}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{QUERY\PYGZus{}OBJECT\PYGZus{}MEASUREMENTS}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{modelId}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{model\PYGZus{}mrid}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{objectId}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{switch\PYGZus{}mrids}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{,}

\sphinxAtStartPar
This query returns a dictionary of all objects matching the particular filter. The query can be for 1) all objects of a particular \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{objectType}} or 2) those with attributes corresponding to a particular SPARQL filter, or both.

\sphinxAtStartPar
If neither \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{objectType}} or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{filter}} is specified, the query will provide all objects belonging to the model. Query responseType is

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"filter":}} “SPARQL triple” \textendash{} Optional. Applies the SPARQL triple filter to the query results

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar

\end{itemize}

\section{8. Available Models in Default Installation}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.3-Using-the-PowerGrid-Models-API:8.-Available-Models-in-Default-Installation}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform comes by default loaded with several distribution feeders ranging in size from 13 to 9500 nodes. Each feeder and recommended usage cases are summarized below.


\subsection{IEEE 13 Node Model}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.3-Using-the-PowerGrid-Models-API:IEEE-13-Node-Model}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This is a very small distribution test feeder operating at 4.16 kV voltage level. It consists of a single voltage regulator at the substation, overhead and underground lines, shunt capacitor, and an in\sphinxhyphen{}line transformer. This feeder is relatively highly loaded and provides a good test of the convergence of the problem for a very unbalanced system.

\sphinxAtStartPar
This model is recommended for debugging as the model is small enough that issues can be traced by hand.


\subsection{IEEE 123 Node Model}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.3-Using-the-PowerGrid-Models-API:IEEE-123-Node-Model}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This models a medium\sphinxhyphen{}sized unbalanced distribution system operating at the nominal voltage of 4.16 kV. It consists of overhead and underground lines with single, two and three\sphinxhyphen{}phase laterals, along with step regulators and shunt capacitors for voltage regulation. The feeder model is characterized by the unbalanced loading having all combinations of load types (constant current, impedance, and power). It also includes a few switches to allow for the alternate paths for the power flow via feeder
reconfiguration.

\sphinxAtStartPar
This model is recommended for initial app testing and debugging thorugh the first stages of development.


\subsection{IEEE 123 Node Model with PV}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.3-Using-the-PowerGrid-Models-API:IEEE-123-Node-Model-with-PV}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This model is a derivative of the IEEE 123 Node model and includes rooftop solar throughout the system.


\subsection{IEEE 8500 Node Model}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.3-Using-the-PowerGrid-Models-API:IEEE-8500-Node-Model}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This is a relatively large and realistic radial distribution feeder consisting of MV and LV (secondary) circuits {[}21{]}. Unlike other test systems, this feeder also includes 120/240V center\sphinxhyphen{}tapped transformers that are commonly deployed in North American power distribution systems. Thus, it allows for users to interchange between the two versions of loading conditions: balanced (208 V) and unbalanced (120 V) in the secondary transformers. Voltage control is possible using a substation LTC
transformer, as well as multiple poletop regulators and capacitor banks. The feeder was created to test scalability and convergence of power flow algorithms on a large unbalanced power distribution system.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Length: 170 km

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Nominal voltage: 12.47 kV, 120/240V

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Topology: radial

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Service transformers: yes

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Customers: 1177

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Peak load: 11.1 MW

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Normally\sphinxhyphen{}open switches: no

\end{itemize}


\subsection{9500 Node Test System}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.3-Using-the-PowerGrid-Models-API:9500-Node-Test-System}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The 9500 Node Test System includes three radial distribution feeders with just over 12 MW of load, consisting of both medium voltage and low voltage equipment each supplied by a different distribution substation. The three distribution feeders are connected to each other through Normally\sphinxhyphen{}Open switches, which is representative of the way many utilities operate in North America. One feeder represents today’s grid with low penetration of customer\sphinxhyphen{}side renewables. The second represents a potential
future grid with microgrids and 100\% renewable penetration. The third has no customer resources, a district steam plant, and a utility\sphinxhyphen{}scale PV farm. All three feeders have customers connected by low\sphinxhyphen{}voltage secondary triplex lines.

\sphinxAtStartPar
This is the recommended target feeder for development of all new applications

\section{Adding New Models to GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.3-Using-the-PowerGrid-Models-API:Adding-New-Models-to-GridAPPS-D}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{git clone https://github.com/GRIDAPPSD/CIMHub.git}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{pip install SPARQLWrapper numpy pandas}}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Copy CIM XML file and UUID file into CIMHub directory.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Open CIMHub directory in terminal:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{cd CIMHub}}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
View the list of feeder models currently in the Blazegraph Database:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{python3 ../CIMHub/utils/ListFeeders.py}}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Upload your new model using \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{curl}} to Blazegraph, specifying the name and MRID of your new feeder:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{curl \sphinxhyphen{}s \sphinxhyphen{}D\sphinxhyphen{} \sphinxhyphen{}H \textquotesingle{}Content\sphinxhyphen{}Type: application/xml\textquotesingle{} \sphinxhyphen{}\sphinxhyphen{}upload\sphinxhyphen{}file \textquotesingle{}yournewmodel.xml\textquotesingle{} \sphinxhyphen{}X POST \textquotesingle{}http://localhost:8889/bigdata/namespace/kb/sparql\textquotesingle{}}}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Create the set of txt files containing the measurable objects in your new model using the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ListMeasurables}} script:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{python3 ../CIMHub/utils/ListMeasureables.py cimhubconfig.json yournewmodel \_YOUR\sphinxhyphen{}NEW\sphinxhyphen{}MODEL\sphinxhyphen{}FEEDER\sphinxhyphen{}MRID\sphinxhyphen{}123ABC456}}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Insert the measurements into Blazegraph using the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{InsertMeasurements}} script. The measurement MRIDs will be saved into the file \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{uuidfile.json}}:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{for f in \textasciigrave{}ls \sphinxhyphen{}1 *txt\textasciigrave{}; do python3 ../CIMHub/utils/InsertMeasurements.py cimhubconfig.json \$f uuidfile.json; done}}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Insert houses into Blazegraph using the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{InsertHouses}} script. The measurement MRIDs for the houses will be saved into the file \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{uuidfile2.json}}: * \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{python3 ../CIMHub/utils/InsertHouses.py cimhubconfig.json \_YOUR\sphinxhyphen{}NEW\sphinxhyphen{}MODEL\sphinxhyphen{}FEEDER\sphinxhyphen{}MRID\sphinxhyphen{}123ABC456 1 1 uuidfile2.json}}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Open the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Viz in a new window and you should be able to start a simulation using your new model

\chapter{Using the Configuration File API}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.4-Using-the-Configuration-File-API:Using-the-Configuration-File-API}}\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.4-Using-the-Configuration-File-API::doc}}

\section{1. Introduction to the Configuration File API}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.4-Using-the-Configuration-File-API:1.-Introduction-to-the-Configuration-File-API}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The Configuration File API is used to generate power system models that can be solved in GridLab\sphinxhyphen{}D or OpenDSS based on the original CIM XML model. The load profile and ZIP parameters can be modified from the nominal values prior to model creation and export.

\sphinxAtStartPar
In the Application Components diagram (explained in detail with sample code in \sphinxhref{../overview/2.4--Lesson-2.4--GridAPPS-D-Application-Structure.ipynb}{GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Application Structure}), the Configuration File API is used for configuring parallel simulations and exporting the power system model.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=1601\sphinxpxdimen,height=1137\sphinxpxdimen]{{04_config_sim_export}.png}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Application passes query to GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform}

\sphinxAtStartPar
First, the application creates a query message for requesting information about the desired power system configuration in the format of a JSON string or equivalant Python dictionary object. The syntax of this message is explained in detail below.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The application then passes the query through the Configuration File API to the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform, which publishes it to a queue channel on the GOSS Message Bus. If the app is authenticated and authorized to pass queries, the query message is delivered to the Configuration Manager.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform responds to Application query}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The Configuration Manager obtains the CIM XML file for the desired power system model and then converts it to the desired output format with all of the requested changes to the model. The Configuration File API then returns the desired information back to the application as a JSON message (for Y\sphinxhyphen{}Bus or partial models) or export the files to the directory specified in the


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\section{2. API Syntax Overview}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.4-Using-the-Configuration-File-API:2.-API-Syntax-Overview}}

\subsection{2.1. API Communication Channel}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.4-Using-the-Configuration-File-API:2.1.-API-Communication-Channel}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
All queries passed to the PowerGrid Models API need to use the correct communication channel, which is obtained using the \sphinxhref{../api\_usage/3.1--Lesson-3.1--API-Communication-Channels.ipynb}{GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Topics library}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The PowerGrid Model API uses a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{/queue/}} channel to pull power system model info from the the Blazegraph Database. The base static string used is \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{goss.gridappsd.process.request.config}}, which can be called using the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{.CONFIG}} method from the topics library.

\sphinxAtStartPar
When developing in python, it is recommended to use the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{.CONFIG}} method. When using the STOMP client in GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D VIZ, it is necessary to use the base static string.

{
\sphinxsetup{VerbatimColor={named}{nbsphinx-code-bg}}
\sphinxsetup{VerbatimBorderColor={named}{nbsphinx-code-border}}
\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\llap{\color{nbsphinxin}[ ]:\,\hspace{\fboxrule}\hspace{\fboxsep}}\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{gridappsd} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{topics} \PYG{k}{as} \PYG{n}{t}
\PYG{n}{topic} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{t}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{CONFIG}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
}


\subsection{2.2. Structure of a Query Message}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.4-Using-the-Configuration-File-API:2.2.-Structure-of-a-Query-Message}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Queries passed to Configuration File API are formatted as python dictionaries or equivalent JSON scripts wrapped as a python string.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The accepted set of key\sphinxhyphen{}value pairs for the Configuration File API query message is

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
message = \PYGZob{}
    \PYGZdq{}configurationType\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZdq{}INSERT QUERY HERE\PYGZdq{},
    \PYGZdq{}parameters\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZob{}
        \PYGZdq{}key1\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZdq{}value1\PYGZdq{},
        \PYGZdq{}key2\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZdq{}value2\PYGZdq{}\PYGZcb{}
\PYGZcb{}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The components of the message are as follows:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"configurationType":}} \textendash{} Specifies the type of configuration file requested.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"parameters":}} \textendash{} Specifies any specific power system model parameters. Values depend on the particular configurationType.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The usage of each of these message components are explained in detail with code block examples below.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Important}: Be sure to pay attention to placement of commas ( \sphinxstylestrong{,} ) at the end of each JSON line. Commas are placed at the end of each line \sphinxstyleemphasis{except} the last line. Incorrect comma placement will result in a JsonSyntaxException.

\sphinxAtStartPar
All of the queries are passed to the Configuration API using the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{.get\_response(topic, message)}} method for the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D platform connection variable.


\subsection{2.3. Specifying the \sphinxstyleliteralintitle{\sphinxupquote{configurationType}}}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.4-Using-the-Configuration-File-API:2.3.-Specifying-the-configurationType}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Below are the possible \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{configurationType}} key\sphinxhyphen{}value pairs that are used to specify the type of each query. Executable code block examples are provided for each of the requests in the subsections below.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The first group of \sphinxstyleemphasis{configurationType} key\sphinxhyphen{}value pairs are for queries for information related to the GridLab\sphinxhyphen{}D GLM files and settings:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"configurationType": "GridLab\sphinxhyphen{}D All"}} \textendash{} {\hyperref[\detokenize{api_usage/3.4-Using-the-Configuration-File-API:3.1.-Query-for-all-GridLab-D-Files}]{\emph{Query for all GridLab\sphinxhyphen{}D files}}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"configurationType": "GridLab\sphinxhyphen{}D Base GLM"}} \textendash{} {\hyperref[\detokenize{api_usage/3.4-Using-the-Configuration-File-API:3.2.-Query-for-GridLab-D-Base-GLM-File}]{\emph{Query for GridLab\sphinxhyphen{}D base GLM file}}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"configurationType": "GridLab\sphinxhyphen{}D Symbols"}} \textendash{} {\hyperref[\detokenize{api_usage/3.4-Using-the-Configuration-File-API:3.3.-Query-for-GridLab-D-Symbols-File}]{\emph{Query for GridLab\sphinxhyphen{}D symbols file}}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"configurationType": "GridLab\sphinxhyphen{}D Simulation Output"}} \textendash{} {\hyperref[\detokenize{api_usage/3.4-Using-the-Configuration-File-API:3.4.-Query-for-GridLab-D-Measurement-Types}]{\emph{Query for available measurement types}}}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The second group of \sphinxstyleemphasis{configurationType} are for queries for CIM dictionary and feeder index files:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"configurationType": "CIM Dictionary"}} \textendash{} {\hyperref[\detokenize{api_usage/3.4-Using-the-Configuration-File-API:4.1.-Query-for-Model-Dictionary}]{\emph{Query for python dictionary of CIM XML model}}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"configurationType": "CIM Feeder Index"}} \textendash{} {\hyperref[\detokenize{api_usage/3.4-Using-the-Configuration-File-API:4.2.-Query-for-CIM-Feeder-Index}]{\emph{Query for python dictionary of model mRIDs}}}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The third group of \sphinxstyleemphasis{configurationType} key\sphinxhyphen{}value pairs are for queries for OpenDSS model files
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"configurationType": "DSS All"}} \textendash{} {\hyperref[\detokenize{api_usage/3.4-Using-the-Configuration-File-API:5.1.-Query-for-all-OpenDSS-Files}]{\emph{Query for all OpenDSS model files}}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"configurationType": "DSS Base"}} \textendash{} {\hyperref[\detokenize{api_usage/3.4-Using-the-Configuration-File-API:5.2.-Query-for-OpenDSS-Base-File}]{\emph{Query for OpenDSS version of power system model}}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"configurationType": "DSS Coordinate"}} \textendash{} {\hyperref[\detokenize{api_usage/3.4-Using-the-Configuration-File-API:5.3.-Query-for-OpenDSS-Coordinate-File}]{\emph{Query for list of OpenDSS XY coordinates}}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"configurationType": "YBus Export"}} \textendash{} {\hyperref[\detokenize{api_usage/3.4-Using-the-Configuration-File-API:5.4.-Query-for-Y-Bus-Matrix}]{\emph{Export Y\sphinxhyphen{}Bus matrix from OpenDSS}}}

\end{itemize}

\section{3. Querying for GridLab\sphinxhyphen{}D Configuration Files}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.4-Using-the-Configuration-File-API:3.-Querying-for-GridLab-D-Configuration-Files}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This section outlines the details of key\sphinxhyphen{}value pairs for the possible queries associated with each value of the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{queryMeasurement}} key listed above.


\subsection{3.1. Query for all GridLab\sphinxhyphen{}D Files}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.4-Using-the-Configuration-File-API:3.1.-Query-for-all-GridLab-D-Files}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This API call generates all the GLM files necessary to solve the power system model in GridLab\sphinxhyphen{}D. The query returns a directory where the set of GLM files are located.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Configuration File request key\sphinxhyphen{}value pair:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"configurationType": "GridLab\sphinxhyphen{}D All"}}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{parameters}} key has a set of required values as well as some optional values:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYGZdq{}parameters\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZob{}     REQUIRED KEYS                   REQUIRED VALUES
                \PYGZdq{}model\PYGZus{}id\PYGZdq{}:                           mRID as string ,
                \PYGZdq{}directory\PYGZdq{}:                          output directory as string ,
                \PYGZdq{}simulation\PYGZus{}name\PYGZdq{}:                    string ,
                \PYGZdq{}simulation\PYGZus{}start\PYGZus{}time\PYGZdq{}:              epoch time number ,
                \PYGZdq{}simulation\PYGZus{}duration\PYGZdq{}:                number ,
                \PYGZdq{}simulation\PYGZus{}id\PYGZdq{}:                      number ,
                \PYGZdq{}simulation\PYGZus{}broker\PYGZus{}host\PYGZdq{}:             string ,
                \PYGZdq{}simulation\PYGZus{}broker\PYGZus{}port\PYGZdq{}:             number ,
                    OPTIONAL KEYS                  OPTIONAL VALUES
                \PYGZdq{}i\PYGZus{}fraction\PYGZdq{}:                         number ,
                \PYGZdq{}p\PYGZus{}fraction\PYGZdq{}:                         number ,
                \PYGZdq{}z\PYGZus{}fraction\PYGZdq{}:                         number ,
                \PYGZdq{}load\PYGZus{}scaling\PYGZus{}factor\PYGZdq{}:                number ,
                \PYGZdq{}schedule\PYGZus{}name\PYGZdq{}:                      string ,
                \PYGZdq{}solver\PYGZus{}method\PYGZdq{}:                      string \PYGZcb{}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The numeric values for the key\sphinxhyphen{}value pairs associated with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{parameters}} can be written as number or as strings. The key\sphinxhyphen{}value pairs can be specified in any order.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Example: Export IEEE 13 node model with constant current loads to GLM files :}

\subsection{4.2. Query for CIM Feeder Index}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.4-Using-the-Configuration-File-API:4.2.-Query-for-CIM-Feeder-Index}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This API call returns a python dictionary of the available feeders in the Blazegraph database of power system models.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Configuration File request key\sphinxhyphen{}value pair:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"configurationType": "CIM Feeder Index"}}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{parameters}} key has a set of required values as well as some optional values:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYGZdq{}parameters\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZob{}     REQUIRED KEYS                   REQUIRED VALUES
                \PYGZdq{}model\PYGZus{}id\PYGZdq{}:                           mRID as string ,
                    OPTIONAL KEYS                  OPTIONAL VALUES
                \PYGZdq{}simulation\PYGZus{}id\PYGZdq{}:                      number \PYGZcb{}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The key\sphinxhyphen{}value pairs can be specified in any order.

{
\sphinxsetup{VerbatimColor={named}{nbsphinx-code-bg}}
\sphinxsetup{VerbatimBorderColor={named}{nbsphinx-code-border}}
\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\llap{\color{nbsphinxin}[ ]:\,\hspace{\fboxrule}\hspace{\fboxsep}}\PYG{n}{topic} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{goss.gridappsd.process.request.config}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}

\PYG{n}{message} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{configurationType}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{CIM Feeder Index}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{parameters}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{model\PYGZus{}id}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{model\PYGZus{}mrid}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}

\PYG{n}{gapps}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{get\PYGZus{}response}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{topic}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{message}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
}

\section{5. Querying for OpenDSS Configuration Files}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.4-Using-the-Configuration-File-API:5.-Querying-for-OpenDSS-Configuration-Files}}

\subsection{5.1. Query for all OpenDSS Files}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.4-Using-the-Configuration-File-API:5.1.-Query-for-all-OpenDSS-Files}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This API call generates all the OpenDSS files necessary to solve the power system model in OpenDSS. The query returns a directory where the set of DSS files are located.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Configuration File request key\sphinxhyphen{}value pair:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"configurationType": "DSS All"}}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{parameters}} key has a set of required values as well as some optional values:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYGZdq{}parameters\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZob{}     REQUIRED KEYS                   REQUIRED VALUES
                \PYGZdq{}model\PYGZus{}id\PYGZdq{}:                           mRID as string ,
                \PYGZdq{}directory\PYGZdq{}:                          desired output directory as string ,
                \PYGZdq{}simulation\PYGZus{}name\PYGZdq{}:                     string ,
                \PYGZdq{}simulation\PYGZus{}start\PYGZus{}time\PYGZdq{}:              epoch time number ,
                \PYGZdq{}simulation\PYGZus{}duration\PYGZdq{}:                number ,
                \PYGZdq{}simulation\PYGZus{}id\PYGZdq{}:                      number ,
                \PYGZdq{}simulation\PYGZus{}broker\PYGZus{}host\PYGZdq{}:             string ,
                \PYGZdq{}simulation\PYGZus{}broker\PYGZus{}port\PYGZdq{}:             number ,
                    OPTIONAL KEYS                  OPTIONAL VALUES
                \PYGZdq{}i\PYGZus{}fraction\PYGZdq{}:                         number ,
                \PYGZdq{}p\PYGZus{}fraction\PYGZdq{}:                         number ,
                \PYGZdq{}z\PYGZus{}fraction\PYGZdq{}:                         number ,
                \PYGZdq{}load\PYGZus{}scaling\PYGZus{}factor\PYGZdq{}:                number ,
                \PYGZdq{}schedule\PYGZus{}name\PYGZdq{}:                      string ,
                \PYGZdq{}solver\PYGZus{}method\PYGZdq{}:                      string \PYGZcb{}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The numeric values for the key\sphinxhyphen{}value pairs associated with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{parameters}} can be written as number or as strings. The key\sphinxhyphen{}value pairs can be specified in any order.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Example: Export IEEE 13 node model with constant current loads to DSS files :}

{
\sphinxsetup{VerbatimColor={named}{nbsphinx-code-bg}}
\sphinxsetup{VerbatimBorderColor={named}{nbsphinx-code-border}}
\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\llap{\color{nbsphinxin}[ ]:\,\hspace{\fboxrule}\hspace{\fboxsep}}\PYG{n}{topic} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{goss.gridappsd.process.request.config}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}

\PYG{n}{message} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{configurationType}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{DSS All}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{parameters}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
        \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{directory}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{/tmp/dsssimulation/}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
        \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{model\PYGZus{}id}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{model\PYGZus{}mrid}\PYG{p}{,}
        \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{simulation\PYGZus{}id}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{12345678}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
        \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{simulation\PYGZus{}name}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{ieee13}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
        \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{simulation\PYGZus{}start\PYGZus{}time}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{1518958800}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
        \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{simulation\PYGZus{}duration}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{60}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
        \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{simulation\PYGZus{}broker\PYGZus{}host}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{localhost}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
        \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{simulation\PYGZus{}broker\PYGZus{}port}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{61616}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
        \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{schedule\PYGZus{}name}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{ieeezipload}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
        \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{load\PYGZus{}scaling\PYGZus{}factor}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{1.0}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
        \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{z\PYGZus{}fraction}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{0.0}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
        \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{i\PYGZus{}fraction}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{1.0}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
        \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{p\PYGZus{}fraction}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{0.0}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
        \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{solver\PYGZus{}method}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{NR}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}} \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}

\PYG{n}{gapps}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{get\PYGZus{}response}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{topic}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{message}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Note:} The output directory is inside the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Docker Container, not in your Ubuntu or Windows environment. To access the files, it is necessary to change directories to those inside the docker container.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Open a new Ubuntu terminal and run: * \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{docker exec \sphinxhyphen{}it gridappsd\sphinxhyphen{}docker\_gridappsd\_1 bash}} * \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{cd /tmp/dssdsimulation}} * \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ls \sphinxhyphen{}l}}

\sphinxAtStartPar
To copy the files to your regular directory, use the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{docker cp}} command. For help using docker, see \sphinxhref{../installation/1.6--Lesson-1.6--Docker-Shortcuts.ipynb}{Docker Shortcuts} on working with Docker containers.

\subsection{5.2. Query for OpenDSS Base File}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.4-Using-the-Configuration-File-API:5.2.-Query-for-OpenDSS-Base-File}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This API call generates a single DSS file that contains the entire power system model that can be solved in OpenDSS. The query returns the entire model DSS file wrapped in a python dictionary.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Configuration File request key\sphinxhyphen{}value pair:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"configurationType": "DSS Base"}}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{parameters}} key has a set of required values as well as some optional values:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYGZdq{}parameters\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZob{}     REQUIRED KEYS                   REQUIRED VALUES
                \PYGZdq{}model\PYGZus{}id\PYGZdq{}:                           mRID as string ,
                    OPTIONAL KEYS                  OPTIONAL VALUES
                \PYGZdq{}i\PYGZus{}fraction\PYGZdq{}:                         number ,
                \PYGZdq{}p\PYGZus{}fraction\PYGZdq{}:                         number ,
                \PYGZdq{}z\PYGZus{}fraction\PYGZdq{}:                         number ,
                \PYGZdq{}load\PYGZus{}scaling\PYGZus{}factor\PYGZdq{}:                number ,
                \PYGZdq{}schedule\PYGZus{}name\PYGZdq{}:                      string \PYGZcb{}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The numeric values for the key\sphinxhyphen{}value pairs associated with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{parameters}} can be written as number or as strings. The key\sphinxhyphen{}value pairs can be specified in any order.

\chapter{Running Simulations with the Simulation API}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.5-Creating-Running-Simulation-API:Running-Simulations-with-the-Simulation-API}}\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.5-Creating-Running-Simulation-API::doc}}

\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\section{1. Introduction to the Simulation API}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.5-Creating-Running-Simulation-API:1.-Introduction-to-the-Simulation-API}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The Simulation API is used for all actions related to a power system simulation. It is used to start, pause, restart, and stop a simulation from the command line or inside an application. It is all used to subscribe to measurements of equipment (such as line flows, loads, and DG setpoints) and the statuses of switches, capacitors, transformer taps, etc. It is also used to publish equipment control and other simulation input commands.


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\section{2. Using the Simulation API}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.5-Creating-Running-Simulation-API:2.-Using-the-Simulation-API}}

\subsection{2.1. Specifying the Topic}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.5-Creating-Running-Simulation-API:2.1.-Specifying-the-Topic}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
In the previous lessons all the queries passed to other APIs all used static \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{/queue/}} channels to pass API calls to the GOSS message bus and the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform.

\sphinxAtStartPar
However, the Simulation API is used to communicate with a broad range of subscribers. The list of topics covered by the Simulation API cover both static \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{/queue/}} and dynamic \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{/topic/}} communication channel names.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Extreme care is needed to use the correct topic. For a review of GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D topics, see \sphinxhref{../api\_usage/3.1--Lesson-3.1--API-Communication-Channels.ipynb}{API Communication Channels}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The correct topic for each Simulation API call will be provided in the corresponding section for each API task below.

\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{api_usage/3.5-Creating-Running-Simulation-API:Table-of-Contents}]{\emph{Return to Top}}}


\subsection{2.2. Structure of a Simulation Message}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.5-Creating-Running-Simulation-API:2.2.-Structure-of-a-Simulation-Message}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Due to the wide range of tasks accomplished by the Simualtion API, there is no single message format that is used across all API Calls.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Each message takes the form of a python dictionary or equivalent JSON script wrapped as a python string.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The structure of each Simulation API call message will be provided in the corresponding section for each API task below.


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\section{3. Starting a Simulation}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.5-Creating-Running-Simulation-API:3.-Starting-a-Simulation}}

\subsection{3.1. Specify the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Topic}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.5-Creating-Running-Simulation-API:3.1.-Specify-the-GridAPPS-D-Topic}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This is a static \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{/queue/}} communication channel

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{1) Specifying the topic as a string:}

{
\sphinxsetup{VerbatimColor={named}{nbsphinx-code-bg}}

\end{sphinxVerbatim}
}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{2) Using the topics library to specify the topic:}

\subsection{3.2. API Message Structure}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.5-Creating-Running-Simulation-API:3.2.-API-Message-Structure}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
To start a simulation from the command line or from inside an application, it is necessary to pass a message with a structure similar to that used by the \sphinxhref{../api\_usage/3.4--Lesson-3.4--Using-the-Configuration-File-API.ipynb}{Configuration File API}) so that the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D platform can create a custom GridLab\sphinxhyphen{}D file from the CIM XML model stored in the Blazegraph Database.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The accepted set of key\sphinxhyphen{}value pairs for the Simulation API call to start a new simulation is

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
message = \PYGZob{}
    \PYGZdq{}power\PYGZus{}system\PYGZus{}config\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZob{}
        \PYGZdq{}key1\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZdq{}value1\PYGZdq{},
        \PYGZdq{}key2\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZdq{}value2\PYGZdq{}\PYGZcb{},
    \PYGZdq{}simulation\PYGZus{}config\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZob{}
        \PYGZdq{}key1\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZdq{}value1\PYGZdq{},

\subsubsection{3.2.1. \sphinxstyleliteralintitle{\sphinxupquote{"power\_system\_config":}}}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.5-Creating-Running-Simulation-API:3.2.1.-"power_system_config":}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This key is \sphinxstylestrong{required} and specifies the CIM XML model to be imported and used for the simulation. Required key\sphinxhyphen{}value pairs are

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYGZdq{}power\PYGZus{}system\PYGZus{}config\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZob{}   REQUIRED KEY                      REQUIRED VALUE
                     \PYGZdq{}GeographicalRegion\PYGZus{}name\PYGZdq{}:           mRID as string ,
                     \PYGZdq{}SubGeographicalRegion\PYGZus{}name\PYGZdq{}:        mRID as string ,
                     \PYGZdq{}Line\PYGZus{}name\PYGZdq{}:                         mRID as string \PYGZcb{}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
As can be seen, the required key\sphinxhyphen{}value pairs are identical to those that are selected graphically using the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Viz:

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics{{api_usage/images/3.5/config_system_config}.png}


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\subsubsection{simulation\_config}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.5-Creating-Running-Simulation-API:simulation_config}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This key is \sphinxstylestrong{required} and specifies the runtime parameters, such as simulation duration and time step. Required key\sphinxhyphen{}value pairs are

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYGZdq{}simulation\PYGZus{}config\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZob{}   REQUIRED KEY                      REQUIRED VALUE
                    \PYGZdq{}start\PYGZus{}time\PYGZdq{}:                    epoch time string ,
                    \PYGZdq{}duration\PYGZdq{}:                      number (seconds) ,
                    \PYGZdq{}simulator\PYGZdq{}:                     \PYGZdq{}GridLAB\PYGZhy{}D\PYGZdq{} ,
                    \PYGZdq{}timestep\PYGZus{}frequency\PYGZdq{}:            number (milliseconds) ,
                    \PYGZdq{}timestep\PYGZus{}increment\PYGZdq{}:            number (milliseconds) ,
                    \PYGZdq{}run\PYGZus{}realtime\PYGZdq{}:                  true OR false ,
                    \PYGZdq{}simulation\PYGZus{}name\PYGZdq{}:               string ,
                    \PYGZdq{}power\PYGZus{}flow\PYGZus{}solver\PYGZus{}method\PYGZdq{}:      \PYGZdq{}NR\PYGZdq{} ,
                    \PYGZdq{}model\PYGZus{}creation\PYGZus{}config\PYGZdq{}:         key\PYGZhy{}value pairs \PYGZcb{}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The key \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"model\_creation\_config":}} is one of the \sphinxstylestrong{optional} key\sphinxhyphen{}value pairs that can specified. This specifies the load profile and changes to the base case used for the simulation. Key\sphinxhyphen{}value pairs are

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYGZdq{}model\PYGZus{}creation\PYGZus{}config\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZob{} KEY                       VALUE
                    \PYGZdq{}load\PYGZus{}scaling\PYGZus{}factor\PYGZdq{}:             number ,
                    \PYGZdq{}schedule\PYGZus{}name\PYGZdq{}:                   string ,
                    \PYGZdq{}z\PYGZus{}fraction\PYGZdq{}:                      number ,
                    \PYGZdq{}i\PYGZus{}fraction\PYGZdq{}:                      number ,
                    \PYGZdq{}p\PYGZus{}fraction\PYGZdq{}:                      number ,
                    \PYGZdq{}randomize\PYGZus{}zipload\PYGZus{}fractions\PYGZdq{}:     true OR false ,
                    \PYGZdq{}use\PYGZus{}houses\PYGZdq{}:                      true OR false ,
                    \PYGZdq{}model\PYGZus{}state\PYGZdq{}:                     key\PYGZhy{}value pairs \PYGZcb{}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The key \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"model\_state:"}} is one of the \sphinxstylestrong{optional} key\sphinxhyphen{}value pairs used to specify changes to switch positions and DER setpoints from the base case stored in the Blazegraph database. Key\sphinxhyphen{}value pairs are

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYGZdq{}model\PYGZus{}state\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZob{}
                \PYGZdq{}synchronousmachines\PYGZdq{}:[
                        \PYGZob{}\PYGZdq{}name\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZdq{}GLM/DSS name\PYGZdq{},\PYGZdq{}p\PYGZdq{}: number,\PYGZdq{}q\PYGZdq{}: number\PYGZcb{},
                        \PYGZob{}\PYGZdq{}name\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZdq{}GLM/DSS name\PYGZdq{},\PYGZdq{}p\PYGZdq{}: number,\PYGZdq{}q\PYGZdq{}: number\PYGZcb{}],
                \PYGZdq{}switches\PYGZdq{}:[
                        \PYGZob{}\PYGZdq{}name\PYGZdq{}:\PYGZdq{}GLM/DSS name\PYGZdq{}, \PYGZdq{}open\PYGZdq{}: true\PYGZcb{},
                        \PYGZob{}\PYGZdq{}name\PYGZdq{}:\PYGZdq{}GLM/DSS name\PYGZdq{}, \PYGZdq{}open\PYGZdq{}: false\PYGZcb{}]
    \PYGZcb{}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
As can be seen, the required key\sphinxhyphen{}value pairs are identical to those that are selected graphically using the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Viz. By default, only the required key\sphinxhyphen{}value pairs are listed in the viz. The simulation launched in the Viz can be configured using any of the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"model\_creation\_config"}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"model\_state"}} key\sphinxhyphen{}value pairs.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics{{api_usage/images/3.5/config_sim_config}.png}

\subsubsection{application\_config}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.5-Creating-Running-Simulation-API:application_config}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This key is \sphinxstylestrong{optional} and specifies which applications will run during the simulation. The associated value is a list that specifies the name and application\sphinxhyphen{}specific configuration parameters.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYGZdq{}application\PYGZus{}config\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZob{}
        \PYGZdq{}applications\PYGZdq{}: [
                \PYGZob{}
                \PYGZdq{}name\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZdq{}application1\PYGZdq{},
                \PYGZdq{}config\PYGZus{}string\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZdq{}application\PYGZhy{}specific config string\PYGZdq{}
                \PYGZcb{},
                \PYGZob{}
                \PYGZdq{}name\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZdq{}application2\PYGZdq{},
                \PYGZdq{}config\PYGZus{}string\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZdq{}application\PYGZhy{}specific config string\PYGZdq{}
                \PYGZcb{}]
\PYGZcb{}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
As can be seen, the required key\sphinxhyphen{}value pairs are identical to those that are selected graphically using the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Viz. Note: simulations started using the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Viz can only run one app at a time. This is due to the GUI design and not a limitation of the Simulation API.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics{{api_usage/images/3.5/config_app_config}.png}

\subsection{3.2.4. \sphinxstyleliteralintitle{\sphinxupquote{"test\_config":}}}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.5-Creating-Running-Simulation-API:3.2.4.-"test_config":}}

\subsubsection{test\_config}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.5-Creating-Running-Simulation-API:test_config}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This key is \sphinxstylestrong{optional} and specifies whether any pre\sphinxhyphen{}scripted events should be scheduled to occur during the simulation, such as faults, communication outages, and equipment malfunctions. The events use the format of a \sphinxstylestrong{Difference Message}, which will be covered in Lesson 3.XX (to be released soon). The key\sphinxhyphen{}value pairs are

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYGZdq{}test\PYGZus{}config\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZob{}
        \PYGZdq{}events\PYGZdq{}: [\PYGZob{}
            \PYGZdq{}message\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZob{}
                \PYGZdq{}forward\PYGZus{}differences\PYGZdq{}: [
                    \PYGZob{}
                        \PYGZdq{}object\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZdq{}control object mRID\PYGZdq{},
                        \PYGZdq{}attribute\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZdq{}CIM Class Attribute\PYGZdq{},
                        \PYGZdq{}value\PYGZdq{}: number
                    \PYGZcb{}
                ],
                \PYGZdq{}reverse\PYGZus{}differences\PYGZdq{}: [
                    \PYGZob{}
                        \PYGZdq{}object\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZdq{}control object mRID\PYGZdq{},
                        \PYGZdq{}attribute\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZdq{}CIM Class Attribute\PYGZdq{},
                        \PYGZdq{}value\PYGZdq{}: number
                    \PYGZcb{}
                ]
            \PYGZcb{},
            \PYGZdq{}event\PYGZus{}type\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZdq{}ScheduledCommandEvent\PYGZdq{},
            \PYGZdq{}occuredDateTime\PYGZdq{}: epoch time number,
            \PYGZdq{}stopDateTime\PYGZdq{}: epoch time number
        \PYGZcb{}]
\PYGZcb{}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
As can be seen, the required key\sphinxhyphen{}value pairs are identical to those that are selected graphically using the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Viz. The Viz offers the equivalent options to create line faults, communications outages, or upload a custom difference message JSON file.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics{{api_usage/images/3.5/config_test_config}.png}


\subsubsection{3.2.5. \sphinxstyleliteralintitle{\sphinxupquote{service\_configs}}}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.5-Creating-Running-Simulation-API:3.2.5.-service_configs}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This key is used to start a GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D service, such as the Sensor Service, State Estimator, or DNP3 Service. The key\sphinxhyphen{}value pairs for starting the service depend on the particular service and will be covered in the lessons for each GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D service.

\subsection{3.3. Starting the Simulation}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.5-Creating-Running-Simulation-API:3.3.-Starting-the-Simulation}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
To start the simulation, we import the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{gridappsd.simulation}} library, which provides multiple shortcut functions for running and controlling a simulation.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The python dictionary created in the previous section is then passed as an argument to Simulation object. The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{.start\_simulation()}} method is then used to pass the Simulation API call to the GOSS Message Bus and the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The simulation id can be obtained by invoking the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{.simulation\_id}} method.

{
\sphinxsetup{VerbatimColor={named}{nbsphinx-code-bg}}
\sphinxsetup{VerbatimBorderColor={named}{nbsphinx-code-border}}
\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]

\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{gridappsd}\PYG{n+nn}{.}\PYG{n+nn}{simulation} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{Simulation}

\PYG{n}{gapps\PYGZus{}sim} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{GridAPPSD}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{simulation} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{Simulation}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{gapps\PYGZus{}sim}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{run\PYGZus{}config\PYGZus{}123}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{simulation}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{start\PYGZus{}simulation}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{n}{simulation\PYGZus{}id} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{simulation}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{simulation\PYGZus{}id}
\PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{simulation\PYGZus{}id}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
}

\section{4. Pausing, Resuming, or Stopping a Simulation}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.5-Creating-Running-Simulation-API:4.-Pausing,-Resuming,-or-Stopping-a-Simulation}}

\subsection{4.1. Using the \sphinxstyleliteralintitle{\sphinxupquote{gridappsd.simulation}} Python Library}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.5-Creating-Running-Simulation-API:4.1.-Using-the-gridappsd.simulation-Python-Library}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
For simulations that are started using the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{.start\_simulation()}} method of the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{gridappsd.simulation}} python library, it is possible to use the associated methods to pause, resume, and stop simulations.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The library provides the following methods:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{.pause()}} \textendash{} Pause the simulation

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{.resume()}} \textendash{} Resume the simulation

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{.resume\_pause\_at(pause\_in)}} \textendash{} Resume the simulation, and then pause it in so many seconds

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{.stop()}} \textendash{} Stop the simulation

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{.run\_loop()}} \textendash{} Loop the entire simulation until interrupted

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{gridappsd.simulation}} library also provides four types of events that can be registered: ontimestep, onmeasurement, oncomplete, and onstart. To register one of the events call the method \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{.add\_ontimestep\_callback}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{.add\_onmesurement\_callback}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{.add\_oncomplete\_callback}}, or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{.add\_onstart\_callback}} method respectively.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Use of these methods will be covered in a later release of this training notebook.}

\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{api_usage/3.5-Creating-Running-Simulation-API:Table-of-Contents}]{\emph{Return to Top}}}

\section{Introduction to the Simulation API}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.6-Controlling-Simulation-API:Introduction-to-the-Simulation-API}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The Simulation API is used for all actions related to a power system simulation. It is used to start, pause, restart, and stop a simulation from the command line or inside an application. It is all used to subscribe to measurements of equipment (such as line flows, loads, and DG setpoints) and the statuses of switches, capacitors, transformer taps, etc. It is also used to publish equipment control and other simulation input commands.


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\section{Using the Simulation API}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.6-Controlling-Simulation-API:Using-the-Simulation-API}}

\subsection{2.1. Specifying the Topic}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.6-Controlling-Simulation-API:2.1.-Specifying-the-Topic}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
In the previous lessons all the queries passed to other APIs all used static \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{/queue/}} channels to pass API calls to the GOSS message bus and the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform.

\sphinxAtStartPar
However, the Simulation API is used to communicate with a broad range of subscribers. The list of topics covered by the Simulation API cover both static \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{/queue/}} and dynamic \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{/topic/}} communication channel names.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Extreme care is needed to use the correct topic. For a review of GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D topics, see \sphinxhref{Lesson\%201.4.\%20GridAPPS-D\%20Topics.ipynb}{Lesson 1.4.}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The correct topic for each Simulation API call will be provided in the corresponding section for each API task below.


\subsection{2.2. Structure of a Simulation Message}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.6-Controlling-Simulation-API:2.2.-Structure-of-a-Simulation-Message}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Due to the wide range of tasks accomplished by the Simualtion API, there is no single message format that is used across all API Calls.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Each message takes the form of a python dictionary or equivalent JSON script wrapped as a python string.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The structure of each Simulation API call message will be provided in the corresponding section for each API task below.

\sphinxAtStartPar

\subsection{3.2. Obtain Equipment Control mRIDs}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.6-Controlling-Simulation-API:3.2.-Obtain-Equipment-Control-mRIDs}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The mRIDs for controlling equipment are generally the same as those obtained using the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{QUERY\_OBJECT\_TYPES}} key with the PowerGrid Models API, which was covered in \sphinxhref{Lesson\%202.2.\%20PowerGrid\%20Models\%20API\%20-\%20Using\%20JSON\%20Queries.ipynb\#4.4.-Query-for-Object-Dictionary}{Lesson 2.2, Section 4.4}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
However, the control attributes for each class of equipment in CIM use a different naming convention than those for the object types. Below is a list of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"objectType"}} used to query for mRIDs and the associated control attribute used in a difference message for each category of power system equipment:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Switches}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
CIM Class Key: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"objectType": "LoadBreakSwitch"}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Control Attribute: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"attribute": "Switch.open"}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Values: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{1}} is open, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{0}} is closed

\end{itemize}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Capacitor Banks:}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
CIM Class Key: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"objectType": "LinearShuntCompensator"}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Control Attribute: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"attribute": "ShuntCompensator.sections"}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Values: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{0}} is off/open, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{1}} is on/closed

\end{itemize}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Inverter\sphinxhyphen{}based DERs:}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
CIM Class Key: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"objectType": "PowerElectronicsConnection"}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Control Attribute: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"attribute": "PowerElectronicsConnection.p"}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Control Attribute: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"attribute": "PowerElectronicsConnection.q"}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Values: number in Watts or VArs (not kW)

\end{itemize}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Synchronous Rotating (diesel) DGs:}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
CIM Class Key: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"objectType": "SynchronousMachine"}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Control Attribute: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"attribute": "RotatingMachine.p"}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Control Attribute: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"attribute": "RotatingMachine.q"}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Values: number in Watts or VArs (not kW)

\end{itemize}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Regulating Transformer Tap:}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
CIM Class Key: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"objectType": "RatioTapChanger"}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Control Attribute: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"attribute": "TapChanger.step"}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Values: integer value for tap step

\end{itemize}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Note on releases\_2020.09.0: The query for RatioTapChanger is not supported in the PowerGrid Models API at the current time. A custom SPARQL query needs to be done, as illustrated in Lesson 2.3, Section X.XX

\sphinxAtStartPar
The example below shows a query to obtain the correct mRID for switch SW2 in the IEEE 123 node model:

{

\sphinxsetup{VerbatimBorderColor={named}{nbsphinx-code-border}}
\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]

\PYG{n}{message} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{modelId}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{model\PYGZus{}mrid}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{requestType}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{QUERY\PYGZus{}OBJECT\PYGZus{}DICT}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{resultFormat}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{JSON}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{objectType}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{LoadBreakSwitch}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}

\PYG{n}{response\PYGZus{}obj} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{gapps}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{get\PYGZus{}response}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{t}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{REQUEST\PYGZus{}POWERGRID\PYGZus{}DATA}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{message}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{switch\PYGZus{}dict} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{response\PYGZus{}obj}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{data}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{]}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Filter to get mRID for switch SW2:}
\PYG{k}{for} \PYG{n}{index} \PYG{o+ow}{in} \PYG{n}{switch\PYGZus{}dict}\PYG{p}{:}
    \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{n}{index}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{IdentifiedObject.name}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{o}{==} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{sw2}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:}
        \PYG{n}{sw\PYGZus{}mrid} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{index}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{IdentifiedObject.mRID}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{]}

\subsection{3.3. Format of a Difference Message}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.6-Controlling-Simulation-API:3.3.-Format-of-a-Difference-Message}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The general format for a difference message is a python dictionary or equivalent JSON string that specifies the reverse difference and the forward difference, in compliance with the CIM standard:

\sphinxAtStartPar
The \sphinxstylestrong{reverse difference} is the current status / value associated with the control attribute. It is a formatted as a list of dictionary constructs, with each dictionary specifying the equipment mRID associated with the CIM class keys above, the control attribute, and the current value of that control attribute. The list can contain reverse differences for multiple pieces of equipment.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The \sphinxstylestrong{forward difference} is the desired new status / value associated with the control attribute. It is a formatted as a list of dictionary constructs, with each dictionary specifying the equipment mRID associated with the CIM class keys above, the control attribute, and the current value of that control attribute. The list can contain foward differences for multiple pieces of equipment.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
message = \PYGZob{}
  \PYGZdq{}command\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZdq{}update\PYGZdq{},
  \PYGZdq{}input\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZob{}
      \PYGZdq{}simulation\PYGZus{}id\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZdq{}simulation id as string\PYGZdq{},
      \PYGZdq{}message\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZob{}
          \PYGZdq{}timestamp\PYGZdq{}: epoch time number,
          \PYGZdq{}difference\PYGZus{}mrid\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZdq{}optional unique mRID for command logs\PYGZdq{},
          \PYGZdq{}reverse\PYGZus{}differences\PYGZdq{}: [\PYGZob{}

                  \PYGZdq{}object\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZdq{}first equipment mRID\PYGZdq{},
                  \PYGZdq{}attribute\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZdq{}control attribute\PYGZdq{},
                  \PYGZdq{}value\PYGZdq{}: current value
              \PYGZcb{},
              \PYGZob{}

                  \PYGZdq{}object\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZdq{}second equipment mRID\PYGZdq{},
                  \PYGZdq{}attribute\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZdq{}control attribute\PYGZdq{},
                  \PYGZdq{}value\PYGZdq{}: current value
              \PYGZcb{}
          ],
          \PYGZdq{}forward\PYGZus{}differences\PYGZdq{}: [\PYGZob{}

                  \PYGZdq{}object\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZdq{}first equipment mRID\PYGZdq{},
                  \PYGZdq{}attribute\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZdq{}control attribute\PYGZdq{},
                  \PYGZdq{}value\PYGZdq{}: new value
              \PYGZcb{},
              \PYGZob{}

                  \PYGZdq{}object\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZdq{}second equipment mRID\PYGZdq{},
                  \PYGZdq{}attribute\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZdq{}control attribute\PYGZdq{},
                  \PYGZdq{}value\PYGZdq{}: new value
              \PYGZcb{}
              ]
              \PYGZcb{}
      \PYGZcb{}
\PYGZcb{}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Note: The GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D platform does not validate whether \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"reverse\_differences":}} has the correct equipment control values for the current time. It is used just for compliance with the CIM standard.

\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{api_usage/3.6-Controlling-Simulation-API:Table-of-Contents}]{\emph{Return to Top}}}


\subsection{3.4. Using GridAPPSD\sphinxhyphen{}Python \sphinxstyleliteralintitle{\sphinxupquote{DifferenceBuilder}}}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.6-Controlling-Simulation-API:3.4.-Using-GridAPPSD-Python-DifferenceBuilder}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{DifferenceBuilder}} class is a GridAPPSD\sphinxhyphen{}Python tool that can be used to automatically build the difference message with correct formatting.

\sphinxAtStartPar
First import DifferenceBuilder from the GridAPPSD\sphinxhyphen{}Python Library and create an object that will be used to create the desired difference messages.

{
\sphinxsetup{VerbatimColor={named}{nbsphinx-code-bg}}
\sphinxsetup{VerbatimBorderColor={named}{nbsphinx-code-border}}
\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\llap{\color{nbsphinxin}[ ]:\,\hspace{\fboxrule}\hspace{\fboxsep}}\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{gridappsd} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{DifferenceBuilder}

\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}diff\PYGZus{}build} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{DifferenceBuilder}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{viz\PYGZus{}simulation\PYGZus{}id}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
}

\sphinxAtStartPar
We then use two methods associated with the DifferenceBuilder object: * \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{.add\_difference(self, object\_mrid, control\_attribute, new\_value, old\_value)}} \textendash{} Generates a correctly formatted difference message. * \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{.get\_message()}} \textendash{} Saves the message as a python dictionary that can be published using gapps.send()

{
\sphinxsetup{VerbatimColor={named}{nbsphinx-code-bg}}
\sphinxsetup{VerbatimBorderColor={named}{nbsphinx-code-border}}
\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\llap{\color{nbsphinxin}[ ]:\,\hspace{\fboxrule}\hspace{\fboxsep}}\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}diff\PYGZus{}build}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{add\PYGZus{}difference}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{sw\PYGZus{}mrid}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{Switch.open}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Open switch given by sw\PYGZus{}mrid}

\PYG{n}{message} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}diff\PYGZus{}build}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{get\PYGZus{}message}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The difference message is then published to the GOSS Message Bus and the Simulation API using the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{.send()}} method associated with the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D connection object.

{
\sphinxsetup{VerbatimColor={named}{nbsphinx-code-bg}}
\sphinxsetup{VerbatimBorderColor={named}{nbsphinx-code-border}}
\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\llap{\color{nbsphinxin}[ ]:\,\hspace{\fboxrule}\hspace{\fboxsep}}\PYG{n}{gapps}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{send}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{input\PYGZus{}topic}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{message}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
}

\sphinxAtStartPar

\section{4.2. Obtain Measurement mRIDs}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.6-Controlling-Simulation-API:4.2.-Obtain-Measurement-mRIDs}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The second step is to obtain the correct measurement mRIDs using the PowerGrid Models API, which was covered in \sphinxhref{Lesson\%202.2.\%20PowerGrid\%20Models\%20API\%20-\%20Using\%20JSON\%20Queries.ipynb\#5.2.-Querying-for-Measurements}{Lesson 2.2, Section 5.2}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
These mRIDs will be needed to parse the simulation output message and filter it to just the desired set of measurements.

\sphinxAtStartPar
For the example below, we will be interested in only the measurement associated with switches, so we will use the PowerGrid Models API to query for the set of measurements associated with the CIM Class \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LoadBreakSwitch}}. We then will filter those values to just the mRIDs associated with each type of measurement.

{

\sphinxsetup{VerbatimBorderColor={named}{nbsphinx-code-border}}
\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]

\PYG{n}{message} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{modelId}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{model\PYGZus{}mrid}\PYG{p}{,}

    \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{resultFormat}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{JSON}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{objectType}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{LoadBreakSwitch}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}

\PYG{n}{response\PYGZus{}obj} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{gapps}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{get\PYGZus{}response}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{t}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{REQUEST\PYGZus{}POWERGRID\PYGZus{}DATA}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{message}\PYG{p}{)}

\section{4.3. Structure of Simulation Output Message}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.6-Controlling-Simulation-API:4.3.-Structure-of-Simulation-Output-Message}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The general format of the messages received by the Simulation API is a python dictionary with the following key\sphinxhyphen{}value pairs:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYGZob{}         KEY                    VALUE
    \PYGZdq{}simulation\PYGZus{}id\PYGZdq{} :           string,
    \PYGZdq{}message\PYGZdq{} : \PYGZob{}
        \PYGZdq{}timestamp\PYGZdq{} :           epoch time number,
        \PYGZdq{}measurements\PYGZdq{} : \PYGZob{}
            \PYGZdq{}meas mrid 1\PYGZdq{}:\PYGZob{}
                                \PYGZdq{}measurement\PYGZus{}mrid\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZdq{}meas mrid 1\PYGZdq{}
                                \PYGZdq{}magnitude\PYGZdq{}: number,
                                \PYGZdq{}angle\PYGZdq{}: number \PYGZcb{},
            \PYGZdq{}meas mrid 2\PYGZdq{}:\PYGZob{}
                                \PYGZdq{}measurement\PYGZus{}mrid\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZdq{}meas mrid 2\PYGZdq{}
                                \PYGZdq{}magnitude\PYGZdq{}: number,
                                \PYGZdq{}angle\PYGZdq{}: number \PYGZcb{},
                           .
                           .
                           .
            \PYGZdq{}meas mrid n\PYGZdq{}:\PYGZob{}
                                \PYGZdq{}measurement\PYGZus{}mrid\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZdq{}meas mrid n\PYGZdq{}
                                \PYGZdq{}magnitude\PYGZdq{}: number,
                                \PYGZdq{}angle\PYGZdq{}: number \PYGZcb{},
    \PYGZcb{}
\PYGZcb{}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
It is the responsibility of the application to parse and filter the message to obtain the desired measurements.

\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{api_usage/3.6-Controlling-Simulation-API:Table-of-Contents}]{\emph{Return to Top}}}


\section{4.4. Subscribe using a Function Definition}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.6-Controlling-Simulation-API:4.4.-Subscribe-using-a-Function-Definition}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The first approach used to subscribe to measurements is to define a function with the correct set of arguments that is then passed to the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{.subscribe()}} method associated with the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{GridAPPPSD()}} object.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The function does not require a specific name, and is somewhat easier to define and use. However, the arguments of the function need to be named correctly for the GridAPPSD\sphinxhyphen{}Python library to process the simulation output correctly.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The format for the function definition is

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
def mySubscribeFunction(header, message):
    \PYGZsh{} do something when receive a message
    \PYGZsh{} parse to get measurments
    \PYGZsh{} do something else
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
That function handle is then passed as an argument to the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{.subscribe(topic, function\_handle)}} method:

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Note on Jupyter Notebook environment:} In the examples below, the Jupyter Notebook environment does not update definitions of the subscription object or function definitions. As a result, it is necessary to restart the notebook kernel. The gapps connection object definition is included again for convenience in executing the notebook code blocks

\section{4.5. Subscribe using a Class Definition}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.6-Controlling-Simulation-API:4.5.-Subscribe-using-a-Class-Definition}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The second approach used to subscribe to measurements is to define a class with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\_\_init\_\_}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{on\_message}} methods.

\sphinxAtStartPar
These methods specify 1) how your app would initialize variables and attributes at the start of the simulation and 2) how your app behaves when it receives various messages.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{IMPORTANT!} The GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform use the exact names and syntax for the methods:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\_\_init\_\_(self, simulation\_id, gapps\_object, optional\_objects)}} \textendash{} This method requires the simulation\_id and GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D connection object. It is also possible add other user\sphinxhyphen{}defined arguments, such as measurement mRIDs or other information required by your application.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{on\_message(self, headers, message)}} \textendash{} This method allows the class to subscribe to simulation measurements. It also contains the core behavior of your application and how it responds to each type of message.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
It is also possible to use the same class definition to subscribe to other topics, such as Simulation Logs. This is done by creating additional user\sphinxhyphen{}defined methods and then passing those methods to the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{.subcribe()}} method associated with the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D connection object. An example of how this is done is provided for subcribing to simulation logs in \sphinxhref{Lesson\%202.8.\%20Logging\%20API.ipynb\#4.3.-Create-Subscription-Method}{Lesson 2.8, Section 4.3}


\subsection{\sphinxstyleemphasis{This class definition is also the core code block of your application!}}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.6-Controlling-Simulation-API:This-class-definition-is-also-the-core-code-block-of-your-application!}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The structure of the class is

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
class YourSimulationClassName(object):
    \PYGZsh{} Your documentation text here on what app does

    def \PYGZus{}\PYGZus{}init\PYGZus{}\PYGZus{}(self, simulation\PYGZus{}id, gapps\PYGZus{}obj, meas\PYGZus{}obj, your\PYGZus{}obj):
        \PYGZsh{} Instantiate class with specific initial state

        \PYGZsh{} Attributes required by Simulation API
        self.\PYGZus{}gapps = gapps\PYGZus{}obj
        self.\PYGZus{}simulation\PYGZus{}id = simulation\PYGZus{}id

        \PYGZsh{} Attributes to publish difference measurements
        self.diff = DifferenceBuilder(simulation\PYGZus{}id)

        \PYGZsh{} Custom attributes for measurements, custom info
        self.meas\PYGZus{}mrid = meas\PYGZus{}obj
        self.your\PYGZus{}attribute1 = your\PYGZus{}obj[\PYGZdq{}key1\PYGZdq{}]
        self.your\PYGZus{}attribute2 = your\PYGZus{}obj[\PYGZdq{}key2\PYGZdq{}]

    def on\PYGZus{}message(self, headers, message):
        \PYGZsh{} What app should do when it receives a subscription message

        variable1 = message[\PYGZdq{}message\PYGZdq{}][\PYGZdq{}key1\PYGZdq{}]
        variable2 = message[\PYGZdq{}message\PYGZdq{}][\PYGZdq{}key2\PYGZdq{}]

        \PYGZsh{} Insert your custom app behavior here
        if variable1 == foo:
            bar = my\PYGZus{}optimization\PYGZus{}result

        \PYGZsh{} Insert your custom equipment commands here
        if variable2 == bar:
            self.diff.add\PYGZus{}difference(object\PYGZus{}mrid, control\PYGZus{}attribute, new\PYGZus{}value, old\PYGZus{}value)

    def my\PYGZus{}custom\PYGZus{}method\PYGZus{}1(self, headers, message):
        \PYGZsh{} Use extra methods to subscribe to other topics, such as simulation logs
        variable1 = message[\PYGZdq{}key1\PYGZdq{}]
        variable2 = message[\PYGZdq{}key2\PYGZdq{}]

    def my\PYGZus{}custom\PYGZus{}method\PYGZus{}2(self, param1, param2):
        \PYGZsh{} Use extra methods as desired
        variable1 = foo
        variable2 = bar
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

        \PYG{k}{for} \PYG{n}{index} \PYG{o+ow}{in} \PYG{n}{Pos\PYGZus{}obj}\PYG{p}{:}
            \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{n}{index}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{measid}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{o+ow}{in} \PYG{n}{meas\PYGZus{}value}\PYG{p}{:}
                \PYG{n}{mrid} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{index}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{measid}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{]}
                \PYG{n}{power} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{meas\PYGZus{}value}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{mrid}\PYG{p}{]}
                \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{n}{power}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{value}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{o}{==} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{:}
                    \PYG{n}{open\PYGZus{}switches}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{append}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{index}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{eqname}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{)}

        \PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{............}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{Number of open switches at time}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{timestamp}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{ is }\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nb}{len}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{set}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{open\PYGZus{}switches}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
}

\sphinxAtStartPar
After defining the class, we create an object that will be passed to the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{.subscribe(topic, object)}} method associated with the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D connection object:

{
\sphinxsetup{VerbatimColor={named}{nbsphinx-code-bg}}
\sphinxsetup{VerbatimBorderColor={named}{nbsphinx-code-border}}
\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\llap{\color{nbsphinxin}[ ]:\,\hspace{\fboxrule}\hspace{\fboxsep}}\PYG{n}{demo\PYGZus{}obj} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{ApplicationDemo}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{viz\PYGZus{}simulation\PYGZus{}id}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{gapps}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{measurements\PYGZus{}obj}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{n}{gapps}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{subscribe}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{subscribe\PYGZus{}topic}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{demo\PYGZus{}obj}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} only measurements simulation\PYGZus{}output\PYGZus{}topic}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
}

\sphinxAtStartPar
If we wish to subscribe to an additional topic (such as the Simulation Logs, a side communication channel between two different applications, or a communication with a particular service), we can define an additional method in the class (such as my\_custom\_method\_1 in the pseudo\sphinxhyphen{}code above) and then pass it to to the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{.subscribe(topic, object.method)}} method associated with the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D connection object:

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{gapps.subscribe(other\_topic, demo\_obj.my\_custom\_method\_1)}}
