\section{4.6. Using the GridAPPSD\sphinxhyphen{}Python Simulation Library Shortcuts}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.6-Controlling-Simulation-API:4.6.-Using-the-GridAPPSD-Python-Simulation-Library-Shortcuts}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Release\_2020.09.0 Note:} If the simulation was started from within the application by importing and using the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Simulation}} library in GridAPPSD\sphinxhyphen{}Python (as shown in \sphinxhref{Lesson\%202.5.\%20Simulation\%20API\%20-\%20Running\%20Simulations.ipynb\#3.3.-Starting-the-Simulation}{Lesson 2.5, Section 3.3}), then several shortcut functions can be used. These methods currently cannot interact with a simulation started from the Viz. This functionality will be added in a future release.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The GridAPPSD\sphinxhyphen{}Python library provides several shortcut methods can be used by importing the Simulation library for GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D:

{
\sphinxsetup{VerbatimColor={named}{nbsphinx-code-bg}}
\sphinxsetup{VerbatimBorderColor={named}{nbsphinx-code-border}}
\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\llap{\color{nbsphinxin}[ ]:\,\hspace{\fboxrule}\hspace{\fboxsep}}\PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{json}
\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{gridappsd} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{GridAPPSD}
\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{gridappsd}\PYG{n+nn}{.}\PYG{n+nn}{simulation} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{Simulation}

\PYG{n}{gapps} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{GridAPPSD}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Create GridAPPS\PYGZhy{}D connection object}

\PYG{n}{run123\PYGZus{}config} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{json}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{load}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{open}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{Run123NodeFileSimAPI.json}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Pull simulation config from saved file}

\PYG{n}{simulation\PYGZus{}obj} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{Simulation}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{gapps}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{run123\PYGZus{}config}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Create Simulation object}

\PYG{n}{simulation\PYGZus{}obj}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{start\PYGZus{}simulation}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Start Simulation}

\PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{Successfully started simulation with simulation\PYGZus{}id: }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{simulation\PYGZus{}obj}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{simulation\PYGZus{}id}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The Simulation library provides four methods that can be used to define how the platform interacts with the simulation:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{.add\_ontimestep\_callback(myfunction1)}} \textendash{} Run the desired function on each timestep

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{.add\_onmesurement\_callback(myfunction2)}} \textendash{} Run the desired function when a measurement is received. \sphinxstylestrong{Note on releases\_2020.09.0: method name is misspelled in the library definition!!}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{.add\_oncomplete\_callback(myfunction3)}} \textendash{} Run the desired function when simulation is

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{.add\_onstart\_callback(myfunction4)}} \textendash{} Run desired function when simulation is started

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Note that the measurement callback method returns just the measurements and timestamps without any of the message formatting used in the messages received by using the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{gapps.subscribe(output\_topic, object)}} approach.

\sphinxAtStartPar
To use use these methods, we define a set of functions that determine the behavior of the application for each of the four types of callbacks listed above:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
def onmeasurement(sim, timestamp, measurements):
    \PYGZsh{} Do something when app receives a measurement
    \PYGZsh{} Insert your custom app behavior here
    if measurements[object\PYGZus{}mrid] == foo:
        bar = my\PYGZus{}optimization\PYGZus{}result

def oncomplete(sim):
    \PYGZsh{} Do something when simulation is complete
    \PYGZsh{} example: delete all variables, close files
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Note on Jupyter Notebook environment:} In the examples below, the Jupyter Notebook environment does not update definitions of the subscription object or function definitions. \section{4.7. Comparison of Approaches}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.6-Controlling-Simulation-API:4.7.-Comparison-of-Approaches}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Each approach has its advantages and disadvantages.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The function\sphinxhyphen{}based approach is simpler and easier to implement. However, any parameters obtained from other APIs or methods to be used inside the function currently need to be defined as global variables.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The class\sphinxhyphen{}based approach is more complex, but also more powerful. It provides greater flexibility in creating additional methods, arguments, etc.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The Simulation Library\sphinxhyphen{}based approach is easiest, but only works currently for simulations started using the simulation\_obj.start\_simulation() method.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The choice of which approach is used depends on the personal preferences of the application developer.

\sphinxAtStartPar

\chapter{Timeseries API}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.7-Using-the-Timeseries-API:Timeseries-API}}\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.7-Using-the-Timeseries-API::doc}}

\section{Introduction to the Timeseries API}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.7-Using-the-Timeseries-API:Introduction-to-the-Timeseries-API}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The Timeseries API is used to query the Influx Database, which stores measurement data from simulations. The API calls can be used to * obtain weather data * obtain measurements from simuation data using measurement mRIDs * obtain equipments commands and other simulation input data * obtain simulated field data from the Sensor Service


\section{API Syntax Overview}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.7-Using-the-Timeseries-API:API-Syntax-Overview}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Application passes query to GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform}

\sphinxAtStartPar
First, the application creates a query message for requesting information about the desired power system components in the format of a JSON string or equivalant Python dictionary object. The syntax of this message is explained in detail below.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The query is sent using the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{gapps.get\_response(topic, message)}} method on the Timeseries queue channel with a response expected back from the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D platform within the specified timeout period.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The application then passes the query through the Timeseries API to the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform, which publishes it to the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{goss.gridappsd.process.request.data.timeseries}} queue channel on the GOSS Message Bus. If the app is authenticated and authorized to pass queries, the query message is delivered to the Data Managers, which obtain the desired information from the Timeseries Influx Database.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform responds to Application query}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The Data Managers then publish the response from the Timeseries Influx Database to the appropriate queue channel. The Timeseries API then returns the desired information back to the application as a JSON message or equivalant Python dictionary object.


\subsection{API Communication Channel}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.7-Using-the-Timeseries-API:API-Communication-Channel}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
API calls to the timeseries databases use a static \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{/queue/}} channel, which was covered in \sphinxhref{Lesson\%201.4.\%20GridAPPS-D\%20Topics.ipynb}{Lesson 1.4}. The topic can be specified as a text string or by importing the topics library:

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Text String:} The topic can be specified as a static string:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{topic = "goss.gridappsd.process.request.data.timeseries"}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{gapps.get\_response(topic, message)}}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{GridAPPSD\sphinxhyphen{}Python Library Method:} The correct topic can also be imported from the GridAPPSD\sphinxhyphen{}Python topics library:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{from gridappsd import topics as t}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{gapps.get\_response(t.TIMESERIES, message)}}

\end{itemize}


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\section{2.2. Query Message Structure}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.7-Using-the-Timeseries-API:2.2.-Query-Message-Structure}}

\subsection{Structure of a Query Message}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.7-Using-the-Timeseries-API:Structure-of-a-Query-Message}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Queries passed to Timeseries API are formatted as python dictionaries or equivalent JSON scripts wrapped as a python string.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The accepted set of key\sphinxhyphen{}value pairs for the Timeseries API query message is

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
message = \PYGZdq{}\PYGZdq{}\PYGZdq{}
\PYGZob{}
    \PYGZdq{}queryMeasurement\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZdq{}INSERT QUERY HERE\PYGZdq{},
    \PYGZdq{}queryFilter\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZob{}\PYGZdq{}key1\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZdq{}value1\PYGZdq{}
                   \PYGZdq{}key2\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZdq{}value2\PYGZdq{}\PYGZcb{},
    \PYGZdq{}responseFormat\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZdq{}JSON\PYGZdq{}
\PYGZcb{}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The components of the message are as follows:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"queryMeasurement":}} \textendash{} Specifies the type of measurement being requested. Allowed queryMeasurement values are listed in the next section.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"queryFilter":}} \textendash{} Filters the measurements to just the set values desired by the application. The set of allowed values depends on the value associated with queryMeasurement.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"responseFormat":}} \textendash{} Specifies the format of the response, can be \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"JSON"}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"CSV"}}, or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"XML"}}. (CAUTION: the Timeseries API uses the key \sphinxstyleemphasis{reponseFormat}, while the PowerGridModel API uses the key \sphinxstyleemphasis{resultFormat}. Using the wrong key for either API will result in a java.lang error.)

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The usage of each of these message components are explained in detail with code block examples below.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Important}: Be sure to pay attention to placement of commas ( \sphinxstylestrong{,} ) at the end of each line. Commas are placed at the end of each line \sphinxstyleemphasis{except} the last line. Incorrect comma placement will result in a JsonSyntaxException.

\sphinxAtStartPar
All of the queries are passed to the Timeseries API using the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{.get\_response(topic, message)}} method for the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D platform connection variable.


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\section{2.3. Specifying the \sphinxstyleliteralintitle{\sphinxupquote{queryMeasurement}} value}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.7-Using-the-Timeseries-API:2.3.-Specifying-the-queryMeasurement-value}}

\subsection{Specifying the queryMeasurement value}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.7-Using-the-Timeseries-API:Specifying-the-queryMeasurement-value}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Below are the allowable values associated with the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{queryMeasurement}} key, which are used to specify the type of data requested by each query. Executable code block examples are provided for each of the requests in the subsections below.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"queryMeasurement": "weather"}} \textendash{} {\hyperref[\detokenize{api_usage/3.7-Using-the-Timeseries-API:3.1.-Query-for-Weather-Data}]{\emph{Query for weather data}}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"queryMeasurement": "simulation"}} \textendash{} {\hyperref[\detokenize{api_usage/3.7-Using-the-Timeseries-API:3.2.-Query-for-Simulation-Output-Data}]{\emph{Query for simulation output data}}} and {\hyperref[\detokenize{api_usage/3.7-Using-the-Timeseries-API:3.3.-Query-for-Simulation-Input-Data}]{\emph{query for simulation intput data}}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"queryMeasurement": "gridappsd\sphinxhyphen{}sensor\sphinxhyphen{}simulator"}} \textendash{} {\hyperref[\detokenize{api_usage/3.7-Using-the-Timeseries-API:3.4.-Query-for-Sensor-Service-Data}]{\emph{Query for sensor service data}}}

\end{itemize}

\subsection{Querying for Weather Data}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.7-Using-the-Timeseries-API:Querying-for-Weather-Data}}

\subsubsection{Interpreting GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Weather Data}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.7-Using-the-Timeseries-API:Interpreting-GridAPPS-D-Weather-Data}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The weather data is based on exported data collected from the Solar Radiation Research Laboratory (39.74N,105.18W,1829 meter elevation) January \sphinxhyphen{} December 2013. The original dataset was based in Mountain Standard Time (MST).

\sphinxAtStartPar

\subsubsection{Querying Weather Data}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.7-Using-the-Timeseries-API:Querying-Weather-Data}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D contains one year of weather data (details given in next subsection), which can be obtained with the following query

\sphinxAtStartPar
Measurement request key\sphinxhyphen{}value pair:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"queryMeasurement": "weather"}}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Allowed key\sphinxhyphen{}value pairs for \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{queryFilter}}:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYGZdq{}queryFilter\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZob{}    KEY                   VALUE
                \PYGZdq{}startTime\PYGZdq{}:            epoch time number,
                \PYGZdq{}endTime\PYGZdq{}:              epoch time number,
                \PYGZdq{}AvgWindDirection\PYGZdq{}:     number,
                \PYGZdq{}AvgWindSpeed\PYGZdq{}:         number,
                \PYGZdq{}Diffuse\PYGZdq{}:              number,
                \PYGZdq{}DirectCH1\PYGZdq{}:            number,
                \PYGZdq{}GlobalCM22\PYGZdq{}:           number,
                \PYGZdq{}MST\PYGZdq{}:                  number,
                \PYGZdq{}TowerDryBulbTemp\PYGZdq{}:     number,
                \PYGZdq{}TowerRH\PYGZdq{}:              number,
                \PYGZdq{}lat\PYGZdq{}:                  string,
                \PYGZdq{}long\PYGZdq{}:                 string,
                \PYGZdq{}place\PYGZdq{}:                string \PYGZcb{}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Not all of the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{queryFilter}} key\sphinxhyphen{}value pairs need to be used. These are filters that can be used to restrict the returned data to particular values.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Note:} The Timeseries API currently does not support querying for a range of values (e.g. all data for temperature betweeen 25 and 30C). This functionality will be added in a future release. Queries are currently limited to a single value.

\subsection{Query for Simulation Output Data}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.7-Using-the-Timeseries-API:Query-for-Simulation-Output-Data}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
All of the measurement output from a simulation is stored in the Influx Database and can be queried with the Timeseries API

\sphinxAtStartPar
Measurement request key\sphinxhyphen{}value pair:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"queryMeasurement": "simulation"}}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Allowed key\sphinxhyphen{}value pairs for \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{queryFilter}} for output data

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYGZdq{}queryFilter\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZob{}    KEY                         VALUE
                \PYGZdq{}startTime\PYGZdq{}:                    epoch time number ,
                \PYGZdq{}endTime\PYGZdq{}:                      epoch time number ,
                \PYGZdq{}measurement\PYGZus{}mrid\PYGZdq{}:             string OR [array of string values] ,
                \PYGZdq{}simulation\PYGZus{}id\PYGZdq{}:                numeric string ,
                \PYGZdq{}hasSimulationMessageType\PYGZdq{}:     \PYGZdq{}OUTPUT\PYGZdq{} OR \PYGZdq{}INPUT\PYGZdq{} ,
                \PYGZdq{}angle\PYGZdq{}:                        number ,
                \PYGZdq{}magnitude\PYGZdq{}:                    number \PYGZcb{}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar

\subsubsection{Using the Sensor Service}
\label{\detokenize{api_usage/3.7-Using-the-Timeseries-API:Using-the-Sensor-Service}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Sensor Service simulates the noise and packet losses of real field device measurements based upon the magnitude of “prestine” simulated values from the GridLab\sphinxhyphen{}D simulation. This service has been specifically designed to work within the gridappsd platform container. The GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D platform will start the service when it is specified as a dependency of an application or when a service configuration is specified within the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Visualization.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Python Application Usage:} The python application using this service should require gridappsd\sphinxhyphen{}sensor\sphinxhyphen{}simulator as a requirement. In addition, the following python code shows how to get the correct topic for the service.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Service Configuration:} The sensor\sphinxhyphen{}config in the above image shows an example of how to configure a portion of the system to have sensor output. Each mrid (such as \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\_99db0dc7\sphinxhyphen{}ccda\sphinxhyphen{}4ed5\sphinxhyphen{}a772\sphinxhyphen{}a7db362e9818}}) will be monitored by this service and either use the default values or use the specified values during the service runtime.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The general format for the Sensor Service configuration message is

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYGZob{}
   \PYGZdq{}\PYGZus{}99db0dc7\PYGZhy{}ccda\PYGZhy{}4ed5\PYGZhy{}a772\PYGZhy{}a7db362e9818\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZob{}
      \PYGZdq{}nominal\PYGZhy{}value\PYGZdq{}: 100,
      \PYGZdq{}perunit\PYGZhy{}confidence\PYGZhy{}band\PYGZdq{}: 0.01,
      \PYGZdq{}aggregation\PYGZhy{}interval\PYGZdq{}: 30,
      \PYGZdq{}perunit\PYGZhy{}drop\PYGZhy{}rate\PYGZdq{}: 0.01
   \PYGZcb{},
   \PYGZdq{}\PYGZus{}ee65ee31\PYGZhy{}a900\PYGZhy{}4f98\PYGZhy{}bf57\PYGZhy{}e752be924c4d\PYGZdq{}:\PYGZob{}\PYGZcb{},
   \PYGZdq{}\PYGZus{}f2673c22\PYGZhy{}654b\PYGZhy{}452a\PYGZhy{}8297\PYGZhy{}45dae11b1e14\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZob{}\PYGZcb{}
\PYGZcb{}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The other options for the service are:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"default\sphinxhyphen{}perunit\sphinxhyphen{}confidence\sphinxhyphen{}band"}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"default\sphinxhyphen{}aggregation\sphinxhyphen{}interval"}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"default\sphinxhyphen{}perunit\sphinxhyphen{}drop\sphinxhyphen{}rate"}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"passthrough\sphinxhyphen{}if\sphinxhyphen{}not\sphinxhyphen{}specified"}}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
These options will be used when not specified within the sensor\sphinxhyphen{}config block.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Note: Currently the nominal\sphinxhyphen{}value is not looked up from the database. At this time services aren’t able to tell the platform when they are “ready”. This will be implemented in the near future and then all of the nominal\sphinxhyphen{}values will be queried from the database.

\sphinxAtStartPar
A complete example of Sensor Service configuration is available in the sample python script \sphinxurl{Run123NodeSensorServiceDemo.py} for three measurements in the IEEE 123 Node Model generated over a two minute simulation.

\chapter{Resilient Restoration (WSU)}
\label{\detokenize{applications/restoration-WSU/source/index:resilient-restoration-wsu}}\label{\detokenize{applications/restoration-WSU/source/index::doc}}
\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics[width=1212\sphinxpxdimen,height=718\sphinxpxdimen]{{website}.PNG}

\sphinxAtStartPar
An advanced distribution management system (ADMS) supports grid management and decision support applications to address the growing operational challenges faced by the modern electric power distribution systems while ensuring reliable and resilient operations. In this document, we describe the development of the proposed fault location, isolation, and restoration (FLISR) and it’s integration with an open\sphinxhyphen{}source standards\sphinxhyphen{}based platform for ADMS application development viz. GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D, developed by Pacific Northwest National Laboratory (PNNL).

\sphinxAtStartPar
Essentially, an ADMS allows for applications that can readily access information from various systems including, but not limited to Distributed Energy Resource Management System (DERMS), Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA), Outage Management Systems (OMS), Graphical Information Management Systems (GIS), and Advanced Metering Infrastructure (AMI). Recently, researchers at PNNL developed an open\sphinxhyphen{}source ADMS application development platform, GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D, that provides an open\sphinxhyphen{}source, extensible application development environment. These new developments call for research not only on advanced applications for the distribution systems that leverage the interoperability of the ADMS platform but also on providing a proof\sphinxhyphen{}of\sphinxhyphen{}concept for integrating such advanced applications into the future ADMS.


\section{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{applications/restoration-WSU/source/overview/index:overview}}\label{\detokenize{applications/restoration-WSU/source/overview/index::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The electric power distribution system is facing a magnitude of challenges due to an increase in severe weather events leading to widespread network outages, coupled with the growing regulatory requirements for increased reliability and resilience, reduced carbon emissions, and growing distributed energy resources (DER) penetrations. The Fault Location Isolation and Service Restoration (FLISR) is one of the most critical applications currently being adopted by the majority of distribution companies and made available by most ADMS vendors to manage system outages \sphinxcite{applications/restoration-WSU/source/overview/index:cit1}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
This report documents the restoration application developed by Washington State University (WSU) and demonstrate its functionality by integrating it with a standards\sphinxhyphen{}based open\sphinxhyphen{}source platform \textendash{} \sphinxhref{https://gridappsd.readthedocs.io/en/master/}{GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D}, developed by the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory (PNNL).


\subsection{Application Architecture}
\label{\detokenize{applications/restoration-WSU/source/overview/index:application-architecture}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The proposed restoration application can be implemented in an advanced distribution management system (ADMS) as shown in Figure 1. Figure shows the overall architecture of a modern DMS with integration of several subsystems such as customer information system (CIS), geographical information system (GIS), interactive voice response (IVR), advanced metering infrastructure (AMI), SCADA and flowchart of the proposed DSR framework. Once a power outage happens, three specific tasks are performed in the DMS to restore the power to out\sphinxhyphen{}of\sphinxhyphen{}service area:
\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Information Collection}: To monitor the power distribution system condition and gather resource information.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Information Processing}: For system model identification and fault location.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Service Restoration}: To find the candidate switch and generate DER control signals for circuit reconfiguration.

\end{enumerate}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=2008\sphinxpxdimen,height=740\sphinxpxdimen]{{flowchart}.PNG}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleemphasis{Figure 1: Architecture of a modern distribution management system and flowchart of the proposed restoration application.}


\subsection{Leveraging the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Platform}
\label{\detokenize{applications/restoration-WSU/source/overview/index:leveraging-the-gridapps-d-platform}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The realization of an autonomous restoration application requires a measurement and control environment that provides post\sphinxhyphen{}fault situational awareness and the ability to remotely deploy the decisions for restoration.
GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D is an open\sphinxhyphen{}source, standards\sphinxhyphen{}based platform designed to support the development of advanced, data\sphinxhyphen{}driven distribution system operation and/or planning applications that take advantage of the data\sphinxhyphen{}rich environment expected in modernized electric power distribution systems with smart grid technologies.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Figure 2 shows a schematic for the interaction and communication among the distribution system operational sub\sphinxhyphen{}system for the proposed restoration application. The platform is typically integrated with other related data and decision\sphinxhyphen{}support systems/subsystems such as DERMS, SCADA, OMS, GIS, AMI, CIS to: a) monitor the distribution system conditions, b) obtain the DER availability and operating conditions, and c) for load estimation and control.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=2175\sphinxpxdimen,height=633\sphinxpxdimen]{{archi}.PNG}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleemphasis{Figure 2: Integration of proposed application to the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D platform. GOSS/FNCS is the PNNL’s platform for data exchange among subsystems. GOSS: GridOPTICS Software System; FNCS: Framework for network simulation.}


\subsection{Definition of Terms}
\label{\detokenize{applications/restoration-WSU/source/overview/index:definition-of-terms}}\label{\detokenize{applications/restoration-WSU/source/overview/index:definitions}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Fault \sphinxhyphen{} Opening of normally\sphinxhyphen{}closed switch in response to any abnormal operating condition on its downstream.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Platform \sphinxhyphen{} Refers to GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D platform.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Simulation \sphinxhyphen{} A real world distribution system currently done by GridLAB\sphinxhyphen{}D

\sphinxAtStartPar
Simulator \sphinxhyphen{} In current release GridLAB\sphinxhyphen{}D serves as the simulator.

\sphinxAtStartPar
CPLEX \sphinxhyphen{} A commercial optimization software package for solving the large\sphinxhyphen{}scale optimization problem

\sphinxAtStartPar
GridLAB\sphinxhyphen{}D \sphinxhyphen{} GridLAB\sphinxhyphen{}D is a distribution level powerflow simulator. It acts as the real world distribution system in GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Power System Model \sphinxhyphen{} A modified IEEE 8500\sphinxhyphen{}node feeder is used as the test case

image: wsu\PYGZhy{}restoration\PYGZhy{}app

\section{Data Model}
\label{\detokenize{applications/restoration-WSU/source/data_model/index:data-model}}\label{\detokenize{applications/restoration-WSU/source/data_model/index::doc}}

\subsection{IEEE 8500\sphinxhyphen{}Node Test Feeder}
\label{\detokenize{applications/restoration-WSU/source/data_model/index:ieee-8500-node-test-feeder}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
An IEEE Working Group specified a set of distribution test circuits \sphinxcite{applications/restoration-WSU/source/overview/index:cit9} and we have chosen the largest one of these as a sample circuit for GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D which is IEEE 8500\sphinxhyphen{}Node model \sphinxcite{applications/restoration-WSU/source/overview/index:cit10}. The original 8500\sphinxhyphen{}Node test feeder operates at 12.47 kV and has a peak load of about 11 MW,
including approximately 1100 single\sphinxhyphen{}phase, center\sphinxhyphen{}tapped transformers with triplex service drops. Loads are \sphinxstyleemphasis{balanced} between the two center\sphinxhyphen{}tapped windings. The circuit includes 4 shunt capacitor banks and 6 voltage regulator banks, making it a reasonable test for solving voltage problems such as VVO. The circuit is splitted into three substation and several new distributed energy resources (DERs) are added in the test case (See Fig. 3). In addition, 7 tie switches are added such that each substation can share the load of another substation during fault to restore the outage customers. A new set of loads is added near S2 and the region is referred to as a new neighborhood.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The detailed model of this feeder can be found at:

\end{itemize}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
https://github.com/GRIDAPPSD/Powergrid\PYGZhy{}Models/tree/develop/blazegraph/test/dss/WSU
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The OpenDSS data can be extracted here:

\end{itemize}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
https://github.com/shpoudel/D\PYGZhy{}Net
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=1801\sphinxpxdimen,height=723\sphinxpxdimen]{{8500}.PNG}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleemphasis{Figure 3: Modified IEEE 85000\sphinxhyphen{}node feeder.}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The model in GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D came from the IEEE 8500\sphinxhyphen{}Node input files distributed with
OpenDSS, exported to CIM from OpenDSS, and then imported to the GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D data
manager. In this automated process, four changes were implemented:
\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Use constant\sphinxhyphen{}current load models, rather than constant\sphinxhyphen{}power load models}. This is necessary for the solution to converge at peak load.  Voltages at peak load are low, and a constant\sphinxhyphen{}power load will draw more current under those conditions. Holding the current magnitude constant allows GridLAB\sphinxhyphen{}D to achieve convergence under a variety of operating conditions. This is an appropriate compromise in accuracy for real\sphinxhyphen{}time applications, which need to be robust through wide variations in voltage and load. In contrast, planning applications usually need more accurate load models, even at the possible expense of re\sphinxhyphen{}running some non\sphinxhyphen{}converged simulations.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Disable automatic regulator and capacitor controls}. The volt\sphinxhyphen{}var application, described below, will supersede these settings. If a developer or user is testing the GridLAB\sphinxhyphen{}D model outside of GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D, these control settings should be re\sphinxhyphen{}enabled in order to solve the circuit at peak load. That requires manual un\sphinxhyphen{}commenting edits to the GridLAB\sphinxhyphen{}D input file.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Substitute a variable called VSOURCE for the SWING bus nominal voltage}.  This needs to be set at 1.05 per\sphinxhyphen{}unit of nominal on the 115\sphinxhyphen{}kV system (i.e. 69715.065) in order to solve at peak load. Other conditions may require different source voltage values.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Use a schedule for the loads} so they can vary with time during GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D simulation. The file should be named \sphinxstyleemphasis{zipload\_schedule.player}.

\end{enumerate}

\subsection{Adding an event}
\label{\detokenize{applications/restoration-WSU/source/hosted_applications/index:adding-an-event}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Since we are running the restoration application, a fault event is required to trigger the application. Before proceeding, an event file is required. There are several ways to add event in the test feeder. Here, we use the upload option and use the following JSON file.

\end{itemize}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{o}{\PYGZob{}}
  \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}commandEvents\PYGZdq{}}: \PYG{o}{[}
    \PYG{o}{\PYGZob{}}
      \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}message\PYGZdq{}}: \PYG{o}{\PYGZob{}}
        \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}forward\PYGZus{}differences\PYGZdq{}}: \PYG{o}{[}
          \PYG{o}{\PYGZob{}}
            \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}object\PYGZdq{}}: \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}\PYGZus{}24A93B95\PYGZhy{}B674\PYGZhy{}4451\PYGZhy{}8670\PYGZhy{}35391D5F51F0\PYGZdq{}},
            \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}attribute\PYGZdq{}}: \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}Switch.open\PYGZdq{}},
            \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}value\PYGZdq{}}: \PYG{l+m}{1}
          \PYG{o}{\PYGZcb{}}
        \PYG{o}{]},
        \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}reverse\PYGZus{}differences\PYGZdq{}}: \PYG{o}{[}
          \PYG{o}{\PYGZob{}}
            \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}object\PYGZdq{}}: \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}\PYGZus{}24A93B95\PYGZhy{}B674\PYGZhy{}4451\PYGZhy{}8670\PYGZhy{}35391D5F51F0\PYGZdq{}},
            \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}attribute\PYGZdq{}}: \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}Switch.open\PYGZdq{}},
            \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}value\PYGZdq{}}: \PYG{l+m}{0}
          \PYG{o}{\PYGZcb{}}
        \PYG{o}{]}
      \PYG{o}{\PYGZcb{}},
      \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}event\PYGZus{}type\PYGZdq{}}: \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}ScheduledCommandEvent\PYGZdq{}},
      \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}occuredDateTime\PYGZdq{}}: \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}2013\PYGZhy{}07\PYGZhy{}14 08:02:00\PYGZdq{}},
      \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}stopDateTime\PYGZdq{}}: \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}2013\PYGZhy{}07\PYGZhy{}14 09:00:00\PYGZdq{}}
    \PYG{o}{\PYGZcb{}}
  \PYG{o}{]}
\PYG{o}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
This event opens a switch (LN0895780\_SW) in the feeder at time 2013\sphinxhyphen{}07\sphinxhyphen{}14 08:02:00 and remains open until 09:00:00. Please adjust the \sphinxstyleemphasis{Start time} in Simulation Configuration based on \sphinxstyleemphasis{occuredDateTime} of the event such that event occurs after the simulation has started.

\end{itemize}


\subsection{Running the platform}
\label{\detokenize{applications/restoration-WSU/source/hosted_applications/index:running-the-platform}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
After few seconds, the test\sphinxhyphen{}feeder will load. In the meantime, use “Edit plots” to add power, voltage and tap of different components to visualize as the simulation progress.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Click on the triangle to start the simulation. Once you get the Simulation\_ID, use it to run the application in terminal. See the python command \sphinxhref{https://gridappsd-restoration.readthedocs.io/en/latest/system\_confguration/index.html\#executing-the-application-container}{here}.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Note that the WSU\sphinxhyphen{}Restoration application gets triggered only when the fault event is added in the test case. During normal operation, application stays quite. The occurrence of the event can be verified on the Alarm tab. Once the event has occured, the applicatin starts and runs the optimization problem to generate the candidate switches for optimal circuit reconfiguration. The candidate switches are toggled and the system is restored.

\end{itemize}

\chapter{Volt\sphinxhyphen{}Var Optimization (WSU)}
\label{\detokenize{applications/VVO-WSU/README:volt-var-optimization-wsu}}\label{\detokenize{applications/VVO-WSU/README::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This repository contains the restoration application for IEEE 9500\sphinxhyphen{}node model (https://github.com/GRIDAPPSD/Powergrid\sphinxhyphen{}Models/tree/develop/blazegraph/test/dss/WSU). The application is hosted on GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D platform.


\section{Layout}
\label{\detokenize{applications/VVO-WSU/README:layout}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Please clone the repository https://github.com/GRIDAPPSD/gridappsd\sphinxhyphen{}docker (refered to as gridappsd\sphinxhyphen{}docker repository) next to this repository (they should both have the same parent folder)


\section{Creating the restoration application container}
\label{\detokenize{applications/VVO-WSU/README:creating-the-restoration-application-container}}\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
From the command line execute the following commands to build the wsu\sphinxhyphen{}restoration container

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+go}{osboxes@osboxes\PYGZgt{} cd WSU\PYGZhy{}VVO\PYGZhy{}app}
\PYG{g+go}{osboxes@osboxes\PYGZgt{} docker build \PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}network=host \PYGZhy{}t wsu\PYGZhy{}vvo\PYGZhy{}app .}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Add the following to the gridappsd\sphinxhyphen{}docker/docker\sphinxhyphen{}compose.yml file

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nt}{wsu\PYGZus{}vvo}\PYG{p}{:}
  \PYG{n+nt}{image}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{wsu\PYGZhy{}vvo\PYGZhy{}app}
  \PYG{n+nt}{depends\PYGZus{}on}\PYG{p}{:} 
    \PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{gridappsd}    
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Run the docker application

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+go}{osboxes@osboxes\PYGZgt{} cd gridappsd\PYGZhy{}docker}
\PYG{g+go}{osboxes@osboxes\PYGZgt{} ./run.sh}

\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZsh{} }you will now be inside the container, the following starts gridappsd

\PYG{g+gp}{gridappsd@f4ede7dacb7d:/gridappsd\PYGZdl{} }./run\PYGZhy{}gridappsd.sh
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Run the application container

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+go}{osboxes@osboxes\PYGZgt{} cd WSU\PYGZhy{}VVO\PYGZhy{}app}
\PYG{g+go}{osboxes@osboxes\PYGZgt{} docker exec \PYGZhy{}it gridappsddocker\PYGZus{}wsu\PYGZus{}vvo\PYGZus{}1 bash}

\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZsh{} }you will now be inside the application container, the following runs the application from terminal

\PYG{g+gp}{root@1b762c641f24:/usr/src/gridappsd\PYGZhy{}vvo\PYGZsh{} }\PYG{n+nb}{cd} wsu\PYGZus{}vvo
\PYG{g+gp}{root@1b762c641f24:/usr/src/gridappsd\PYGZhy{}vvo/wsu\PYGZus{}vvo\PYGZsh{} }python main.py \PYG{l+m}{1234} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}\PYGZob{}\PYGZdq{}power\PYGZus{}system\PYGZus{}config\PYGZdq{}:  \PYGZob{}\PYGZdq{}Line\PYGZus{}name\PYGZdq{}:\PYGZdq{}\PYGZus{}AAE94E4A\PYGZhy{}2465\PYGZhy{}6F5E\PYGZhy{}37B1\PYGZhy{}3E72183A4E44\PYGZdq{}\PYGZcb{}\PYGZcb{}\PYGZsq{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\end{enumerate}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Next to start the application through the viz follow the directions here: https://gridappsd.readthedocs.io/en/latest/using\_gridappsd/index.html\#start\sphinxhyphen{}gridapps\sphinxhyphen{}d\sphinxhyphen{}platform


\section{Forming optimization problem}
\label{\detokenize{applications/VVO-WSU/README:forming-optimization-problem}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
In the optimization problem, test feeders are modeled as graph; G (V, E), where V is set of nodes and E is set of edges. The graph and line parameters of the test feeder can be extracted from (https://github.com/shpoudel/D\sphinxhyphen{}Net).


\section{Get real\sphinxhyphen{}time topology and load data of the test case}
\label{\detokenize{applications/VVO-WSU/README:get-real-time-topology-and-load-data-of-the-test-case}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
First, the real time topology of the test case is extracted from the operating feeder in platform (top\_identify.py). Then, load data for each node is obtained (get\_Load.py) and stored in json format to be used in linear power flow while writing constraints for optimization problem.

\section{Creating the der\sphinxhyphen{}dispatch\sphinxhyphen{}app application container}

\item {}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]

\chapter{Solar Forecasting (NREL)}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Solar\sphinxhyphen{}Forecast GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Application


\section{Purpose}
\label{\detokenize{applications/solar-forecast-NREL/README:purpose}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The application to forecast GHI data


\section{Requirements}
\label{\detokenize{applications/solar-forecast-NREL/README:requirements}}\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Docker ce version 17.12 or better.  You can install this via the docker\_install\_ubuntu.sh script.  (note for mint you will need to modify the file to work with xenial rather than ubuntu generically)

\end{enumerate}


\section{Quick Start}
\label{\detokenize{applications/solar-forecast-NREL/README:quick-start}}\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Please clone the repository \sphinxurl{https://github.com/GRIDAPPSD/gridappsd-docker} (refered to as gridappsd\sphinxhyphen{}docker repository) next to this repository (they should both have the same parent folder)

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]

\PYG{g+go}{git clone https://github.nrel.gov/PSEC/Solar\PYGZhy{}Forecasting}

\PYG{g+go}{ls \PYGZhy{}l}

\PYG{g+go}{drwxrwxr\PYGZhy{}x  5 osboxes osboxes 4096 Sep  4 19:06 Solar\PYGZhy{}Forecasting}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\end{enumerate}


\section{Creating the sample\sphinxhyphen{}app application container}
\label{\detokenize{applications/solar-forecast-NREL/README:creating-the-sample-app-application-container}}\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
From the command line execute the following commands to build the sample\sphinxhyphen{}app container

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+go}{osboxes@osboxes\PYGZgt{} cd Solar\PYGZhy{}Forecasting}
\PYG{g+go}{osboxes@osboxes\PYGZgt{} docker build \PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}network=host \PYGZhy{}t solar\PYGZhy{}forecasting\PYGZhy{}app .}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Add the following to the gridappsd\sphinxhyphen{}docker/docker\sphinxhyphen{}compose.yml file

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
  \PYG{n+nt}{solar\PYGZus{}forecast}\PYG{p}{:}
    \PYG{n+nt}{image}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{solar\PYGZhy{}forecast\PYGZhy{}app}
    \PYG{n+nt}{ports}\PYG{p}{:}
      \PYG{p+pIndicator}{\PYGZhy{}} \PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{9002:9002}
    \PYG{n+nt}{environment}\PYG{p}{:}
      \PYG{n+nt}{GRIDAPPSD\PYGZus{}URI}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{tcp://gridappsd:61613}
    \PYG{n+nt}{depends\PYGZus{}on}\PYG{p}{:}
      \PYG{p+pIndicator}{\PYGZhy{}} \PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{gridappsd}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Run the docker application

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+go}{osboxes@osboxes\PYGZgt{} cd gridappsd\PYGZhy{}docker}
\PYG{g+go}{osboxes@osboxes\PYGZgt{} ./run.sh \PYGZhy{}t develop}

\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZsh{} }you will now be inside the container, the following starts gridappsd

\PYG{g+gp}{gridappsd@f4ede7dacb7d:/gridappsd\PYGZdl{} }./run\PYGZhy{}gridappsd.sh
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\item {}

Run bokeh on port 9002

\chapter{GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D DNP3 Service}
\label{\detokenize{services/dnp3/source/index:gridapps-d-dnp3-service}}\label{\detokenize{services/dnp3/source/index::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D DNP3 service is an application service to integrate GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D
and a Distrbuted Newtork Protocol(DNP3){[}1{]} based commercial product that
allows operation, monitoring, analysis, restoration, and optimization of
network operations to enable data exchange bewteen the applications. The
DNP3 data exchange interface translates Common Information Model (CIM)
standards data within GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D to DNP3 packets and vice\sphinxhyphen{}versa to communicate
with the DNP3 based software.Likewise, the service uses the existing GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D
platform to translate DNP3 data received from SurvalentONE. The use of GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D
made the development easier because of its standardized programming interface
that unifies data integration.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Integration Architecture}

\sphinxAtStartPar
This application is implemented as an application service consisting
of python modules. DNP3 is a robust, efficient and interoperable protocol.
Its compatibility with other protocols has made this integration easier.
The integration is shown as a Master and Outstation link communication as
shown in the figure below.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics[width=1194\sphinxpxdimen,height=557\sphinxpxdimen]{{GridAPPS-D_DNP3IntegrationArchitecture}.png}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Figure 1: Integration architecture
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The commercial tool used here is SurvalentONE{[}2{]}, a DNP3 based SCADA system. The SurvalentONE SCADA system was configured as per the manuals provided by the Survalent Company. The Master server configuration includes creating a Station, Communication Link, Intelligent Electronic Device(IED) . The name and description of CIM measurement points of an IEEE model is added to a template (an excel sheet) containing all the DNP3 related metadata such as predefined datatypes, groups, variation. The template is created using a template maker provided by Survalent.Then the  template is  loaded in the Master IED of the Master server.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Once this configuration is done and the DNP3 application service is created,start the service by creating a simulation request. Since the service is added to gridapps container, it gets started as soon as the gridappsd service is started. A model dictionary file(CIM measurements) is generated for each simulation ID when a simulation request for a specific model is sent to the simulator(GridLAB\sphinxhyphen{}D). The simulation output from  the simulator running under GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D is received on the simulation output topic by the Message Bus.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The DNP3 service at the Outstation and also the Communication Line at the Master Server on startup initiate a connection request from the Master, to the IP address of the Outstation at port 20000. In our case, the Outstation listens on port 20000. The DNP3 points created from the CIM model dictionary file are loaded by the DNP3 service in the Outstation database with the datatype, attribute,

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
description etc. fields. The Master polls the Outstation every 60 seconds to update the realtime data.  The service translates model  dictionary data into DNP3 points as JSON structures.An example of a JSON packet loaded in the Outstation database and
sent to the Master is shown below.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
        \PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}attribute\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}Switch.open\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
        \PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}data\PYGZus{}type\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}DO\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
        \PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}description\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}Name:671692,ConductingEquipment\PYGZus{}type:LoadBreakSwitchPhase:B,controlAttribute:Switch.open\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
        \PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}group\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{12}\PYG{p}{,}
        \PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}index\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{14}\PYG{p}{,}
        \PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}measurement\PYGZus{}id\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}\PYGZus{}56495819\PYGZhy{}9E14\PYGZhy{}DFEC\PYGZhy{}CC01\PYGZhy{}67526BBC9987\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
        \PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}name\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}564958199E14DFECCC0167526BBC9987\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
        \PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}value\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}0\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
        \PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}variation\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The datatype, group and variation of the points are shown in the Table below.

\end{itemize}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+go}{Datatype                Group   Variation       Examples                                Control/Status                  Sent From}
\PYG{g+go}{\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}          \PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}  \PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}      \PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}                  \PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}               \PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}}
\PYG{g+go}{Analog  Output          42      3               Solar Panels, Capacitors, Regulators    Control(Update set points)      Master to Outstation}
\PYG{g+go}{Analog Input            30      1               AC Line segment                         Measurement values               Outstation to Master}
\PYG{g+go}{Digital Output          12      1               Switches,reclosers                      Control, Enable, Disable        Master to Outstation}
\PYG{g+go}{Digital Input           1       2               Breakers                                Status                          Outstation to Master}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The on\_message function in the service code keeps on updating the real\sphinxhyphen{}time

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
values for all the DNP3 points in Master server. The status and amgnitude values
updates can be seen in the User Interfaces(Point viewers) provided by Survalent.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
SurvalentONE SCADA has the capability of controlling the points/measurements.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The output commands are generated using the point viewers’ user interface.
For example, a switch can be turned ON/OFF by selecting the control option
manually. Similarly, analog values the AC Line segment can also be modified.
The control points can be chosen from the options in the telemetry of the points.
For a binary point five different inputs can be sent. The control inputs are
sent in the form of OpenDNP3 Control relay Output Block commands to the
Outstation and translated to CIM difference messages, sent back to FNCS bridge
and then to the simulator. OpenDNP3 is an implementation of the DNP3 communication
in the form of a library which provides C++ programming APIs{[}3{]}. The analog
points can also be modified in a similar way. The values can be set and sent as
an OpenDNP3 AnalogOutputInt16 command. The command has the value and status as input
to the Outstation.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Results}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The integration was tested using a 13\sphinxhyphen{}bus system. The JSON stored in Oustation
database as shown in the example above is created for all the CIM measurement
values in the dictionary file. An example of logs from Outstation at service
start\sphinxhyphen{}up is shown below.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{Adding} \PYG{n}{Point}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{PointDefinition} \PYG{l+m+mi}{00730}\PYG{n}{ee504e148bf917fe47d5be16e6f} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mf}{30.1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{index}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nb}{type}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{Analog} \PYG{n}{Input}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{Recording} \PYG{n}{DNP3} \PYG{n}{Analog} \PYG{n}{measurement}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{index}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{88}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n}{value}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mf}{564.143691452854}
\PYG{n}{Recording} \PYG{n}{DNP3} \PYG{n}{Binary} \PYG{n}{measurement}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{index}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{10}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n}{value}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{k+kc}{True}
\PYG{n}{Recording} \PYG{n}{DNP3} \PYG{n}{Binary} \PYG{n}{measurement}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{index}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{13}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n}{value}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{k+kc}{True}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The control input from Master by sending a PULSE\_OFF command for a switch which
is an  OpenDNP3 command sent from Master to Outstation as shown below.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{cmdtype}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{Operate}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n}{command}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{pydnp3}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{opendnp3}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{ControlRelayOutputBlock} \PYG{n+nb}{object} \PYG{n}{at}
\PYG{l+m+mh}{0x7fd1f69527d8}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n}{index}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{4}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n}{optype}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{OperateType}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{SELECT\PYGZus{}BEFORE\PYGZus{}OPERATE}

\PYG{n}{Received} \PYG{n}{DNP3} \PYG{n}{Point} \PYG{n}{value} \PYG{n}{ControlCode}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{PULSE\PYGZus{}OFF} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{6}\PYG{n}{ed7855451e84bc79db2c810d07509dd}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mf}{12.1}\PYG{l+m+mf}{.4}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{Operate}\PYG{p}{)}

\chapter{GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Sensor Simulator Service}
\label{\detokenize{services/sensor-simulator/source/index:gridapps-d-sensor-simulator-service}}\label{\detokenize{services/sensor-simulator/source/index::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The \sphinxtitleref{GridAPPSD’s Sensor Simulator} simulates real devices based upon the magnitude of “prestine” simulated values.  This
service has been specifically designed to work within the gridappsd platform container.  The \sphinxtitleref{GridAPPSD} platform will
start the service when it is specified as a dependency of an application or when a service configuration is specified
within the \sphinxhref{https://gridappsd.readthedocs.io/en/latest/using\_gridappsd/index.html}{GridAPPSD Visualization}.  The image
below shows a portion of the configuration options available through the service configuration panel.

\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics{{_static/sensor-simulator-service-configuration}.png}


\section{Python Application Usage}
\label{\detokenize{services/sensor-simulator/source/index:python-application-usage}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The python application using this service should require \sphinxtitleref{gridappsd\sphinxhyphen{}sensor\sphinxhyphen{}simulator} as a requirement.  In addition,
the following python code shows how to get the correct topic for the service.


\section{Service Configuration}
\label{\detokenize{services/sensor-simulator/source/index:service-configuration}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The sensor\sphinxhyphen{}config in the above image shows an example of how to configure a portion of the system to have sensor output.
Each mrid (\sphinxtitleref{\_99db0dc7\sphinxhyphen{}ccda\sphinxhyphen{}4ed5\sphinxhyphen{}a772\sphinxhyphen{}a7db362e9818}) will be monitored by this service and either use the default values
or use the specified values during the service runtime.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
   \PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}\PYGZus{}99db0dc7\PYGZhy{}ccda\PYGZhy{}4ed5\PYGZhy{}a772\PYGZhy{}a7db362e9818\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
      \PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}nominal\PYGZhy{}value\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{100}\PYG{p}{,}
      \PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}perunit\PYGZhy{}confidence\PYGZhy{}band\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mf}{0.01}\PYG{p}{,}
      \PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}aggregation\PYGZhy{}interval\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{30}\PYG{p}{,}
      \PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}perunit\PYGZhy{}drop\PYGZhy{}rate\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mf}{0.01}
   \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{},}
   \PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}\PYGZus{}ee65ee31\PYGZhy{}a900\PYGZhy{}4f98\PYGZhy{}bf57\PYGZhy{}e752be924c4d\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:\PYGZob{}\PYGZcb{},}
   \PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}\PYGZus{}f2673c22\PYGZhy{}654b\PYGZhy{}452a\PYGZhy{}8297\PYGZhy{}45dae11b1e14\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}\PYGZcb{}}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The other options for the service are:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
default\sphinxhyphen{}perunit\sphinxhyphen{}confidence\sphinxhyphen{}band

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
default\sphinxhyphen{}aggregation\sphinxhyphen{}interval

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
default\sphinxhyphen{}perunit\sphinxhyphen{}drop\sphinxhyphen{}rate

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
passthrough\sphinxhyphen{}if\sphinxhyphen{}not\sphinxhyphen{}specified

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
These options will be used when not specified within the sensor\sphinxhyphen{}config block.

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Currently the nominal\sphinxhyphen{}value is not looked up from the database.  At this time services aren’t able to tell
the platform when they are “ready”.  This will be implemented in the near future and then all of the nominal\sphinxhyphen{}values
will be queried from the database.
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\chapter{GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D Voltage Violation Service}
\label{\detokenize{services/voltage-violation/README:gridapps-d-voltage-violation-service}}\label{\detokenize{services/voltage-violation/README::doc}}

\section{Purpose}
\label{\detokenize{services/voltage-violation/README:purpose}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This is a GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D service that calculates and publishes voltage voilations during a simulation.
Voltage violations are published every 15 seconds by default.


\section{Topics}
\label{\detokenize{services/voltage-violation/README:topics}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Subscribes to simulation output topic /topic/goss.gridappsd.simulation.output.{[}simulation\_id{]}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Publishes on topic /topic/goss.gridappsd.simulation.voltage\_violation.{[}simulation\_id{]}.output

\end{itemize}


\section{Message Structure}
\label{\detokenize{services/voltage-violation/README:message-structure}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Simulation output message structure is available here: https://gridappsd.readthedocs.io/en/master/using\_gridappsd/index.html\#subscribe\sphinxhyphen{}to\sphinxhyphen{}simulation\sphinxhyphen{}output

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Voltage violation service publishes a JSON message with measurement MRIDs and their per unit voltage value. For example,

\end{itemize}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}	
	\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZus{}00730ee5\PYGZhy{}04e1\PYGZhy{}48bf\PYGZhy{}917f\PYGZhy{}e47d5be16e6f}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mf}{1.07}\PYG{p}{,} 
	\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZus{}078cfc25\PYGZhy{}8a2e\PYGZhy{}4f34\PYGZhy{}8631\PYGZhy{}0346abe2214d}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mf}{1.06}\PYG{p}{,} 
	\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZus{}40df103f\PYGZhy{}b458\PYGZhy{}4c15\PYGZhy{}a2eb\PYGZhy{}ffe7d029ef65}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mf}{1.06}\PYG{p}{,} 
	\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZus{}51fe8d20\PYGZhy{}a89e\PYGZhy{}497f\PYGZhy{}8c4b\PYGZhy{}d5bd654449bf}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mf}{1.08}

\chapter{GridAPPS\sphinxhyphen{}D State Estimator Service}
\label{\detokenize{services/state-estimator/README:gridapps-d-state-estimator-service}}\label{\detokenize{services/state-estimator/README::doc}}

\section{Purpose}
\label{\detokenize{services/state-estimator/README:purpose}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The state estimator service will produce and output the best available system state from measurements for use by other applications.


\section{State estimator service layout}
\label{\detokenize{services/state-estimator/README:state-estimator-service-layout}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The following is the structure of the state estimator:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
.
├── README.md
├── LICENSE
└── state\PYGZhy{}estimator
    ├── include
    ├── src
    ├── bin
    ├── obj
    ├── Makefile
    └── state\PYGZhy{}estimator.config
└───\PYG{o}{(}Prerequisite libraries\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}SuiteSparse, ActiveMQ\PYGZhy{}CPP, Json\PYG{o}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\section{Prerequisites}
\label{\detokenize{services/state-estimator/README:prerequisites}}\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Docker ce version 17.12 or newer is required.  You can install this via the docker\_install\_ubuntu.sh script in the gridappsd\sphinxhyphen{}docker repository described in the next step. (note for mint you will need to modify the file to work with xenial rather than ubuntu generically)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Clone the repository \sphinxurl{https://github.com/GRIDAPPSD/gridappsd-docker} (referred to as gridappsd\sphinxhyphen{}docker repository).

\end{enumerate}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYGZti{}/git
└── gridappsd\PYGZhy{}docker
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
To run the gridappsd\sphinxhyphen{}docker platform, follow the instructions provided at \sphinxurl{https://github.com/GRIDAPPSD/gridappsd-docker/README.md}.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
To configure and run a simulation under the platform, follow the instructions provided at \sphinxurl{https://gridappsd.readthedocs.io/en/master/using\_gridappsd}.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The state estimator is distributed pre\sphinxhyphen{}built under the gridappsd\sphinxhyphen{}docker repository, but you may instead build the state estimator from source code from its own repository if you wish to modify it, run a different branch than master, or otherwise run it outside the gridappsd\sphinxhyphen{}docker container.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
If you wish to run the state estimator provided with gridappsd\sphinxhyphen{}docker, follow the instructions in the following section, {\hyperref[\detokenize{services/state-estimator/README:running-state-estimator-from-the-gridappsd-docker-container}]{\emph{Running state estimator from the gridappsd\sphinxhyphen{}docker container}}}.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Alternatively, to build the state estimator from source code and then run that version from the command line, skip to the section {\hyperref[\detokenize{services/state-estimator/README:building-state-estimator}]{\emph{Building state estimator}}} below.

\end{enumerate}


\section{Running state estimator from the gridappsd\sphinxhyphen{}docker container}
\label{\detokenize{services/state-estimator/README:running-state-estimator-from-the-gridappsd-docker-container}}\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Configure the simulation from the GRIDAPPSD platform web browser visualization.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Click on the “Service Configuration” tab and then click on the checkbox under the gridappsd\sphinxhyphen{}state\sphinxhyphen{}estimator section of the configuration user interface to specify that state estimator should be started with the simulation.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Click on the “Submit” button and then the play button to start the simulation.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The state estimator will process running simulation measurements producing state estimate messages for other applications.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The gridappsd\sphinxhyphen{}state\sphinxhyphen{}plotter application can be used to plot state estimator output as described at \sphinxurl{https://github.com/GRIDAPPSD/gridappsd-state-plotter}.

\end{enumerate}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The remainder of these instructions apply only when building the state estimator from source code and running that build from the command line.


\section{Building state estimator}
\label{\detokenize{services/state-estimator/README:building-state-estimator}}\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Clone the repository \sphinxurl{https://github.com/GRIDAPPSD/gridappsd-state-estimator} next to the gridappsd\sphinxhyphen{}docker repository (they should both have the same parent folder, assumed to be \textasciitilde{}/git in docker\sphinxhyphen{}compose.yml)

\end{enumerate}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYGZti{}/git
├── gridappsd\PYGZhy{}docker
└── gridappsd\PYGZhy{}state\PYGZhy{}estimator
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Then the following two repositories should be cloned under the top\sphinxhyphen{}level gridappsd\sphinxhyphen{}state\sphinxhyphen{}estimator directory of the repository cloned above

\end{enumerate}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
	\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}} \PYG{n}{https}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{github}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{com}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{GRIDAPPSD}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{SuiteSparse}
	\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}} \PYG{n}{https}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{github}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{com}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{GRIDAPPSD}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{json}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The ActiveMQ C++ client library, ActiveMQ\sphinxhyphen{}CPP, should be downloaded from the URL below as a Unix source code distrubtion.  Both the 3.9.4 and 3.9.5 releases have been successfully used with state estimator.  The tar.gz or tar.bz2 distribution should be extracted under the gridappsd\sphinxhyphen{}state\sphinxhyphen{}estimator directory, the same location as the SuiteSparse and json repositories.

\end{enumerate}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
    \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}} \PYG{n}{https}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{activemq}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{apache}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{org}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{components}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{cms}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{download}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Building prerequisite libraries requires some other packages to be installed first.  The following apt\sphinxhyphen{}get install commands should install those packages if they are not already installed:

\end{enumerate}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
sudo apt\PYGZhy{}get install cmake
sudo apt\PYGZhy{}get install m4
sudo apt\PYGZhy{}get install liblapack\PYGZhy{}dev libblas\PYGZhy{}dev
sudo apt\PYGZhy{}get install libapr1 libapr1\PYGZhy{}dev
sudo apt\PYGZhy{}get install libssl\PYGZhy{}dev
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
From the gridappsd\sphinxhyphen{}state\sphinxhyphen{}estimator directory, run the following commands to build the prerequisite libraries and then the state\sphinxhyphen{}estimator executable:

\end{enumerate}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nb}{cd} activemq\PYGZhy{}cpp\PYGZhy{}library\PYGZhy{}*
./configure
make
sudo make install

\PYG{n+nb}{cd} ../SuiteSparse
make \PYG{n+nv}{LAPACK}\PYG{o}{=}\PYGZhy{}llapack \PYG{n+nv}{BLAS}\PYG{o}{=}\PYGZhy{}lblas

\PYG{n+nb}{cd} ../state\PYGZhy{}estimator
make
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The executable application will be placed in bin/state\sphinxhyphen{}estimator.  The Json distribution consists entirely of include files and therefore is not compiled separately from the application using it.

\end{enumerate}


\section{Running state estimator from the command line}
\label{\detokenize{services/state-estimator/README:running-state-estimator-from-the-command-line}}\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Edit the run\sphinxhyphen{}se.sh script in the state\sphinxhyphen{}estimator subdirectory of the top\sphinxhyphen{}level gridappsd\sphinxhyphen{}state\sphinxhyphen{}estimator repository, uncomment the appropriate SIMREQ variable for the model being run based on the comment at the end of each SIMREQ line denoting the corresponding model, and save changes.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Configure and start the simulation from the GRIDAPPSD platform web browser visualization, click on the “Simulation ID” value in the upper left corner of the simulation diagram to copy the value to the clipboard.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Invoke the script “./run\sphinxhyphen{}se.sh” from the command line with the Simulation ID value pasted from the clipboard as the command line argument to the script.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The state estimator will process running simulation measurements producing state estimate messages for other applications along with diagnostic log output to the terminal.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The gridappsd\sphinxhyphen{}state\sphinxhyphen{}plotter application can be used to plot state estimator output as described at \sphinxurl{https://github.com/GRIDAPPSD/gridappsd-state-plotter}.

\end{enumerate}
